category.description: DISA ASD STIG
category.name: APSC_DV

category.description: APSC_DV-002550 The application must not be vulnerable to XML-oriented attacks.

rule.header: Never use unfiltered data from an untrusted user as the format parameter
Untrusted data is used as a loop boundary

category.description: APSC_DV-002560 The application must not be subject to input handling vulnerabilities.

rule.header: Never use unfiltered data from an untrusted user as the format parameter
Untrusted data is used as a loop boundary

category.description: APSC_DV-003110 The application must not contain embedded authentication data.

rule.header: Do not hard code string literals

category.description: APSC_DV-000160 The application must implement DoD-approved encryption to protect the confidentiality of remote access sessions.

rule.header: Do not use weak encryption functions

category.description: APSC_DV-000170 The application must implement cryptographic mechanisms to protect the integrity of remote access sessions.

rule.header: Do not use weak encryption functions

category.description: APSC_DV-000500 The application must prevent non-privileged users from executing privileged functions to include disabling, circumventing, or altering implemented security safeguards/countermeasures.

rule.header: Observe correct revocation order while relinquishing privileges

category.description: APSC_DV-000650 The application must not write sensitive data into the application logs.

rule.header: Do not print potentially sensitive information, resulting from an application error into exception messages

category.description: APSC_DV-001290 The application must protect audit information from unauthorized modification.

rule.header: Untrusted data is used as a loop boundary
Avoid passing user input into methods as parameters
Avoid using unsecured shell functions that may be affected by shell metacharacters

category.description: APSC_DV-001860 The application must use mechanisms meeting the requirements of applicable federal laws, Executive Orders, directives, policies, regulations, standards, and guidance for authentication to a cryptographic module.

rule.header: Do not use weak encryption functions

category.description: APSC_DV-001995 The application must not be vulnerable to race conditions.

rule.header: Avoid using thread-unsafe functions
Usage of functions prone to race is not allowed
Avoid using the 'vfork()' function

category.description: APSC_DV-002010 The application must implement NSA-approved cryptography to protect classified information in accordance with applicable federal laws, Executive Orders, directives, policies, regulations, and standards.

rule.header: Do not use weak encryption functions

category.description: APSC_DV-002290 The application must use the Federal Information Processing Standard (FIPS) 140-2-validated cryptographic modules and random number generator if the application implements encryption, key exchange, digital signature, and hash functionality.

rule.header: Do not use the rand() function for generating pseudorandom numbers
The 'random_shuffle' identifier should not be used
The random number generator functions 'rand()' and 'srand()' should not be used

category.description: APSC_DV-002350 The application must use appropriate cryptography in order to protect stored DoD information when required by the information owner or DoD policy.

rule.header: Do not use weak encryption functions

category.description: APSC_DV-002390 XML-based applications must mitigate DoS attacks by using XML filters, parser options, or gateways.

rule.header: Do not process structured text data natively
Do not use scanf and fscanf functions without specifying variable size in format string
Do not use mbstowcs() function

category.description: APSC_DV-002400 The application must restrict the ability to launch Denial of Service (DoS) attacks against itself or other information systems.

rule.header: The execution of a function registered with 'std::atexit()' or 'std::at_quick_exit()' should not exit via an exception
Avoid using the 'vfork()' function
Avoid using thread-unsafe functions

category.description: APSC_DV-002480 The application must not disclose unnecessary information to users.

rule.header: Do not print potentially sensitive information, resulting from an application error into exception messages

category.description: APSC_DV-002520 The application must protect from canonical representation vulnerabilities.

rule.header: Never use unfiltered data from an untrusted user as the format parameter
Untrusted data is used as a loop boundary

category.description: APSC_DV-002530 The application must validate all input.

rule.header: Never use unfiltered data from an untrusted user as the format parameter
Untrusted data is used as a loop boundary

category.description: APSC_DV-002570 The application must generate error messages that provide information necessary for corrective actions without revealing information that could be exploited by adversaries.

rule.header: Do not print potentially sensitive information, resulting from an application error into exception messages

category.description: SEI CERT C
category.name: CERT_C

category.description: CERT-ARR01_C (REC) Do not apply the sizeof operator to a pointer when taking the size of an array
category.name: ARR01

rule.header: Do not call 'sizeof' on a pointer type

category.description: CERT-DCL20_C (REC) Explicitly specify void when a function accepts no arguments
category.name: DCL20

rule.header: The number of arguments passed to a function shall match the number of parameters

category.description: CERT-ENV01_C (REC) Do not make assumptions about the size of an environment variable
category.name: ENV01

rule.header: Don't use unsafe C functions that do write to range-unchecked buffers
Avoid using unsafe string functions which may cause buffer overflows

category.description: CERT-ENV33_C (RULE) Do not call system()
category.name: ENV33

rule.header: Do not call the 'system()' function from the 'stdlib.h' or 'cstdlib' library with an argument other than '0' (null pointer)

category.description: CERT-ERR33_C (RULE) Detect and handle standard library errors
category.name: ERR33

rule.header: The value returned by a standard library function that may return an error should be used
The standard library functions for which return values need not be checked should be cast to 'void'

category.description: CERT-EXP20_C (REC) Perform explicit tests to determine success, true and false, and equality
category.name: EXP20

rule.header: Avoid comparing values with TRUE macro/enum constant using equality operators ("==", "!=")
Tests of a value against zero should be made explicit, unless the operand is effectively Boolean

category.description: CERT-FIO01_C (REC) Be careful using functions that use file names for identification
category.name: FIO01

rule.header: Don't use chmod(), chown(), chgrp()
Usage of functions prone to race is not allowed

category.description: CERT-FIO30_C (RULE) Exclude user input from format strings
category.name: FIO30

rule.header: Avoid calling functions printf/wprintf with only one argument other than string constant
Avoid using functions fprintf/fwprintf with only two parameters, when second parameter is a variable
Never use unfiltered data from an untrusted user as the format parameter

category.description: CERT-INT18_C (REC) Evaluate integer expressions in a larger size before comparing or assigning to that size
category.name: INT18

rule.header: Avoid possible integer overflow in expressions in which the result is assigned to a variable of a wider integer type
Avoid possible integer overflow in expressions in which the result is compared to an expression of a wider integer type
Avoid possible integer overflow in expressions in which the result is cast to a wider integer type

category.description: CERT-MEM00_C (REC) Allocate and free memory in the same module, at the same level of abstraction
category.name: MEM00

rule.header: Do not allocate memory and expect that someone else will deallocate it later
Do not allocate memory and expect that someone else will deallocate it later
Do not allocate memory and expect that someone else will deallocate it later

category.description: CERT-MSC15_C (REC) Do not depend on undefined behavior
category.name: MSC15

rule.header: Evaluation of constant unsigned integer expressions should not lead to wrap-around

category.description: CERT-MSC17_C (REC) Finish every set of statements associated with a case label with a break statement
category.name: MSC17

rule.header: Missing break statement between cases in a switch statement

category.description: CERT-MSC33_C (RULE) Do not pass invalid data to the asctime() function
category.name: MSC33

rule.header: The 'asctime()' and 'asctime_r()' functions should not be used

category.description: CERT-MSC41_C (RULE) Never hard code sensitive information
category.name: MSC41

rule.header: Do not hard code string literals

category.description: CERT-POS30_C (RULE) Use the readlink() function properly
category.name: POS30

rule.header: The values returned by functions 'read' and 'readlink' shall be used
Use of possibly not null-terminated string with functions expecting null-terminated string

category.description: CERT-POS36_C (RULE) Observe correct revocation order while relinquishing privileges
category.name: POS36

rule.header: Observe correct revocation order while relinquishing privileges

category.description: CERT-POS37_C (RULE) Ensure that privilege relinquishment is successful
category.name: POS37

rule.header: Ensure that privilege relinquishment is successful

category.description: CERT-POS47_C (RULE) Do not use threads that can be canceled asynchronously
category.name: POS47

rule.header: The function 'pthread_setcanceltype()' should not be called with 'PTHREAD_CANCEL_ASYNCHRONOUS' argument

category.description: CERT-POS54_C (RULE) Detect and handle POSIX library errors
category.name: POS54

rule.header: The value returned by a POSIX library function that may return an error should be used

category.description: CERT-PRE01_C (REC) Use parentheses within macros around parameter names
category.name: PRE01

rule.header: In the definition of a function-like macro each instance of a parameter shall be enclosed in parentheses unless it is used as the operand of # or ##

category.description: CERT-PRE02_C (REC) Macro replacement lists should be parenthesized
category.name: PRE02

rule.header: Enclose in parentheses whole definition of a function-like macro

category.description: CERT-SIG02_C (REC) Avoid using signals to implement normal functionality
category.name: SIG02

rule.header: The signal handling facilities of <signal.h> shall not be used

category.description: CERT-STR00_C (REC) Represent characters using an appropriate type
category.name: STR00

rule.header: The plain char type shall be used only for the storage and use of character values

category.description: CERT-STR07_C (REC) Use the bounds-checking interfaces for string manipulation
category.name: STR07

rule.header: Avoid using unsafe string functions that do not check bounds

category.description: CERT-STR31_C (RULE) Guarantee that storage for strings has sufficient space for character data and the null terminator
category.name: STR31

rule.header: Avoid using unsafe string functions which may cause buffer overflows

category.description: CERT-STR38_C (RULE) Do not confuse narrow and wide character strings and functions
category.name: STR38

rule.header: Do not confuse narrow and wide character strings and functions

category.description: CERT-API02_C (REC) Functions that read or write to or from an array should take an argument to specify the source or target size
category.name: API02

rule.header: Avoid using unsafe string functions which may cause buffer overflows
Don't use unsafe C functions that do write to range-unchecked buffers

category.description: CERT-ARR02_C (REC) Explicitly specify array bounds, even if implicitly defined by an initializer
category.name: ARR02

rule.header: Explicitly specify array bounds in array declarations with initializers

category.description: CERT-ARR37_C (RULE) Do not add or subtract an integer to a pointer to a non-array object
category.name: ARR37

rule.header: Pointer arithmetic shall not be applied to pointers that address variables of non-array type

category.description: CERT-ARR39_C (RULE) Do not add or subtract a scaled integer to a pointer
category.name: ARR39

rule.header: Pointer arithmetic should not be used
Do not add or subtract a scaled integer to a pointer

category.description: CERT-CON02_C (REC) Do not use volatile as a synchronization primitive
category.name: CON02

rule.header: Do not use the volatile keyword

category.description: CERT-CON37_C (RULE) Do not call signal() in a multithreaded program
category.name: CON37

rule.header: The signal handling facilities of <signal.h> shall not be used

category.description: CERT-CON40_C (RULE) Do not refer to an atomic variable twice in an expression
category.name: CON40

rule.header: Do not refer to an atomic variable twice in an expression

category.description: CERT-DCL10_C (REC) Maintain the contract between the writer and caller of variadic functions
category.name: DCL10

rule.header: The number of format specifiers in the format string and the number of corresponding arguments in the invocation of a string formatting function should be equal

category.description: CERT-DCL11_C (REC) Understand the type issues associated with variadic functions
category.name: DCL11

rule.header: There should be no mismatch between the '%s' and '%c' format specifiers in the format string and their corresponding arguments in the invocation of a string formatting function
There should be no mismatch between the '%f' format specifier in the format string and its corresponding argument in the invocation of a string formatting function
There should be no mismatch between the '%i' and '%d' format specifiers in the string and their corresponding arguments in the invocation of a string formatting function
There should be no mismatch between the '%u' format specifier in the format string and its corresponding argument in the invocation of a string formatting function
There should be no mismatch between the '%p' format specifier in the format string and its corresponding argument in the invocation of a string formatting function
The number of format specifiers in the format string and the number of corresponding arguments in the invocation of a string formatting function should be equal

category.description: CERT-DCL30_C (RULE) Declare objects with appropriate storage durations
category.name: DCL30

rule.header: The address of an object with automatic storage shall not be returned from a function
The address of an object with automatic storage shall not be assigned to another object that may persist after the first object has ceased to exist

category.description: CERT-DCL36_C (RULE) Do not declare an identifier with conflicting linkage classifications
category.name: DCL36

rule.header: Identifiers shall not simultaneously have both internal and external linkage in the same translation unit

category.description: CERT-ERR01_C (REC) Use ferror() rather than errno to check for FILE stream errors
category.name: ERR01

rule.header: The error indicator 'errno' shall not be used

category.description: CERT-ERR07_C (REC) Prefer functions that support error checking over equivalent functions that don't
category.name: ERR07

rule.header: The library functions atof, atoi and atol from library stdlib.h shall not be used
The Standard Library input/output functions shall not be used

category.description: CERT-ERR30_C (RULE) Set errno to zero before calling a library function known to set errno, and check errno only after the function returns a value indicating failure
category.name: ERR30

rule.header: Provide error handling for file opening errors right next to the call to fopen

category.description: CERT-EXP05_C (REC) Do not cast away a const qualification
category.name: EXP05

rule.header: A cast shall not remove any 'const' or 'volatile' qualification from the type of a pointer or reference

category.description: CERT-EXP08_C (REC) Ensure pointer arithmetic is used correctly
category.name: EXP08

rule.header: Pointer arithmetic should not be used

category.description: CERT-EXP10_C (REC) Do not depend on the order of evaluation of subexpressions or the order in which side effects take place
category.name: EXP10

rule.header: The value of an expression shall be the same under any order of evaluation that the standard permits
Don't write code that depends on the order of evaluation of function arguments
Don't write code that depends on the order of evaluation of function designator and function arguments
Don't write code that depends on the order of evaluation of expression that involves a function call

category.description: CERT-EXP16_C (REC) Do not compare function pointers to constant values
category.name: EXP16

rule.header: Function address should not be compared to zero

category.description: CERT-EXP19_C (REC) Use braces for the body of an if, for, or while statement
category.name: EXP19

rule.header: The statement forming the body of a 'switch', 'while', 'do...while' or 'for' statement shall be a compound statement

category.description: CERT-EXP30_C (RULE) Do not depend on the order of evaluation for side effects
category.name: EXP30

rule.header: The value of an expression shall be the same under any order of evaluation that the standard permits
Don't write code that depends on the order of evaluation of function arguments
Don't write code that depends on the order of evaluation of function designator and function arguments
Don't write code that depends on the order of evaluation of expression that involves a function call

category.description: CERT-EXP32_C (RULE) Do not access a volatile object through a nonvolatile reference
category.name: EXP32

rule.header: A cast shall not remove any 'const' or 'volatile' qualification from the type of a pointer or reference

category.description: CERT-EXP42_C (RULE) Do not compare padding data
category.name: EXP42

rule.header: Don't memcpy or memcmp non-PODs

category.description: CERT-EXP45_C (RULE) Do not perform assignments in selection statements
category.name: EXP45

rule.header: Assignment operators shall not be used in conditions without brackets
Assignment operators shall not be used in expressions that yield a Boolean value

category.description: CERT-EXP46_C (RULE) Do not use a bitwise operator with a Boolean-like operand
category.name: EXP46

rule.header: Expressions that are effectively Boolean should not be used as operands to operators other than (&&, ||, !, =, ==, !=, ?:)

category.description: CERT-EXP47_C (RULE) Do not call va_arg with an argument of the incorrect type
category.name: EXP47

rule.header: Do not call va_arg with an argument of the incorrect type

category.description: CERT-FIO21_C (REC) Do not create temporary files in shared directories
category.name: FIO21

rule.header: Usage of functions prone to race is not allowed

category.description: CERT-FIO47_C (RULE) Use valid format strings
category.name: FIO47

rule.header: There should be no mismatch between the '%s' and '%c' format specifiers in the format string and their corresponding arguments in the invocation of a string formatting function
There should be no mismatch between the '%f' format specifier in the format string and its corresponding argument in the invocation of a string formatting function
There should be no mismatch between the '%i' and '%d' format specifiers in the string and their corresponding arguments in the invocation of a string formatting function
There should be no mismatch between the '%u' format specifier in the format string and its corresponding argument in the invocation of a string formatting function
There should be no mismatch between the '%p' format specifier in the format string and its corresponding argument in the invocation of a string formatting function
The number of format specifiers in the format string and the number of corresponding arguments in the invocation of a string formatting function should be equal

category.description: CERT-FLP06_C (REC) Convert integers to floating point for floating-point operations
category.name: FLP06

rule.header: Implicit conversions from integral to floating type which may result in a loss of information shall not be used
Implicit conversions from integral constant to floating type which may result in a loss of information shall not be used

category.description: CERT-FLP30_C (RULE) Do not use floating-point variables as loop counters
category.name: FLP30

rule.header: Do not use floating point variables as loop counters

category.description: CERT-INT02_C (REC) Understand integer conversion rules
category.name: INT02

rule.header: Implicit conversions from wider to narrower integral type which may result in a loss of information shall not be used
Avoid mixing arithmetic of different precisions in the same expression

category.description: CERT-INT07_C (REC) Use only explicitly signed or unsigned char type for numeric values
category.name: INT07

rule.header: The plain char type shall be used only for the storage and use of character values
signed and unsigned char type shall be used only for the storage and use of numeric values

category.description: CERT-INT13_C (REC) Use bitwise operators only on unsigned operands
category.name: INT13

rule.header: Bitwise operators shall only be applied to operands of unsigned underlying type

category.description: CERT-INT15_C (REC) Use intmax_t or uintmax_t for formatted IO on programmer-defined integer types
category.name: INT15

rule.header: Use intmax_t or uintmax_t for formatted IO on programmer-defined integer types

category.description: CERT-INT30_C (RULE) Ensure that unsigned integer operations do not wrap
category.name: INT30

rule.header: Integer overflow or underflow in constant expression in '+', '-', '*' operator
Integer overflow or underflow in constant expression in '<<' operator

category.description: CERT-INT31_C (RULE) Ensure that integer conversions do not result in lost or misinterpreted data
category.name: INT31

rule.header: An expression of essentially Boolean type should always be used where an operand is interpreted as a Boolean value
An operand of essentially Boolean type should not be used where an operand is interpreted as a numeric value
An operand of essentially character type should not be used where an operand is interpreted as a numeric value
An operand of essentially enum type should not be used in an arithmetic operation
Shift and bitwise operations should not be performed on operands of essentially signed or enum type
An operand of essentially signed or enum type should not be used as the right hand operand to the bitwise shifting operator
An operand of essentially unsigned type should not be used as the operand to the unary minus operator
The value of an expression shall not be assigned to an object with a narrower essential type
The value of an expression shall not be assigned to an object of a different essential type category
Both operands of an operator in which the usual arithmetic conversions are performed shall have the same essential type category
The second and third operands of the ternary operator shall have the same essential type category
The value of a composite expression shall not be assigned to an object with wider essential type
If a composite expression is used as one operand of an operator in which the usual arithmetic conversions are performed then the other operand shall not have wider essential type
If a composite expression is used as one (second or third) operand of a conditional operator then the other operand shall not have wider essential type

category.description: CERT-INT32_C (RULE) Ensure that operations on signed integers do not result in overflow
category.name: INT32

rule.header: Integer overflow or underflow in constant expression in '+', '-', '*' operator
Integer overflow or underflow in constant expression in '<<' operator

category.description: CERT-MEM01_C (REC) Store a new value in pointers immediately after free()
category.name: MEM01

rule.header: Always assign a new value to an expression that points to deallocated memory
Always assign a new value to global or member variable that points to deallocated memory
Always assign a new value to parameter or local variable that points to deallocated memory

category.description: CERT-MEM04_C (REC) Beware of zero-length allocations
category.name: MEM04

rule.header: The validity of values passed to library functions shall be checked

category.description: CERT-MEM07_C (REC) Ensure that the arguments to calloc(), when multiplied, do not wrap
category.name: MEM07

rule.header: The validity of values passed to library functions shall be checked

category.description: CERT-MEM35_C (RULE) Allocate sufficient memory for an object
category.name: MEM35

rule.header: Do not use sizeof operator on pointer type to specify the size of the memory to be allocated via 'malloc', 'calloc' or 'realloc' function

category.description: CERT-MSC01_C (REC) Strive for logical completeness
category.name: MSC01

rule.header: All 'if...else-if' constructs shall be terminated with an 'else' clause
The final clause of a switch statement shall be the default clause

category.description: CERT-MSC30_C (RULE) Do not use the rand() function for generating pseudorandom numbers
category.name: MSC30

rule.header: Do not use the rand() function for generating pseudorandom numbers

category.description: CERT-MSC37_C (RULE) Ensure that control never reaches the end of a non-void function
category.name: MSC37

rule.header: All exit paths from a function, except main(), with non-void return type shall have an explicit return statement with an expression

category.description: CERT-POS33_C (RULE) Do not use vfork()
category.name: POS33

rule.header: Avoid using the 'vfork()' function

category.description: CERT-POS34_C (RULE) Do not call putenv() with a pointer to an automatic variable as the argument
category.name: POS34

rule.header: Usage of system properties (environment variables) should be restricted

category.description: CERT-POS44_C (RULE) Do not use signals to terminate threads
category.name: POS44

rule.header: The 'pthread_kill', 'pthread_sigqueue' and 'tgkill' functions should not be used to send signals to threads

category.description: CERT-SIG00_C (REC) Mask signals handled by noninterruptible signal handlers
category.name: SIG00

rule.header: The signal handling facilities of <signal.h> shall not be used

category.description: CERT-STR11_C (REC) Do not specify the bound of a character array initialized with a string literal
category.name: STR11

rule.header: Do not specify the bound of a character array initialized with a string literal

category.description: CERT-STR30_C (RULE) Do not attempt to modify string literals
category.name: STR30

rule.header: A string literal shall not be modified

category.description: CERT-STR34_C (RULE) Cast characters to unsigned char before converting to larger integer sizes
category.name: STR34

rule.header: Cast characters to unsigned char before assignment to larger integer sizes
An expressions of the 'signed char' type should not be used as an array index
Cast characters to unsigned char before converting to larger integer sizes

category.description: CERT-WIN00_C (REC) Be specific when dynamically loading libraries
category.name: WIN00

rule.header: Use care to ensure that LoadLibrary() will load the correct library

category.description: CERT-API00_C (REC) Functions should validate their parameters
category.name: API00

rule.header: The validity of parameters must be checked inside each function

category.description: CERT-API01_C (REC) Avoid laying out strings in memory directly before sensitive data
category.name: API01

rule.header: Avoid using unsafe string functions which may cause buffer overflows

category.description: CERT-CON33_C (RULE) Avoid race conditions when using library functions
category.name: CON33

rule.header: Avoid using thread-unsafe functions

category.description: CERT-CON36_C (RULE) Wrap functions that can spuriously wake up in a loop
category.name: CON36

rule.header: Wrap functions that can spuriously wake up in a loop

category.description: CERT-CON38_C (RULE) Preserve thread safety and liveness when using condition variables
category.name: CON38

rule.header: Use the 'cnd_signal()' function with a unique condition variable

category.description: CERT-CON41_C (RULE) Wrap functions that can fail spuriously in a loop
category.name: CON41

rule.header: Wrap functions that can fail spuriously in a loop

category.description: CERT-DCL00_C (REC) Const-qualify immutable objects
category.name: DCL00

rule.header: Declare local variable as const whenever possible
Declare parameters as const whenever possible

category.description: CERT-DCL01_C (REC) Do not reuse variable names in subscopes
category.name: DCL01

rule.header: Identifier declared in a local or function prototype scope shall not hide an identifier declared in a global or namespace scope
Identifiers declared in an inner local scope should not hide identifiers declared in an outer local scope

category.description: CERT-DCL02_C (REC) Use visually distinct identifiers
category.name: DCL02

rule.header: Use visually distinct identifiers

category.description: CERT-DCL04_C (REC) Do not declare more than one variable per declaration
category.name: DCL04

rule.header: Each variable should be declared in a separate declaration statement

category.description: CERT-DCL05_C (REC) Use typedefs of non-pointer types only
category.name: DCL05

rule.header: Declare a type of parameter as typedef to pointer to const if the pointer is not used to modify the addressed object

category.description: CERT-DCL06_C (REC) Use meaningful symbolic constants to represent literal values
category.name: DCL06

rule.header: Use meaningful symbolic constants to represent literal values

category.description: CERT-DCL12_C (REC) Implement abstract data types using opaque types
category.name: DCL12

rule.header: If a pointer to a structure or union is never dereferenced within a translation unit, then the implementation of the object should be hidden

category.description: CERT-DCL13_C (REC) Declare function parameters that are pointers to values not changed by the function as const
category.name: DCL13

rule.header: A pointer parameter in a function prototype should be declared as pointer to const if the pointer is not used to modify the addressed object

category.description: CERT-DCL15_C (REC) Declare file-scope objects or functions that do not need external linkage as static
category.name: DCL15

rule.header: Objects or functions with external linkage shall be declared in a header file

category.description: CERT-DCL16_C (REC) Use "L," not "l," to indicate a long value
category.name: DCL16

rule.header: Use capital 'L' instead of lowercase 'l' to indicate long

category.description: CERT-DCL18_C (REC) Do not begin integer constants with 0 when specifying a decimal value
category.name: DCL18

rule.header: Octal and hexadecimal escape sequences shall be terminated
Octal constants (other than zero) shall not be used

category.description: CERT-DCL19_C (REC) Minimize the scope of variables and functions
category.name: DCL19

rule.header: Declare variables as locally as possible

category.description: CERT-DCL31_C (RULE) Declare identifiers before using them
category.name: DCL31

rule.header: All functions shall be declared before use

category.description: CERT-DCL37_C (RULE) Do not declare or define a reserved identifier
category.name: DCL37

rule.header: Do not #define or #undef identifiers with names which start with underscore

category.description: CERT-DCL38_C (RULE) Use the correct syntax when declaring a flexible array member
category.name: DCL38

rule.header: The final member of a structure should not be an array of size '0' or '1'

category.description: CERT-DCL39_C (RULE) Avoid information leakage when passing a structure across a trust boundary
category.name: DCL39

rule.header: A pointer to a structure should not be passed to a function that can copy data to the user space

category.description: CERT-DCL40_C (RULE) Do not create incompatible declarations of the same function or object
category.name: DCL40

rule.header: If objects or functions are declared more than once their types shall be compatible

category.description: CERT-DCL41_C (RULE) Do not declare variables inside a switch statement before the first case label
category.name: DCL41

rule.header: A switch statement shall only contain switch labels and switch clauses, and no other code

category.description: CERT-ENV02_C (REC) Beware of multiple environment variables with the same effective name
category.name: ENV02

rule.header: Usage of system properties (environment variables) should be restricted

category.description: CERT-ENV30_C (RULE) Do not modify the object referenced by the return value of certain functions
category.name: ENV30

rule.header: The pointers returned by the Standard Library functions 'localeconv', 'getenv', 'setlocale' or, 'strerror' shall only be used as if they have pointer to const-qualified type

category.description: CERT-ERR02_C (REC) Avoid in-band error indicators
category.name: ERR02

rule.header: The Standard Library input/output functions shall not be used

category.description: CERT-ERR04_C (REC) Choose an appropriate termination strategy
category.name: ERR04

rule.header: The 'abort()' function from the 'stdlib.h' or 'cstdlib' library shall not be used
The 'exit()' function from the 'stdlib.h' or 'cstdlib' library shall not be used
The 'quick_exit()' and '_Exit()' functions from the 'stdlib.h' or 'cstdlib' library shall not be used

category.description: CERT-ERR05_C (REC) Application-independent code should provide error detection without dictating error handling
category.name: ERR05

rule.header: The 'abort()' function from the 'stdlib.h' or 'cstdlib' library shall not be used
The 'exit()' function from the 'stdlib.h' or 'cstdlib' library shall not be used
The 'quick_exit()' and '_Exit()' functions from the 'stdlib.h' or 'cstdlib' library shall not be used

category.description: CERT-ERR06_C (REC) Understand the termination behavior of assert() and abort()
category.name: ERR06

rule.header: Do not use assertions

category.description: CERT-ERR34_C (RULE) Detect errors when converting a string to a number
category.name: ERR34

rule.header: The library functions atof, atoi and atol from library stdlib.h shall not be used

category.description: CERT-EXP00_C (REC) Use parentheses for precedence of operation
category.name: EXP00

rule.header: Use parenthesis to clarify expression order if operators with precedence lower than arithmetic are used

category.description: CERT-EXP02_C (REC) Be aware of the short-circuit behavior of the logical AND and OR operators
category.name: EXP02

rule.header: The right-hand operand of a logical && or || operator shall not contain side effects

category.description: CERT-EXP12_C (REC) Do not ignore values returned by functions
category.name: EXP12

rule.header: The value returned by a function having non-void return type shall be used
The value returned by a function having non-void return type shall be used

category.description: CERT-EXP14_C (REC) Beware of integer promotion when performing bitwise operations on integer types smaller than int
category.name: EXP14

rule.header: Avoid mixing arithmetic of different precisions in the same expression

category.description: CERT-EXP15_C (REC) Do not place a semicolon on the same line as an if, for, or while statement
category.name: EXP15

rule.header: Suspicious use of semicolon

category.description: CERT-EXP35_C (RULE) Do not modify objects with temporary lifetime
category.name: EXP35

rule.header: Do not modify objects with temporary lifetime

category.description: CERT-EXP36_C (RULE) Do not cast pointers into more strictly aligned pointer types
category.name: EXP36

rule.header: Do not cast pointers into more strictly aligned pointer types

category.description: CERT-EXP37_C (RULE) Call functions with the correct number and type of arguments
category.name: EXP37

rule.header: Conversions shall not be performed between non compatible pointer to a function types
Specify the access permission bits if a file is created using the 'open' or 'openat' system call
Functions shall always have visible prototype at the function call

category.description: CERT-EXP39_C (RULE) Do not access a variable through a pointer of an incompatible type
category.name: EXP39

rule.header: There shall be no implicit conversions from integral to floating type
A cast should not be performed between a pointer to object type and a different pointer to object type

category.description: CERT-EXP40_C (RULE) Do not modify constant objects
category.name: EXP40

rule.header: A cast shall not remove any 'const' or 'volatile' qualification from the type of a pointer or reference

category.description: CERT-EXP43_C (RULE) Avoid undefined behavior when using restrict-qualified pointers
category.name: EXP43

rule.header: The restrict type qualifier shall not be used

category.description: CERT-EXP44_C (RULE) Do not rely on side effects in operands to sizeof, _Alignof, or _Generic
category.name: EXP44

rule.header: Object designated by a volatile lvalue should not be accessed in the operand of the sizeof operator
The function call that causes the side effect shall not be the operand of the sizeof operator

category.description: CERT-FIO38_C (RULE) Do not copy a FILE object
category.name: FIO38

rule.header: A pointer to a FILE object shall not be dereferenced

category.description: CERT-FIO41_C (RULE) Do not call getc(), putc(), getwc(), or putwc() with a stream argument that has side effects
category.name: FIO41

rule.header: Do not call 'getc()', 'putc()', 'getwc()', or 'putwc()' with a stream argument containing assignments, increment or decrement operators
Do not call 'getc()', 'putc()', 'getwc()', or 'putwc()' with a stream argument containing function calls or function-like macro calls

category.description: CERT-FLP00_C (REC) Understand the limitations of floating-point numbers
category.name: FLP00

rule.header: Floating-point expressions shall not be tested for equality or inequality

category.description: CERT-FLP02_C (REC) Avoid using floating-point numbers when precise computation is needed
category.name: FLP02

rule.header: Floating-point expressions shall not be tested for equality or inequality

category.description: CERT-FLP03_C (REC) Detect and handle floating-point errors
category.name: FLP03

rule.header: Avoid implicit conversions from wider to narrower floating type
Avoid implicit conversions from narrower to wider floating type
Avoid implicit conversions of floating point numbers from wider to narrower floating type

category.description: CERT-FLP34_C (RULE) Ensure that floating-point conversions are within range of the new type
category.name: FLP34

rule.header: Avoid implicit conversions from wider to narrower floating type
Avoid implicit conversions of floating point numbers from wider to narrower floating type

category.description: CERT-FLP36_C (RULE) Preserve precision when converting integral values to floating-point type
category.name: FLP36

rule.header: Implicit conversions from integral to floating type which may result in a loss of information shall not be used
Implicit conversions from integral constant to floating type which may result in a loss of information shall not be used

category.description: CERT-FLP37_C (RULE) Do not use object representations to compare floating-point values
category.name: FLP37

rule.header: Do not use object representations to compare floating-point values

category.description: CERT-INT05_C (REC) Do not use input functions to convert character data if they cannot handle all possible inputs
category.name: INT05

rule.header: Avoid using unsafe string functions that do not check bounds

category.description: CERT-INT09_C (REC) Ensure enumeration constants map to unique values
category.name: INT09

rule.header: In an enumerator list, the "=" construct shall not be used to explicitly initialise members other than the first, unless all items are explicitly initialised

category.description: CERT-INT10_C (REC) Do not assume a positive remainder when using the % operator
category.name: INT10

rule.header: The operands of the remainder operator '%' should be of unsigned integer types

category.description: CERT-INT12_C (REC) Do not make assumptions about the type of a plain int bit-field when used in an expression
category.name: INT12

rule.header: Bit fields shall only be defined to be of type unsigned int or signed int

category.description: CERT-INT16_C (REC) Do not make assumptions about representation of signed integers
category.name: INT16

rule.header: Bitwise operators shall only be applied to operands of unsigned underlying type

category.description: CERT-INT35_C (RULE) Use correct integer precisions
category.name: INT35

rule.header: Use correct integer precisions when checking the right hand operand of the shift operator

category.description: CERT-INT36_C (RULE) Converting a pointer to integer or integer to pointer
category.name: INT36

rule.header: A conversion should not be performed between a pointer to object type and an integer type other than 'uintptr_t' or 'intptr_t'

category.description: CERT-MEM02_C (REC) Immediately cast the result of a memory allocation function call into a pointer to the allocated type
category.name: MEM02

rule.header: The result of the memory allocation function should be cast immediately
The result of the memory allocation function should be cast immediately into a pointer to the allocated type

category.description: CERT-MEM33_C (RULE) Allocate and copy structures containing a flexible array member dynamically
category.name: MEM33

rule.header: Allocate structures containing a flexible array member dynamically
Do not copy instances of structures containing a flexible array member

category.description: CERT-MSC04_C (REC) Use comments consistently and in a readable fashion
category.name: MSC04

rule.header: The character sequence /* shall not be used within a C-style comment
The character sequence // shall not be used within a C-style comment
The character sequence /* shall not be used within a C++-style comment
Line-splicing shall not be used in // comments

category.description: CERT-MSC07_C (REC) Detect and remove dead code
category.name: MSC07

rule.header: There shall be no unreachable code in "else" block
There shall be no unreachable code after 'return', 'break', 'continue', and 'goto' statements
There shall be no unreachable code in "if/else/while/for" block
There shall be no unreachable code in switch statement
There shall be no unreachable code in 'for' loop
There shall be no unreachable code after 'if' or 'switch' statement
There shall be no unreachable code after "if" or "switch" statement inside while/for/do...while loop

category.description: CERT-MSC09_C (REC) Character encoding: Use subset of ASCII for safety
category.name: MSC09

rule.header: Only use characters defined in the ISO C standard

category.description: CERT-MSC11_C (REC) Incorporate diagnostic tests using assertions
category.name: MSC11

rule.header: Assert liberally to document internal assumptions and invariants

category.description: CERT-MSC12_C (REC) Detect and remove code that has no effect or is never executed
category.name: MSC12

rule.header: There shall be no unreachable code in "else" block
There shall be no unreachable code after 'return', 'break', 'continue', and 'goto' statements
There shall be no unreachable code in "if/else/while/for" block
There shall be no unreachable code in switch statement
There shall be no unreachable code in 'for' loop
There shall be no unreachable code after 'if' or 'switch' statement
There shall be no unreachable code after "if" or "switch" statement inside while/for/do...while loop
All non-null statements shall either have at least one side-effect however executed or cause control flow to change

category.description: CERT-MSC13_C (REC) Detect and remove unused values
category.name: MSC13

rule.header: Avoid unnecessary local variables

category.description: CERT-MSC14_C (REC) Do not introduce unnecessary platform dependencies
category.name: MSC14

rule.header: Evaluation of constant unsigned integer expressions should not lead to wrap-around

category.description: CERT-MSC22_C (REC) Use the setjmp(), longjmp() facility securely
category.name: MSC22

rule.header: The facilities provided by <setjmp.h> should not be used

category.description: CERT-MSC24_C (REC) Do not use deprecated or obsolescent functions
category.name: MSC24

rule.header: The library functions atof, atoi and atol from library stdlib.h shall not be used
The 'getenv()' function from the 'stdlib.h' or 'cstdlib' library shall not be used
Avoid using unsafe string functions which may cause buffer overflows
Don't use unsafe C functions that do write to range-unchecked buffers

category.description: CERT-MSC38_C (RULE) Do not treat a predefined identifier as an object if it might only be implemented as a macro
category.name: MSC38

rule.header: A function-like macro shall not be invoked without all of its arguments

category.description: CERT-MSC40_C (RULE) Do not violate constraints
category.name: MSC40

rule.header: An inline definition of a function with external linkage shall not contain definitions and uses of static objects

category.description: CERT-PRE00_C (REC) Prefer inline or static functions to function-like macros
category.name: PRE00

rule.header: A function should be used in preference to a function-like macro

category.description: CERT-PRE06_C (REC) Enclose header files in an include guard
category.name: PRE06

rule.header: Use multiple include guards

category.description: CERT-PRE07_C (REC) Avoid using repeated question marks
category.name: PRE07

rule.header: Trigraphs shall not be used

category.description: CERT-PRE30_C (RULE) Do not create a universal character name through concatenation
category.name: PRE30

rule.header: Avoid token concatenation that may produce universal character names

category.description: CERT-PRE31_C (RULE) Avoid side effects in arguments to unsafe macros
category.name: PRE31

rule.header: Assertions should not contain assignments, increment, or decrement operators
Assertions should not contain function calls nor function-like macro calls
Avoid side effects in arguments to unsafe macros

category.description: CERT-PRE32_C (RULE) Do not use preprocessor directives in invocations of function-like macros
category.name: PRE32

rule.header: Arguments to a function-like macro shall not contain tokens that look like preprocessing directives

category.description: CERT-SIG01_C (REC) Understand implementation-specific details regarding signal handler persistence
category.name: SIG01

rule.header: The signal handling facilities of <signal.h> shall not be used

category.description: CERT-STR04_C (REC) Use plain char for characters in the basic character set
category.name: STR04

rule.header: The plain char type shall be used only for the storage and use of character values

category.description: CERT-STR05_C (REC) Use pointers to const when referring to string literals
category.name: STR05

rule.header: A string literal shall not be modified

category.description: CERT-STR09_C (REC) Don't assume numeric values for expressions with type plain character
category.name: STR09

rule.header: Expressions with type (plain) char and wchar_t shall not be used as operands to built-in operators other than =, ==, != and the unary & operator

category.description: CERT-STR10_C (REC) Do not concatenate different type of string literals
category.name: STR10

rule.header: Narrow and wide string literals shall not be concatenated

category.description: SEI CERT C++
category.name: CERT_CPP

category.description: CERT-CTR55_CPP (RULE) Do not use an additive operator on an iterator if the result would overflow
category.name: CTR55

rule.header: Do not add or subtract a constant with a value greater than one from an iterator

category.description: CERT-DCL50_CPP (RULE) Do not define a C-style variadic function
category.name: DCL50

rule.header: Functions shall not be defined with a variable number of arguments

category.description: CERT-ERR54_CPP (RULE) Catch handlers should order their parameter types from most derived to least derived
category.name: ERR54

rule.header: Where multiple handlers are provided in a single try-catch statement or function-try-block for a derived class and some or all of its bases, the handlers shall be ordered most-derived to base class

category.description: CERT-ERR59_CPP (RULE) Do not throw an exception across execution boundaries
category.name: ERR59

rule.header: Do not throw an exception across execution boundaries

category.description: CERT-EXP60_CPP (RULE) Do not pass a nonstandard-layout type object across execution boundaries
category.name: EXP60

rule.header: Do not pass a nonstandard-layout type object across execution boundaries

category.description: CERT-MEM51_CPP (RULE) Properly deallocate dynamically allocated resources
category.name: MEM51

rule.header: Use the same form in corresponding calls to new/malloc and delete/free
Always provide empty brackets ([]) for delete when deallocating arrays
Both copy constructor and copy assignment operator should be declared for classes with a nontrivial destructor

category.description: CERT-MEM52_CPP (RULE) Detect and handle memory allocation errors
category.name: MEM52

rule.header: Check the return value of new
Do not allocate resources in function argument list because the order of evaluation of a function's parameters is undefined

category.description: CERT-MEM53_CPP (RULE) Explicitly construct and destruct objects when manually managing object lifetime
category.name: MEM53

rule.header: Do not invoke malloc/realloc for objects having constructors

category.description: CERT-MEM54_CPP (RULE) Provide placement new with properly aligned pointers to sufficient storage capacity
category.name: MEM54

rule.header: Do not pass a pointer that has insufficient storage capacity or that is not suitably aligned for the object being constructed to placement 'new'
An overhead should be used when an array of objects is passed to the placement 'new' allocation function

category.description: CERT-MEM55_CPP (RULE) Honor replacement dynamic storage management requirements
category.name: MEM55

rule.header: The user defined 'new' operator should throw the 'std::bad_alloc' exception when the allocation fails

category.description: CERT-STR50_CPP (RULE) Guarantee that storage for strings has sufficient space for character data and the null terminator
category.name: STR50

rule.header: Do not use the 'char' buffer to store input from 'std::cin'

category.description: CERT-CON51_CPP (RULE) Ensure actively held locks are released on exceptional conditions
category.name: CON51

rule.header: Do not call lock() directly on a mutex

category.description: CERT-CTR53_CPP (RULE) Use valid iterator ranges
category.name: CTR53

rule.header: Do not use an iterator range that isn't really a range

category.description: CERT-CTR56_CPP (RULE) Do not use pointer arithmetic on polymorphic objects
category.name: CTR56

rule.header: Don't treat arrays polymorphically
A pointer to an array of derived class objects should not be converted to a base class pointer

category.description: CERT-DCL54_CPP (RULE) Overload allocation and deallocation functions as a pair in the same scope
category.name: DCL54

rule.header: Always provide new and delete together

category.description: CERT-DCL57_CPP (RULE) Do not let exceptions escape from destructors or deallocation functions
category.name: DCL57

rule.header: Never allow an exception to be thrown from a destructor, deallocation, and swap

category.description: CERT-DCL58_CPP (RULE) Do not modify the standard namespaces
category.name: DCL58

rule.header: Do not modify the standard namespaces 'std' and 'posix'

category.description: CERT-ERR55_CPP (RULE) Honor exception specifications
category.name: ERR55

rule.header: Where a function's declaration includes an exception-specification, the function shall only be capable of throwing exceptions of the indicated type(s)

category.description: CERT-ERR56_CPP (RULE) Guarantee exception safety
category.name: ERR56

rule.header: Do not leave 'catch' blocks empty

category.description: CERT-ERR58_CPP (RULE) Handle all exceptions thrown before main() begins executing
category.name: ERR58

rule.header: Exceptions shall be raised only after start-up and before termination of the program

category.description: CERT-EXP50_CPP (RULE) Do not depend on the order of evaluation for side effects
category.name: EXP50

rule.header: The value of an expression shall be the same under any order of evaluation that the standard permits
Don't write code that depends on the order of evaluation of function arguments
Don't write code that depends on the order of evaluation of function designator and function arguments
Don't write code that depends on the order of evaluation of expression that involves a function call
Between sequence points an object shall have its stored value modified at most once by the evaluation of an expression
Don't write code that depends on the order of evaluation of function calls

category.description: CERT-EXP54_CPP (RULE) Do not access an object outside of its lifetime
category.name: EXP54

rule.header: The address of an object with automatic storage shall not be returned from a function
The address of an object with automatic storage shall not be assigned to another object that may persist after the first object has ceased to exist

category.description: CERT-EXP55_CPP (RULE) Do not access a cv-qualified object through a cv-unqualified type
category.name: EXP55

rule.header: A cast shall not remove any 'const' or 'volatile' qualification from the type of a pointer or reference

category.description: CERT-EXP61_CPP (RULE) A lambda object must not outlive any of its reference captured objects
category.name: EXP61

rule.header: Never return lambdas that capture local objects by reference
Never capture local objects from an outer lambda by reference
The lambda that captures local objects by reference should not be assigned to the variable with a greater lifetime

category.description: CERT-EXP62_CPP (RULE) Do not access the bits of an object representation that are not part of the object's value representation
category.name: EXP62

rule.header: Do not compare objects of a class that may contain padding bits with C standard library functions

category.description: CERT-MEM57_CPP (RULE) Avoid using default operator new for over-aligned types
category.name: MEM57

rule.header: Avoid using the default operator 'new' for over-aligned types

category.description: CERT-MSC50_CPP (RULE) Do not use std::rand() for generating pseudorandom numbers
category.name: MSC50

rule.header: Do not use the rand() function for generating pseudorandom numbers

category.description: CERT-MSC52_CPP (RULE) Value-returning functions must return a value from all exit paths
category.name: MSC52

rule.header: All exit paths from a function, except main(), with non-void return type shall have an explicit return statement with an expression

category.description: CERT-OOP52_CPP (RULE) Do not delete a polymorphic object without a virtual destructor
category.name: OOP52

rule.header: Define a virtual destructor in classes used as base classes which have virtual functions

category.description: CERT-OOP55_CPP (RULE) Do not use pointer-to-member operators to access nonexistent members
category.name: OOP55

rule.header: A cast shall not convert a pointer to a function to any other pointer type, including a pointer to function type

category.description: CERT-OOP57_CPP (RULE) Prefer special member functions and overloaded operators to C Standard Library functions
category.name: OOP57

rule.header: Do not initialize objects with a non-trivial class type using C standard library functions
Do not compare objects of nonstandard-layout class type with C standard library functions

category.description: CERT-OOP58_CPP (RULE) Copy operations must not mutate the source object
category.name: OOP58

rule.header: Copy operations must not mutate the source object

category.description: CERT-CON54_CPP (RULE) Wrap functions that can spuriously wake up in a loop
category.name: CON54

rule.header: Wrap functions that can spuriously wake up in a loop

category.description: CERT-CON55_CPP (RULE) Preserve thread safety and liveness when using condition variables
category.name: CON55

rule.header: Do not use the 'notify_one()' function when multiple threads are waiting on the same condition variable

category.description: CERT-CTR57_CPP (RULE) Provide a valid ordering predicate
category.name: CTR57

rule.header: For associative containers never use comparison function returning true for equal values

category.description: CERT-CTR58_CPP (RULE) Predicate function objects should not be mutable
category.name: CTR58

rule.header: Make predicates const pure functions

category.description: CERT-DCL51_CPP (RULE) Do not declare or define a reserved identifier
category.name: DCL51

rule.header: Do not #define or #undef identifiers with names which start with underscore
Do not redefine reserved words
Do not #define nor #undef identifier 'defined'
The names of standard library macros, objects and functions shall not be reused
The names of standard library macros, objects and functions shall not be reused (C90)
The names of standard library macros, objects and functions shall not be reused (C99)

category.description: CERT-DCL52_CPP (RULE) Never qualify a reference type with const or volatile
category.name: DCL52

rule.header: Never qualify a reference type with 'const' or 'volatile'

category.description: CERT-DCL53_CPP (RULE) Do not write syntactically ambiguous declarations
category.name: DCL53

rule.header: Parameter names in function declarations should not be enclosed in parentheses
Local variable names in variable declarations should not be enclosed in parentheses
Avoid function declarations that are syntactically ambiguous

category.description: CERT-DCL55_CPP (RULE) Avoid information leakage when passing a class object across a trust boundary
category.name: DCL55

rule.header: A pointer to a structure should not be passed to a function that can copy data to the user space

category.description: CERT-DCL56_CPP (RULE) Avoid cycles during initialization of static objects
category.name: DCL56

rule.header: Avoid initialization order problems across translation units by replacing non-local static objects with local static objects

category.description: CERT-DCL59_CPP (RULE) Do not define an unnamed namespace in a header file
category.name: DCL59

rule.header: There shall be no unnamed namespaces in header files

category.description: CERT-ERR50_CPP (RULE) Do not abruptly terminate the program
category.name: ERR50

rule.header: The execution of a function registered with 'std::atexit()' or 'std::at_quick_exit()' should not exit via an exception
Never allow an exception to be thrown from a destructor, deallocation, and swap
Do not throw from within destructor
There should be at least one exception handler to catch all otherwise unhandled exceptions
An empty throw (throw;) shall only be used in the compound-statement of a catch handler
Exceptions shall be raised only after start-up and before termination of the program
Each exception explicitly thrown in the code shall have a handler of a compatible type in all call paths that could lead to that point
Where a function's declaration includes an exception-specification, the function shall only be capable of throwing exceptions of the indicated type(s)
Function called in global or namespace scope shall not throw unhandled exceptions
The 'abort()' function from the 'stdlib.h' or 'cstdlib' library shall not be used
The 'quick_exit()' and '_Exit()' functions from the 'stdlib.h' or 'cstdlib' library shall not be used

category.description: CERT-ERR51_CPP (RULE) Handle all exceptions
category.name: ERR51

rule.header: Each exception explicitly thrown in the code shall have a handler of a compatible type in all call paths that could lead to that point

category.description: CERT-ERR52_CPP (RULE) Do not use setjmp() or longjmp()
category.name: ERR52

rule.header: The facilities provided by <setjmp.h> should not be used
The standard header files <setjmp.h> or <csetjmp> shall not be used

category.description: CERT-ERR53_CPP (RULE) Do not reference base classes or class data members in a constructor or destructor function-try-block handler
category.name: ERR53

rule.header: Handlers of a function-try-block implementation of a class constructor or destructor shall not reference nonstatic members from this class or its bases

category.description: CERT-ERR60_CPP (RULE) Exception objects must be nothrow copy constructible
category.name: ERR60

rule.header: Exception objects must be nothrow copy constructible
An explicitly declared copy constructor for a class that inherits from 'std::exception' should have a non-throwing exception specification

category.description: CERT-ERR61_CPP (RULE) Catch exceptions by lvalue reference
category.name: ERR61

rule.header: A class type exception shall always be caught by reference
Throw by value, catch by reference

category.description: CERT-ERR62_CPP (RULE) Detect errors when converting a string to a number
category.name: ERR62

rule.header: The library functions atof, atoi and atol from library stdlib.h shall not be used

category.description: CERT-EXP52_CPP (RULE) Do not rely on side effects in unevaluated operands
category.name: EXP52

rule.header: The operand of the sizeof operator shall not contain any expression which has side effects
Object designated by a volatile lvalue should not be accessed in the operand of the sizeof operator
The function call that causes the side effect shall not be the operand of the sizeof operator
The operand of the 'typeid' operator shall not contain any expression that has side effects
The operand of the 'typeid' operator shall not contain a function call that causes side effects

category.description: CERT-EXP56_CPP (RULE) Do not call a function with a mismatched language linkage
category.name: EXP56

rule.header: Do not call a function with a mismatched language linkage

category.description: CERT-EXP57_CPP (RULE) Do not cast or delete pointers to incomplete classes
category.name: EXP57

rule.header: Do not delete objects with incomplete class at the point of deletion
Conversions shall not be performed between a pointer to an incomplete type and any other type

category.description: CERT-EXP59_CPP (RULE) Use offsetof() on valid types and members
category.name: EXP59

rule.header: Use offsetof() on valid types and members

category.description: CERT-INT50_CPP (RULE) Do not cast to an out-of-range enumeration value
category.name: INT50

rule.header: An expression with enum underlying type shall only have values corresponding to the enumerators of the enumeration

category.description: CERT-OOP50_CPP (RULE) Do not invoke virtual functions from constructors or destructors
category.name: OOP50

rule.header: Avoid calling virtual functions from constructors
Avoid calling virtual functions from destructors

category.description: CERT-OOP51_CPP (RULE) Do not slice derived objects
category.name: OOP51

rule.header: Avoid slicing function arguments / return value

category.description: CERT-OOP53_CPP (RULE) Write constructor member initializers in the canonical order
category.name: OOP53

rule.header: List members in an initialization list in the order in which they are declared

category.description: CERT-OOP54_CPP (RULE) Gracefully handle self-copy assignment
category.name: OOP54

rule.header: Check for assignment to self in operator=

category.description: Coding Conventions
category.name: CODSTA

rule.header: Local variable or parameter names and class member variable or parent class/struct member variable names shall differ by more than a single character
Avoid internal or external name conflict with a C++ reserved word
Local variables should not use the same names as member variables
Parameters should not use the same names as member variables

category.description: Coding Conventions for C++
category.name: CPP

rule.header: Constructors allowing for conversion should be made explicit
Do not use user-defined conversion functions
The first operand of a conditional-operator shall have type bool
Declare at least one constructor to prevent the compiler from doing so
Arrays shall not be used in interfaces
Private and protected methods shall not declare parameters with array type
Copy operations must not mutate the source object
Have assignment operator returns a reference to *this; make assignment operator's return type a non-const reference to it's class' type
Bitwise operators, comparison operators, logical operators, comma operator should be const
Avoid returning handles to class data from member functions
Postfix increment and decrement should be implemented in terms of their prefix counterparts
Avoid overloading logical operators AND, OR (&&, ||)
Avoid using reinterpret_cast
Do not define structs that contain member functions
Do not compare objects of a class that may contain padding bits with C standard library functions
A relational operator shall return a boolean value
A binary arithmetic operator and a bitwise operator shall return a 'prvalue'
Output parameters shall not be used
The operand of the 'typeid' operator shall not contain any expression that has side effects
The operand of the 'typeid' operator shall not contain a function call that causes side effects
Define special members as =default when the behavior is equivalent to the compiler's behavior
Use delegating constructors to reduce code duplication
Comparison operators shall be non-member functions
Comparison operators shall be non-member functions with identical parameter types and noexcept
A parameter of const reference to a 'cheap to copy' type should be passed by value
Pass small objects with a trivial copy constructor by value
A parameter of a type that is not 'cheap to copy' should be passed by reference
C-style casts should not be used
Put classes that are used as base classes and classes that are used as member variables into separate include files
Put classes that are used as function return type into separate include files
Put classes that are used as argument types in function prototypes into separate include files
Put functions that are used in the body of inline member function into separate include file
When two operators are opposites (such as == and !=), it is appropriate to define both
Do not use the 'struct' keyword to declare a variable in C++
If you'd like to support mixed-mode operations make operators a non-member functions
Avoid making any assignment operator virtual. Do not return const T& from assignment operator
Consider making virtual functions nonpublic, and public functions nonvirtual
Keep types and functions in separate namespaces unless they're specifically intended to work together
Keep a type and its nonmember function interface in the same namespace
When binary arithmetic operators are defined ( + , - , * , / , ^ , % , | , & ), assignment versions should be provided too
Prefer the canonical forms of arithmetic and assignment operators
Prefer non-member operators than member ones to support mixed-mode arithmetic
A function definition should not be placed in a class specification unless the function is intended to be inlined
Member functions shall not be defined within the template class definition
Avoid using static_cast on pointers
Avoid dynamic_casts
The global namespace shall only contain main() and namespace declarations
Do not define class/struct/union inside function implementation
Conversion operator, operator->, operator(), operator[] should be const
Don't write namespace usings in a header file or before an #include
Do not use the 'enum' keyword to declare a variable in C++
Do not declare member variables with the 'mutable' keyword
Declare reference parameters as const references whenever possible
Have the non-const version call the const version of member function instead of duplicating the const version definition
In the private section of a class items shall be declared in the following order: Constructors, Destructor, Member Functions, Member Operator Function, Enumerations and others
Order of scopes in class: public before all others
Order of scopes in classes: protected before private
In the protected section of a class items shall be declared in the following order: Constructors, Destructor, Member Functions, Member Operator Function, Enumerations and others
In the public section of a class items shall be declared in the following order: Constructors, Destructor, Member Functions, Member Operator Function, Enumerations and others
Do not use static keyword except inside functions and classes
Do not define inline functions in source files
Consider using the natural relationship between the assignment version of an operator and the stand-alone version
Declare local variable as const whenever possible
Declare parameters as const whenever possible
Member functions shall be declared const whenever possible
A class, structure, or enumeration will not be declared in the definition of its type
Namespaces will not be nested more than two levels deep
The value returned by a function having a non-void return type that is not an overloaded operator shall always be used
The C library shall not be used
Only those escape sequences that are defined in ISO/IEC 14882:2003 shall be used
Only those escape sequences that are defined in ISO/IEC 14882:2014 shall be used
NULL shall not be used as an integer value
Literal zero (0) shall not be used as the null-pointer-constant
The condition of an if-statement and the condition of an iteration-statement shall have type bool
C-style casts (other than void casts) and functional notation casts (other than explicit constructor calls) shall not be used
Each operand of the ! operator, the logical && or the logical || operators shall have type bool
The unary & operator shall not be overloaded
A for loop shall contain a single loop-counter which shall not have floating type
If loop-counter is not modified by -- or ++, then, within condition, the loop-counter shall only be used as an operand to <=, <, > or >=
The loop-counter shall be modified by one of: --, ++, -=n, or +=n; where n remains constant for the duration of the loop
A loop-control-variable other than the loop-counter shall not be modified within condition or expression
A loop-control-variable other than the loop-counter which is modified in statement shall have type bool
There shall be no unnamed namespaces in header files
using-directives shall not be used
Multiple declarations for an identifier in the same namespace shall not straddle a using-declaration for that identifier
Const member functions shall not return non-const pointers or references to class-data
If a member function can be made static then it shall be made static, otherwise if it can be made const then it shall be made const
Neither operand of an equality operator (== or !=) shall be a pointer to a virtual member function
Avoid overloading comma operator ","
Avoid unencapsulated global variables (including variables declared in namespaces and public static members)
Identifiers declared in a local scope should not hide identifiers declared in a class scope
Identifiers declared in a class scope should not hide identifiers declared in a global or namespace scope
Identifiers declared in an inner class scope should not hide identifiers declared in outer class scope
If two opposite equality operators ('==', '!=') are defined in a class, one shall be defined in terms of the other
If an identifier refers to a type, it shall not also refer to an object or a function in the same scope
If an identifier refers to a type, it shall not also refer to an object or a function in the same scope
If an identifier refers to a type, it shall not also refer to an object or a function in the same scope
The name of typedef should not be the same as the name of its basic type
using-directives and using-declarations (excluding class scope or function scope using-declarations) shall not be used in header files
The overloaded binary operator should be implemented in terms of its corresponding compound assignment operator
All accessible entity names within a multiple inheritance hierarchy should be unique
Do not initialize objects with a non-trivial class type using C standard library functions
Do not compare objects of nonstandard-layout class type with C standard library functions
Do not modify the standard namespaces 'std' and 'posix'
Do not call a function with a mismatched language linkage
Never qualify a reference type with 'const' or 'volatile'
Use offsetof() on valid types and members
Prefer non-member non-friend functions to member functions
Classes which have only getters/setters (accessors/mutators) are not allowed
Do not assign enumerations to bool
Prefer iostream.h to stdio.h
Encapsulate global variables and constants, enumerated types, and typedefs in a class
Assignment operator must return const reference
Whenever a global function is referenced, use the :: operator
Do not use the keyword 'explicit' for a constructor
Limiting the number of objects of a class
Do not use break in for loops
All arguments to any type-generic macros declared in <tgmath.h> shall have appropriate essential type
All arguments to any multi-argument type-generic macros declared in <tgmath.h> shall have the same standard type
Pointers to variably-modified array types should not be used
Global functions shall not declare parameters with array type
Do not declare the size of an array when the array is passed into a function as a parameter
Do not declare the size of an array when the array is initialized
The declaration of an array parameter shall not contain the 'static' keyword between the [ ]
A pointer to a FILE object shall not be dereferenced
A pointer to a FILE object shall not be dereferenced by a library function
The 'sizeof' operator shall not have an operand which is a function parameter declared as "array of type"
The pointers returned by the Standard Library functions 'localeconv', 'getenv', 'setlocale' or, 'strerror' shall only be used as if they have pointer to const-qualified type
Do not specify the bound of a character array initialized with a string literal
EOS should be used to terminate a string rather than NULL
An inline definition of a function with external linkage shall not contain definitions and uses of static objects
Literal suffixes shall use uppercase rather than lowercase letters
Enumeration types shall be used instead of integer types (and constants) as case labels

category.description: Coding Conventions for Modern C++
category.name: MCPP

rule.header: Prefer lambdas over std::bind, std::bind1st and std::bind2nd
Prefer 'auto' to explicit type names in variable declarations
Prefer 'auto' to explicit type names for function return types
All std::hash specializations for user-defined types shall have a noexcept function call operator

If a class declares a copy or move operation, or a destructor, either via '=default', '=delete', or via a user-provided declaration, then all others of these five special member functions shall be declared as well
User-conversion cast operators should be made explicit
Prefer alias declarations to typedefs
Prefer Scoped Enums to Unscoped Enums
Each overriding virtual function shall be declared with the override or final specifier
Declare copy constructor and copy assignment operators with the 'delete' specifier to prevent copying of class
Declare copy constructor and copy assignment operators with the 'delete' specifier instead of using a base class with private methods to prevent copying of class
The 'binder1st' and 'binder2nd' identifiers should not be used
Declare functions 'noexcept' if they will not emit exceptions
Prefer const iterators to iterators
Prefer to use cbegin(), crbegin, cend(), crend() functions
Use std::move() on rvalue references and std::forward() on forwarding references
The 'std::forward' function shall be used to forward universal references
Avoid Overloading on Forwarding References
Avoid default capture modes
Use the 'this' pointer explicitly in lambdas with a default by-reference capture
Prefer 'std::make_shared' to the direct use of new
Prefer to use std::unique_ptr instead of std::auto_ptr
'std::make_unique' shall be used to construct objects owned by 'std::unique_ptr'
Never return lambdas that capture local objects by reference
Never capture local objects from an outer lambda by reference
The lambda that captures local objects by reference should not be assigned to the variable with a greater lifetime
Avoid unnecessary default capture modes in lambda expressions
Avoid unnecessary lambda captures
Declare assignment operators with the ref-qualifier &
Use explicit ref-qualifiers on auto declarations in range-based 'for' loops
If a public destructor of a class is non-virtual, then the class should be declared final
Only one of virtual, override or final should be specified in a member function declaration
Digit sequences separators ' shall only be used consistently
A pointer to member virtual function shall only be tested for equality with null-pointer-constant
A lambda shall not be an operand to typeid
Use smart pointers when passing a pointer to an object in a thread
Consider using 'std::unique_ptr' instead of 'std::shared_ptr' for local objects
Define both sized and unsized versions of operator delete
Static and thread-local objects shall be constant-initialized
User defined literals operators shall only perform conversion of passed parameters
A smart pointer shall only be used as a parameter type if it expresses lifetime semantics
A parameter should only be declared as a non-const lvalue reference to 'std::shared_ptr' or 'std::unique_ptr' if the function replaces the managed object
Do not declare the type of a parameter as an rvalue reference to 'std::shared_ptr' or 'std::unique_ptr'
Derived classes that do not need further explicit initialization and require all the constructors from the base class shall use inheriting constructors
Braced-initialization {}, without equals sign, shall be used for variable initialization
A variable of type auto shall not be initialized using '{}' or '={}' braced-initialization
Do not overuse 'auto' specifier
The 'random_shuffle' identifier should not be used
Do not use the increment operator (++) on an operand of type 'bool'
The 'set_unexpected' identifier should not be used
Lambda expressions should not be defined inside another lambda expression
Return type of a non-void return type lambda expression should be explicitly specified
Include a parameter list in every lambda expression
Avoid overloading constructors with std::initializer_list
Multiple output values from a function should be returned as a struct or tuple
User-defined copy and move assignment operators should use user-defined no-throw swap function
