A for-loop that loops through all elements of the container and does not use its loop-counter shall not be used
Use const container calls when the result is immediately converted to a const iterator
Do not introduce virtual functions in a final class
Do not use std::move on objects declared with the const or const & type
Do not create an rvalue reference of std::array
Use std::call_once rather than the Double-Checked Locking pattern
Prefer 'nullptr' over 'NULL' or '0'(zero)
Use constexpr to declare const variables whenever possible
Use constexpr to declare functions whenever possible
Prefer smart pointer members over raw pointer members
Prefer smart pointers over raw pointers for arrays or STL containers
Prefer smart pointers over raw local pointers
Do not call lock() directly on a mutex
Array elements shall be accessed by the array operator [ ]
A member of a union shall not be declared as a bit-field
Do not define constants via #define
Pointers to pointers should be avoided whenever possible
Avoid using the '?:' operator
If a function has no parameters, use ( ) instead of ( void )
Do not cast pointers to functions to pointers to primitive types
Storage type modifiers shall be associated with the type, not the variable or the function
Signed and unsigned values shall not be mixed in arithmetic operations
Signed and unsigned values shall not be mixed in second and third operand of conditional operator
A single operation with side-effect shall only be used in the proper context
A call of function with side-effect shall only be used in the proper context
The operands of a logical && or || shall be parenthesized if the operands contain binary operators
The library functions bsearch and qsort of <stdlib.h> shall not be used
The standard header file <tgmath.h> shall not be used
The facilities that are specified as being provided by <tgmath.h> should not be used
The features provided by <fenv.h> should not be used
The standard header file <fenv.h> shall not be used
The Standard Library input/output functions shall not be used
The union keyword should not be used
Variable-length arrays should not be used
Flexible array members shall not be declared
Assembly language shall be encapsulated and isolated in C/C++ functions
A 'default' label, if it exists, shall appear as either the first or the last switch label of a switch statement
Octal and hexadecimal escape sequences shall be terminated
A declaration shall be visible when an object or function with external linkage is defined
A 'default' label shall have a statement or a comment before terminating 'break'
Avoid using shift operations instead of arithmetic operations
An inline function shall be declared with the static storage class
The restrict type qualifier shall not be used
The value returned by a function having non-void return type shall be used
The value returned by a function having non-void return type shall be used
Conversions shall not be performed between a pointer to a function and any other type than pointer to function
Conversions shall not be performed between non compatible pointer to a function types
Conversions shall not be performed between a pointer to an incomplete type and any other type
A cast shall not be performed between a pointer to object type and a pointer to a different object type
A cast shall not be performed between pointer to void and an arithmetic type
An implicit conversion shall not be performed between pointer to void and an arithmetic type
>, >=, <, <= shall not be applied to pointer types except where they point to the same array
A cast shall not be performed between pointer to object and a non-integer arithmetic type
Use NULL instead of literal zero (0) as the null-pointer-constant
A macro shall not be defined with the same name as a keyword in C90
A macro shall not be defined with the same name as a keyword in C99
Type casting from any type to or from pointers shall not be used
The identifiers va_list, va_arg, va_start, va_end, va_copy should not be used
The identifiers va_list, va_arg, va_start, va_end should not be used
The standard header file <stdarg.h> or <cstdarg> shall not be used
The function call shall not be the operand of the sizeof operator
The result of a built-in assignment operator should not be used
Pointer subtraction shall only be applied to pointers that address elements of the same array
Never convert consts to non-consts
Initializer lists shall not contain persistent side effects
Functions which are called with array argument shall not be declared with pointer parameter
Suspicious use of 'strcpy' without checking size of source buffer
The values returned by functions 'read' and 'readlink' shall be used
Use of possibly not null-terminated string with functions expecting null-terminated string
A value returned from a stdio character-oriented I/O function should not be implicitly converted to a type smaller than 'int'
Pointer should not be compared with NULL using relational operators <, >, >=, <=
Do not use string literals as operands of equality or relational operators
Missing break statement between cases in a switch statement
Assertions should not contain assignments, increment, or decrement operators
Avoid side effects in arguments to unsafe macros
The value of a composite expression shall not be cast to a different essential type category or a wider essential type
An external object or function shall not have more than one non-defining declaration in translation unit
Use typedefs from stdint.h instead of declaring your own in C99 code
If a composite expression is used as one operand of an operator in which the usual arithmetic conversions are performed then the other operand shall not have wider essential type
If a composite expression is used as one (second or third) operand of a conditional operator then the other operand shall not have wider essential type
The value of a composite expression shall not be assigned to an object with wider essential type
Function types shall have named parameters
Function types shall be in prototype form
An expression of essentially Boolean type should always be used where an operand is interpreted as a Boolean value
An operand of essentially Boolean type should not be used where an operand is interpreted as a numeric value
An operand of essentially character type should not be used where an operand is interpreted as a numeric value
An operand of essentially enum type should not be used in an arithmetic operation
Shift and bitwise operations should not be performed on operands of essentially signed or enum type
An operand of essentially signed or enum type should not be used as the right hand operand to the bitwise shifting operator
An operand of essentially unsigned type should not be used as the operand to the unary minus operator
Expressions of essentially character type shall not be used inappropriately in addition and subtraction operations
The value of an expression shall not be assigned to an object with a narrower essential type
The value of an expression shall not be assigned to an object of a different essential type category
Both operands of an operator in which the usual arithmetic conversions are performed shall have the same essential type category
The second and third operands of the ternary operator shall have the same essential type category
Do not cast from or to essentially Boolean type
A loop counter in a 'for' loop shall not have essentially floating type
A loop counter in 'while' and 'do-while' loops shall not have essentially floating type
There shall only be one loop counter in a 'for' loop, which shall not be modified in the 'for' loop body
The first clause of a 'for' loop shall be well-formed
The second clause of a 'for' loop shall be well-formed
The third clause of a 'for' statement shall be well-formed
Do not use NULL identifier; use 0 instead
The names of macros that exist prior to preprocessing should be distinct from the identifiers that exist after preprocessing (c90)
The names of macros that exist prior to preprocessing should be distinct from the identifiers that exist after preprocessing (c99)
The name of a macro should be distinct from the names of its parameters(c90)
The name of a macro should be distinct from the names of its parameters(c99)
The name of a macro should be distinct from the names of other macros that are currently defined(c90)
The name of a macro should be distinct from the names of other macros that are currently defined(c99)
A program should not exceed the translation limits imposed by The Standard (c90)
A program should not exceed the translation limits imposed by The Standard (c99)
A program should not exceed the translation limits imposed by The Standard (c90)
A program should not exceed the translation limits imposed by The Standard (c99)
External identifiers shall be distinct
Identifiers declared in the file scope and in the same name space shall be distinct (c90)
Identifiers declared in the file scope and in the same name space shall be distinct (c99)
Identifiers declared in the same block scope and name space shall be distinct (c90)
Identifiers declared in the same block scope and name space shall be distinct (c99)
The pointer arguments to the Standard Library functions 'memcmp', 'memmove' and 'memcmp' shall be pointers to qualified or unqualified versions of compatible types

The pointer arguments to the Standard Library function 'memcmp' shall point to either a pointer type, an essentially signed type, an essentially unsigned type, an essentially Boolean type or an essentially enum type
Strings pointed by members of the structure 'lconv' should not be modified
Where designated initializers are used to initialize an array object the size of the array shall be specified explicitly
Cast characters to unsigned char before assignment to larger integer sizes
An expressions of the 'signed char' type should not be used as an array index
Cast characters to unsigned char before converting to larger integer sizes
Do not confuse narrow and wide character strings and functions
Do not add or subtract a scaled integer to a pointer
Use the ctype.h facilities for character test
Do not use object representations to compare floating-point values
Wrap functions that can spuriously wake up in a loop
The final member of a structure should not be an array of size '0' or '1'
Allocate structures containing a flexible array member dynamically
Wrap functions that can fail spuriously in a loop
Do not refer to an atomic variable twice in an expression
Do not modify objects with temporary lifetime
The value of a complex expression of floating type should not be cast to a wider floating type
The value of a complex expression of floating type should not be cast to an integer type
Do not use assertions
Explicitly specify array bounds in array declarations with initializers
Do not process structured text data natively
Functions declared as 'noreturn' shall have the 'void' return type
Do not cast an array to the pointer to a structure of a larger size than the size of the array
The '_Noreturn' function specifier should not be used
The <stdnoreturn.h> header file should not be used
The <stdalign.h> header file shall not be used
The facilities that are specified as being provided by <stdatomic.h> should not be used
Do not use the macro ATOMIC_VAR_INIT
The '_Thread_local' storage class specifier should not be used
The facilities that are specified as being provided by <threads.h> should not be used
The 'rsize_t' type should not be used
The '_Alignas' alignment specifier and the '_Alignof' operator should not be used
The '_Atomic' type specifier and the '_Atomic' type qualifier should not be used
The '__STDC_WANT_LIB_EXT1__' macro should not be defined to the value other than '0'
The '_Generic' operator should not be used
The 'errno_t' type should not be used
Do not use following macros: RSIZE_MAX, L_tmpnam_s, TMP_MAX_S
Do not use the functions defined in Annex K of ISO/IEC 9899:2011 standard
Arguments of integer-constant macros should be decimal, octal, or hexadecimal constants with appropriate values
The small integer variants of the minimum-width integer constant macros should not be used
Do not include any type qualifiers in the specification of a function type
Avoid implicit integral conversions from a wider to a narrower type
Fixed width integer types from <cstdint>, indicating the size and signedness, shall be used in place of the basic numerical types
A typedef should be used in place of the plain char type
The conditional operator should not be used as a sub-expression
Floating-point expressions shall not be explicitly (syntactically) tested for equality (==) or inequality (!=)
The value returned by a standard library function that may return an error should be used
The value returned by a POSIX library function that may return an error should be used
Do not call 'getc()', 'putc()', 'getwc()', or 'putwc()' with a stream argument containing assignments, increment or decrement operators
All 'if' statements should have an 'else' clause
Do not cast pointers into more strictly aligned pointer types
The address of an object with thread storage duration shall not be assigned to an object with static storage duration
The increment (++) and decrement (--) operators should not be mixed with arithmetic operators in an expression
Avoid magic numbers
Avoid functions that modify global variables
Use meaningful symbolic constants to represent literal values
Avoid returning handles to function parameters
Avoid explicit type conversions (casts)
Do not write logical expressions of the type if(test) or if(!test) when test is a pointer
Do not use operator ++ or -- in the conditional expression of if, while, or switch
Use a typedef to simplify program syntax when declaring function pointers
Always provide a default branch for switch statements
Pass built-in-types by value unless you are modifying them
Prefer const objects or enums to #defines for simple constants
Do not use a #define that prevents the compiler from checking types
'void' should be used when a function is passed or returns no values
All structures should be typedef'd
Do not use the following digraphs: <%, %>, <:, :>, %:, %:%:
Null initialize or increment expressions in for loops will not be used; a while loop will be used instead
Hexadecimal constants will be represented using all uppercase letters
The initialization expression in a for loop will perform no actions other than to initialize the value of a single for loop parameter
The increment expression in a for loop will perform no action other than to change a single loop parameter to the next value for the loop
Every switch statement will have at least two cases and a potential default
All 'case' and 'default' labels of 'switch' statement should have an explicit 'break' or a 'return' statement, or 'fall through' comment
Avoid comparing values with TRUE macro/enum constant using equality operators ("==", "!=")
The final clause of a switch statement shall be the default-clause unless all enumeration values are tested
A cast shall not convert a pointer to a function to any other pointer type, including a pointer to function type
Bitwise operators shall only be applied to operands of unsigned underlying type
An unconditional throw or break statement shall terminate every non-empty switch-clause
An object with integer type or pointer to void type shall not be converted to an object with pointer type
Non-constant operands to a binary bitwise operator shall have the same underlying type
The types used for an object, a function return type, or a function parameter shall be token-for-token identical in all declarations and re-declarations
A "U" suffix shall be applied to all octal or hexadecimal integer literals of unsigned type
Expressions with type (plain) char and wchar_t shall not be used as operands to built-in operators other than =, ==, != and the unary & operator
Expressions with type enum shall not be used as operands to built-in operators other than [ ], =, ==, !=, <, <=, >, >=, and the unary & operator
Named bit-fields with signed integer type shall have a length of more than one bit
Assembler instructions shall only be introduced using the asm declaration
Bit-fields shall not have enum type
Bit-fields shall be either bool type or an explicitly unsigned or signed integral type
The identifier main shall not be used for a function other than the global function main
The goto statement shall jump to a label declared later in the same function body
Any label referenced by a goto statement shall be declared in the same block, or in a block enclosing the goto statement
For any iteration statement there shall be no more than one break or goto statement used for loop termination
The continue statement shall only be used within a well formed for loop
If a function has internal linkage then all re-declarations shall include the 'static' storage class specifier
Avoid infinite loops
Do not use empty infinite loops
All loops must have a fixed upper or lower bound
Avoid exit points within infinite loops
The validity of parameters must be checked inside each function
Use no more than one level of dereferencing
Function pointers are not permitted
The declaration should not contain more than one level of pointer indirection
Each operand of a logical '&&' or '||' shall be a postfix-expression
A function shall have at most one exit point
The names of standard library macros and objects shall not be reused
Reserved identifiers, macros and functions in the standard library, shall not be defined, redefined or undefined (C90 code)
Reserved identifiers, macros and functions in the standard library, shall not be defined, redefined or undefined (C99 code)
Do not declare pointer or array type
Do not declare pointer type
Bit-fields shall have explicitly unsigned integral or enumeration types only
Use parenthesis to clarify expression order if operators with precedence lower than arithmetic are used
All 'if...else if' constructs will contain either a final else clause or a comment indicating why a final else clause is not necessary
Signed and unsigned values shall not be mixed in comparison operations

category.description: Coding Conventions for Modern C
category.name: MC

rule.header: The 'alignof' operator should not be used with an array type as its operand
A declaration of an object should contain at most one explicit alignment specifier
The zero-alignment specifier should not be used in an object declaration
Explicit alignment specifiers in all declarations of an object with internal linkage shall be the same
Every generic selection shall contain a default association
The default association shall be placed first or last in the association list
A generic selection shall indicate at least one non-default association
A generic selection should only be expanded from a macro
A generic association shall list an appropriate type
A generic selection used in a macro definition should have a macro parameter in the controlling expression
The controlling expression of a generic selection shall have an essential type that matches its standard type
A generic selection that is not expanded from a macro shall not contain potential side effects in the controlling expression
Enumerated types should not be mixed with integer types in generic selections
A generic selection that is expanded from a macro shall evaluate its argument only once
The '_Atomic' qualifier should not be used with the 'void' type
Members of atomic objects of structure and union types should not be directly accessed
A cast shall not remove any '_Atomic' qualification from the type of a pointer
The value of an expression with atomic type should be independent from thread interleaving
Only 'memory_order_seq_cst' should be used as an explicit memory order argument
The second argument passed to the 'mtx_init()' function call should be either 'mtx_plain', 'mtx_timed', 'mtx_plain | mtx_recursive', or 'mtx_timed | mtx_recursive'
Thread objects, thread synchronization objects, and thread-specific storage pointers shall only be accessed by the appropriate Standard Library functions
A generic selection should not depend on implicit pointer type conversion
The second or third operand of a ternary operator '?:' shall not contain side effects
If a pointer to a structure or union is never dereferenced within a translation unit, then the implementation of the object should be hidden
A full expression containing an increment (++) or decrement (--) operator should have no other potential side effects
A conversion should not be performed between a pointer to object and an integer type
A conversion should not be performed between a pointer to object type and an integer type other than 'uintptr_t' or 'intptr_t'
A conversion should not be performed from pointer to void into pointer to object
A function parameter should not be modified
The function argument corresponding to a parameter declared to have an array type shall have an appropriate number of elements
Do not use enumerations in boolean condition
The cast operation to essentially enumeration type is not allowed
Do not use casts between essentially character types and essentially floating types
A function should not contain unused type declarations
A source file should not contain unused type declarations
A function should not contain unused local tag declarations
A source file should not contain unused tag declarations
A source file should not contain unused macro definitions
The +, -, += and -= operators should not be applied to an expression of pointer type
'Do' statements should not be used except in a function-like macro
The operands of the remainder operator '%' should be of unsigned integer types
Avoid switch statements with only one case
Suspicious use of semicolon
Cast to void is not allowed
Hardcoded array declarations and 'malloc' calls should not be used
Do not declare member variables as bit-fields
Do not declare local variables with the 'static' keyword
Assert liberally to document internal assumptions and invariants
Assertions should not contain function calls nor function-like macro calls
Prefer 'while' statements over 'do' statements
Do not hard code string literals
When using enum, the values of each member should be explicitly declared
The standard library functions for which return values need not be checked should be cast to 'void'
Do not call 'getc()', 'putc()', 'getwc()', or 'putwc()' with a stream argument containing function calls or function-like macro calls
The macro FALSE should be defined as 0 (zero)
The enumeration constant named 'FALSE' should be explicitly initialized by 0 value
Define fields for union declarations
The macro TRUE should be defined as 1
The enumeration constant named 'TRUE' should be explicitly initialized by 1 value
Use positive logic rather than negative logic whenever practical
The names of standard library functions shall not be overridden

category.description: Common Weakness Enumeration
category.name: CWE

category.description: CWE-772 Missing Release of Resource after Effective Lifetime

rule.header: Define a virtual destructor in classes used as base classes which have virtual functions

category.description: CWE-20 Improper Input Validation

rule.header: Untrusted data is used as a loop boundary

category.description: CWE-200 Information Exposure

rule.header: Do not print potentially sensitive information, resulting from an application error into exception messages

category.description: CWE-287 Improper Authentication

rule.header: Do not use weak encryption functions

category.description: CWE-326 Inadequate Encryption Strength

rule.header: Do not use weak encryption functions

category.description: CWE-362 Concurrent Execution using Shared Resource with Improper Synchronization ('Race Condition')

rule.header: Usage of functions prone to race is not allowed

category.description: CWE-426 Untrusted Search Path

rule.header: Use care to ensure that LoadLibrary() will load the correct library

category.description: CWE-427: Uncontrolled Search Path Element

rule.header: Use care to ensure that LoadLibrary() will load the correct library

category.description: CWE-863 Incorrect Authorization

rule.header: Do not use 'cuserid' function

category.description: CWE-119 Improper Restriction of Operations within the Bounds of a Memory Buffer

rule.header: Suspicious use of 'strcpy' without checking size of source buffer

category.description: CWE-190 Integer Overflow or Wraparound

rule.header: Avoid possible integer overflow in expressions in which the result is cast to a wider integer type
Avoid possible integer overflow in expressions in which the result is assigned to a variable of a wider integer type
Avoid possible integer overflow in expressions in which the result is compared to an expression of a wider integer type
Integer overflow or underflow in constant expression in '+', '-', '*' operator
Integer overflow or underflow in constant expression in '<<' operator
Evaluation of constant unsigned integer expressions should not lead to wrap-around

category.description: CWE-269 Improper Privilege Management

rule.header: Observe correct revocation order while relinquishing privileges
Ensure that privilege relinquishment is successful

category.description: CWE-416 Use After Free

rule.header: Freed memory shouldn't be accessed under any circumstances

category.description: CWE-617 Reachable Assertion

rule.header: Do not use assertions

category.description: CWE-704 Incorrect Type Conversion or Cast

rule.header: Conversions shall not be performed between a pointer to a function and any other type than pointer to function
Conversions shall not be performed between non compatible pointer to a function types
Conversions shall not be performed between a pointer to an incomplete type and any other type
A cast shall not be performed between a pointer to object type and a pointer to a different object type
A cast shall not be performed between pointer to void and an arithmetic type
An implicit conversion shall not be performed between pointer to void and an arithmetic type
A cast shall not be performed between pointer to object and a non-integer arithmetic type
Implicit conversions from wider to narrower integral type which may result in a loss of information shall not be used
Implicit conversions from integral to floating type which may result in a loss of information shall not be used
Implicit conversions from integral constant to floating type which may result in a loss of information shall not be used
A conversion should not be performed between a pointer to object type and an integer type other than 'uintptr_t' or 'intptr_t'
A conversion should not be performed from pointer to void into pointer to object

category.description: CWE-732 Incorrect Permission Assignment for Critical Resource

rule.header: Specify the access permission bits if a file is created using the 'open' or 'openat' system call
Call 'umask' before calling 'mkstemp'

category.description: CWE-835 Loop with Unreachable Exit Condition ('Infinite Loop')

rule.header: Avoid infinite loops

category.description: CWE-843: Access of Resource Using Incompatible Type ('Type Confusion')

rule.header: A cast should not be performed between a pointer to object type and a different pointer to object type

category.description: CWE-798 Use of Hard-coded Credentials

rule.header: Do not hard code string literals
Never allow an exception to be thrown from a destructor, deallocation, and swap
Throw by value, catch by reference
Do not throw from within destructor
The assignment-expression of a throw statement shall not itself cause an exception to be thrown
All exceptions should be rethrown or logged with standard logger
C++ exceptions shall not be used (i.e. throw, catch and try shall not be used.)
There should be at least one exception handler to catch all otherwise unhandled exceptions
An empty throw (throw;) shall only be used in the compound-statement of a catch handler
Exceptions shall be raised only after start-up and before termination of the program
An exception object should not have pointer type
Control shall not be transferred into a try or catch block using a goto or a switch statement
NULL shall not be thrown explicitly
Each exception explicitly thrown in the code shall have a handler of a compatible type in all call paths that could lead to that point
Where a function's declaration includes an exception-specification, the function shall only be capable of throwing exceptions of the indicated type(s)
A class type exception shall always be caught by reference
Handlers of a function-try-block implementation of a class constructor or destructor shall not reference nonstatic members from this class or its bases
Where multiple handlers are provided in a single try-catch statement or function-try-block for a derived class and some or all of its bases, the handlers shall be ordered most-derived to base class
Function called in global or namespace scope shall not throw unhandled exceptions
Exception objects must be nothrow copy constructible
An explicitly declared copy constructor for a class that inherits from 'std::exception' should have a non-throwing exception specification
All user-provided move constructors and move assignment operators shall not exit with an exception
Checked exceptions that could be thrown from a function shall be specified in the comment directly before the function declaration
Do not use throw exception specifications
Where multiple handlers are provided in a single 'try-catch' statement or 'function-try-block', any ellipsis (catch-all) handler shall occur last
Do not leave 'catch' blocks empty
Avoid using catch-all exception handlers

category.description: High Integrity C++
category.name: HICPP

category.description: HIC++ 10.3.1 Ensure that a derived class has at most one base class which is not an interface class

rule.header: Ensure that a derived class has at most one base class which is not an interface class

category.description: HIC++ 12.1.1 Do not declare implicit user defined conversions

rule.header: Constructors allowing for conversion should be made explicit
User-conversion cast operators should be made explicit

category.description: HIC++ 12.2.1 Declare virtual, private or protected the destructor of a type used as a base class

rule.header: Make destructors virtual in base classes

category.description: HIC++ 12.4.2 Ensure that a constructor initializes explicitly all base classes and non-static data members

rule.header: All member variables should be initialized in constructor

category.description: HIC++ 15.2.1 Do not throw an exception from a destructor

rule.header: Do not throw from within destructor

category.description: HIC++ 5.1.2 Do not rely on the sequence of evaluation within an expression

rule.header: Don't write code that depends on the order of evaluation of function arguments
The value of an expression shall be the same under any order of evaluation that the standard permits
Don't write code that depends on the order of evaluation of function designator and function arguments
Don't write code that depends on the order of evaluation of expression that involves a function call
Between sequence points an object shall have its stored value modified at most once by the evaluation of an expression
Do not use more than one volatile between two adjacent sequence points
Don't write code that depends on the order of evaluation of function calls
The increment (++) and decrement (--) operators should not be mixed with other operators in an expression
The comma operator shall not be used
The result of a built-in assignment operator should not be used

category.description: HIC++ 11.1.1 Declare all data members private

rule.header: Avoid "public" data members
Avoid 'protected' data members

category.description: HIC++ 16.1.2 Do not include a path specifier in filenames supplied in #include directives

rule.header: Do not allow absolute or relative path names in #include statements
The \ character should not occur in a header file name

category.description: HIC++ 5.4.3 Do not convert from a base class to a derived class

rule.header: Down casting (casting from base to derived class) shall not be allowed

category.description: HIC++ 10.1.1 Ensure that access to base class subobjects does not require explicit disambiguation

rule.header: For multiple inheritance use virtual common base class

category.description: HIC++ 10.2.1 Use the override special identifier when overriding a virtual function

rule.header: Each overriding virtual function shall be declared with the override or final specifier

category.description: HIC++ 11.2.1 Do not use friend declarations

rule.header: Avoid using the friend mechanism

category.description: HIC++ 12.3.1 Correctly declare overloads for operator new and delete

rule.header: Write operator delete if you write operator new
Write operator delete[] if you write operator new[]

category.description: HIC++ 12.4.3 Do not specify both an NSDMI and a member initializer in a constructor for the same non static member

rule.header: Do not specify both an NSDMI and a member initializer in a constructor for the same non-static member

category.description: HIC++ 12.4.4 Write members in an initialization list in the order in which they are declared

rule.header: List members in an initialization list in the order in which they are declared

category.description: HIC++ 12.4.5 Use delegating constructors to reduce code duplication

rule.header: Use delegating constructors to reduce code duplication

category.description: HIC++ 12.5.1 Define explicitly =default or =delete implicit special member functions of concrete classes

rule.header: Explicitly define =default or =delete special member functions of concrete classes implicitly provided by the compiler

category.description: HIC++ 12.5.2 Define special members =default if the behavior is equivalent

rule.header: Define special members as =default when the behavior is equivalent to the compiler's behavior

category.description: HIC++ 12.5.3 Ensure that a user defined move/copy constructor only moves/copies base and member objects

rule.header: A copy constructor shall only initialize its base classes and the non-static members of the class of which it is a member

category.description: HIC++ 12.5.4 Declare noexcept the move constructor and move assignment operator

rule.header: All user-provided move constructors and move assignment operators shall not exit with an exception

category.description: HIC++ 12.5.6 Use an atomic, non-throwing swap operation to implement the copy and move assignment operators

rule.header: User-defined copy and move assignment operators should use user-defined no-throw swap function

category.description: HIC++ 12.5.7 Declare assignment operators with the ref-qualifier &

rule.header: Declare assignment operators with the ref-qualifier &

category.description: HIC++ 12.5.8 Make the copy assignment operator of an abstract class protected or define it =delete

rule.header: The copy assignment operator shall be declared protected or private in an abstract class

category.description: HIC++ 13.1.1 Ensure that all overloads of a function are visible from where it is called

rule.header: Member functions declared in derived class should not hide functions declared in base classes

category.description: HIC++ 13.1.2 If a member of a set of callable functions includes a universal reference parameter, ensure that one appears in the same position for all other members

rule.header: Avoid Overloading on Forwarding References

category.description: HIC++ 13.2.1 Do not overload operators with special semantics

rule.header: Avoid overloading logical operators AND, OR (&&, ||)
Avoid overloading comma operator ","

category.description: HIC++ 13.2.2 Ensure that the return type of an overloaded binary operator matches the built-in counterparts

rule.header: A relational operator shall return a boolean value
A binary arithmetic operator and a bitwise operator shall return a 'prvalue'

category.description: HIC++ 13.2.3 Declare binary arithmetic and bitwise operators as non-members

rule.header: Declare binary arithmetic and bitwise operators as non-members

category.description: HIC++ 13.2.4 When overloading the subscript operator (operator[]) implement both const and non-const versions

rule.header: When overloading the subscript operator (operator[]), implement both const and non-const versions

category.description: HIC++ 13.2.5 Implement a minimal set of operators and use them to implement all other related operators

rule.header: The overloaded binary operator should be implemented in terms of its corresponding compound assignment operator

category.description: HIC++ 14.1.1 Use variadic templates rather than an ellipsis

rule.header: Do not use functions with variable numbers of arguments

category.description: HIC++ 14.2.1 Declare template specializations in the same file as the primary template they specialize.

rule.header: All partial and explicit specializations for a template shall be declared in the same file as the declaration of their primary template

category.description: HIC++ 14.2.2 Do not explicitly specialize a function template that is overloaded with other templates

rule.header: Overloaded function templates shall not be explicitly specialized

category.description: HIC++ 14.2.3 Declare extern an explicitly instantiated template

rule.header: Declare 'extern' an explicitly instantiated template

category.description: HIC++ 15.1.1 Only use instances of std::exception for exceptions

rule.header: Only use instances of std::exception for exceptions

category.description: HIC++ 15.3.1 Do not access non-static members from a catch handler of constructor/destructor function try block

rule.header: Handlers of a function-try-block implementation of a class constructor or destructor shall not reference nonstatic members from this class or its bases

category.description: HIC++ 15.3.2 Ensure that a program does not result in a call to std::terminate

rule.header: There should be at least one exception handler to catch all otherwise unhandled exceptions

category.description: HIC++ 16.1.1 Use the preprocessor only for implementing include guards, and including header files with include guards

rule.header: Avoid using macro definitions
The #ifndef pre-processor directive will only be used to prevent multiple inclusions of the same header file
The #ifdef, #else, #elif preprocessor directives should not be used
Use multiple include guards
The #endif pre-processor directives will only be used to prevent multiple inclusions of the same header file
The #if pre-processor directive will only be used to prevent multiple inclusions of the same header file
#error directive shall not be used
The #pragma directive shall not be used
#undef shall not be used

category.description: HIC++ 16.1.3 Match the filename in a #include directive to the one on the filesystem

rule.header: Match the filename in a #include directive to the one on the filesystem

category.description: HIC++ 16.1.4 Use <> brackets for system and standard library headers. Use quotes for all other headers

rule.header: Use <> brackets for system and standard library headers. Use quotes for all other headers

category.description: HIC++ 17.1.1 Do not use std::vector<bool>

rule.header: Avoid using vector<bool>

category.description: HIC++ 17.2.1 Wrap use of the C Standard Library

rule.header: The error indicator 'errno' shall not be used
Wrap use of the C Standard Library

category.description: HIC++ 17.3.1 Do not use std::move on objects declared with const or const & type

rule.header: Do not use std::move on objects declared with the const or const & type

category.description: HIC++ 17.3.2 Use std::forward to forward universal references

rule.header: The 'std::forward' function shall be used to forward universal references

category.description: HIC++ 17.3.4 Do not create smart pointers of array type

rule.header: Do not create smart pointers of array type

category.description: HIC++ 17.3.5 Do not create an rvalue reference of std::array

rule.header: Do not create an rvalue reference of std::array

category.description: HIC++ 17.4.1 Use const container calls when result is immediately converted to a const iterator

rule.header: Use const container calls when the result is immediately converted to a const iterator

category.description: HIC++ 17.4.2 Use API calls that construct objects in place

rule.header: Prefer 'std::make_shared' to the direct use of new

category.description: HIC++ 17.5.1 Do not ignore the result of std::remove, std::remove if or std::unique

rule.header: Follow remove-like algorithms by erase to remove elements from a container

category.description: HIC++ 18.1.1 Do not use platform specific multi-threading facilities

rule.header: Do not use platform-specific multi-threading facilities

category.description: HIC++ 18.2.1 Use high integrity::thread in place of std::thread

rule.header: Use high_integrity::thread in place of std::thread

category.description: HIC++ 18.2.3 Do not share volatile data between threads

rule.header: Do not share volatile data between threads

category.description: HIC++ 18.2.4 Use std::call_once rather than the Double-Checked Locking pattern

rule.header: Use std::call_once rather than the Double-Checked Locking pattern

category.description: HIC++ 18.3.3 Do not use std::recursive mutex

rule.header: Do not use std::recursive_mutex

category.description: HIC++ 18.3.4 Only use std::unique lock when std::lock guard cannot be used

rule.header: Only use std::unique lock when std::lock guard cannot be used

category.description: HIC++ 18.3.5 Do not access the members of std::mutex directly

rule.header: Do not access the members of std::mutex directly

category.description: HIC++ 18.3.6 Do not use relaxed atomics

rule.header: Do not use relaxed atomics

category.description: HIC++ 18.4.1 Do not use std::condition variable any on a std::mutex

rule.header: Do not use std::condition_variable_any on a std::mutex

category.description: HIC++ 1.2.1 Ensure that all statements are reachable

rule.header: There shall be no unreachable code in "else" block
There shall be no unreachable code after 'return', 'break', 'continue', and 'goto' statements
There shall be no unreachable code in "if/else/while/for" block
There shall be no unreachable code in switch statement
There shall be no unreachable code in 'for' loop
There shall be no unreachable code after 'if' or 'switch' statement
There shall be no unreachable code after "if" or "switch" statement inside while/for/do...while loop

category.description: HIC++ 1.2.2 Ensure that no expression or sub-expression is redundant

rule.header: All non-null statements shall either have at least one side-effect however executed or cause control flow to change

category.description: HIC++ 1.3.1 Do not use the increment operator (++) on a variable of type bool

rule.header: Do not use the increment operator (++) on an operand of type 'bool'

category.description: HIC++ 1.3.3 Do not use the C Standard Library .h headers

rule.header: The C library shall not be used

category.description: HIC++ 1.3.4 Do not use deprecated STL library features

rule.header: Do not use deprecated STL library features

category.description: HIC++ 1.3.5 Do not use throw exception specifications

rule.header: Do not use throw exception specifications

category.description: HIC++ 2.2.1 Do not use digraphs or trigraphs

rule.header: Do not use the following digraphs: <%, %>, <:, :>, %:, %:%:
Trigraphs shall not be used

category.description: HIC++ 2.3.1 Do not use the C comment delimiters /* ... */

rule.header: Prefer C++ style comment

category.description: HIC++ 2.4.1 Ensure that each identifier is distinct from any other visible identifier

rule.header: Different identifiers shall be typographically unambiguous

category.description: HIC++ 2.5.1 Do not concatenate strings with different encoding prefixes

rule.header: String literals with different encoding prefixes shall not be concatenated

category.description: HIC++ 2.5.2 Do not use octal constants (other than zero)

rule.header: Octal constants (other than zero) shall not be used

category.description: HIC++ 3.1.1 Do not hide declarations

rule.header: Identifier declared in a local or function prototype scope shall not hide an identifier declared in a global or namespace scope
Identifiers declared in an inner local scope should not hide identifiers declared in an outer local scope
Identifiers declared in a local scope should not hide identifiers declared in a class scope
Identifiers declared in a class scope should not hide identifiers declared in a global or namespace scope
Identifiers declared in an inner class scope should not hide identifiers declared in outer class scope

category.description: HIC++ 3.2.1 Do not declare functions at block scope

rule.header: Always declare functions at file scope

category.description: HIC++ 3.3.1 Do not use variables with static storage duration

rule.header: Do not use variables with static storage duration

category.description: HIC++ 3.4.1 Do not return a reference or a pointer to an automatic variable defined within the function

rule.header: The address of an object with automatic storage shall not be returned from a function

category.description: HIC++ 3.4.2 Do not assign the address of a variable to a pointer with a greater lifetime

rule.header: The address of an object with automatic storage shall not be assigned to another object that may persist after the first object has ceased to exist

category.description: HIC++ 3.5.1 Do not make any assumptions about the internal representation of a value or object

rule.header: Unions shall not be used
typedefs should be used in place of the basic types

category.description: HIC++ 4.1.1 Ensure that a function argument does not undergo an array-to-pointer conversion

rule.header: An identifier with array type passed as a function argument shall not decay to a pointer
Do not pass an expression with array type to a function with a pointer or array type parameter

category.description: HIC++ 4.2.1 Ensure that the U suffix is applied to a literal used in a context requiring an unsigned integral expression

rule.header: Apply the U suffix to literals used in a context that requires an unsigned integral expression

category.description: HIC++ 4.2.2 Ensure that data loss does not demonstrably occur in an integral expression

rule.header: The right-hand operand of a shift operator shall lie between zero and one less than the width in bits of the underlying type of the left-hand operand
Avoid explicit type conversions (casts)
Integer overflow or underflow in constant expression in '+', '-', '*' operator
Integer overflow or underflow in constant expression in '<<' operator

category.description: HIC++ 4.3.1 Do not convert an expression of wider floating point type to a narrower floating point type

rule.header: Avoid implicit conversions from wider to narrower floating type
Avoid implicit conversions of floating point numbers from wider to narrower floating type

category.description: HIC++ 4.4.1 Do not convert floating values to integral types except through use of standard library functions

rule.header: Avoid implicit conversions from floating to integral type

category.description: HIC++ 5.1.1 Use symbolic names instead of literal values in code

rule.header: Avoid magic numbers

category.description: HIC++ 5.1.3 Use parentheses in expressions to specify the intent of the expression

rule.header: Use parentheses unless all operators in the expression are the same
The operands of a logical && or || shall be primary-expressions

category.description: HIC++ 5.1.4 Do not capture variables implicitly in a lambda

rule.header: Do not capture variables implicitly in a lambda

category.description: HIC++ 5.1.5 Include a (possibly empty) parameter list in every lambda expression

rule.header: Include a parameter list in every lambda expression

category.description: HIC++ 5.1.6 Do not code side effects into the right-hand operands of: &&, ||, sizeof, typeid or a function passed to condition variable::wait

rule.header: The operand of the sizeof operator shall not contain any expression which has side effects
Object designated by a volatile lvalue should not be accessed in the operand of the sizeof operator
The function call that causes the side effect shall not be the operand of the sizeof operator
The right-hand operand of a logical && or || operator shall not contain side effects
The operand of the 'typeid' operator shall not contain any expression that has side effects
The operand of the 'typeid' operator shall not contain a function call that causes side effects

category.description: HIC++ 5.2.2 Ensure that functions do not call themselves, either directly or indirectly

rule.header: Functions shall not call themselves, either directly or indirectly

category.description: HIC++ 5.3.1 Do not apply unary minus to operands of unsigned type

rule.header: The unary minus operator shall not be applied to an expression whose underlying type is unsigned

category.description: HIC++ 5.3.2 Allocate memory using new and release it using delete

rule.header: Do not use calloc, malloc, realloc and free functions

category.description: HIC++ 5.3.3 Ensure that the form of delete matches the form of new used to allocate the memory

rule.header: Never provide brackets ([]) for delete when deallocating non-arrays
Always provide empty brackets ([]) for delete when deallocating arrays

category.description: HIC++ 5.4.1 Only use casting forms: static cast (excl. void*), dynamic cast or explicit constructor call

rule.header: C-style casts should not be used
Avoid using reinterpret_cast
A cast shall not remove any 'const' or 'volatile' qualification from the type of a pointer or reference

category.description: HIC++ 5.4.2 Do not cast an expression to an enumeration type

rule.header: Do not cast an expression to an enumeration type

category.description: HIC++ 5.6.1 Do not use bitwise operators with signed operands

rule.header: Bitwise operators shall only be applied to operands of unsigned underlying type

category.description: HIC++ 5.7.1 Do not write code that expects floating point calculations to yield exact results

rule.header: Floating-point expressions shall not be tested for equality or inequality

category.description: HIC++ 5.7.2 Ensure that a pointer to member that is a virtual function is only compared (==) with nullptr

rule.header: A pointer to member virtual function shall only be tested for equality with null-pointer-constant

category.description: HIC++ 5.8.1 Do not use the conditional operator (?:) as a sub-expression

rule.header: The conditional operator should not be used as a sub-expression

category.description: HIC++ 6.1.1 Enclose the body of a selection or an iteration statement in a compound statement

rule.header: The statement forming the body of a 'switch', 'while', 'do...while' or 'for' statement shall be a compound statement
'if' and 'else' should be followed by a compound statement

category.description: HIC++ 6.1.2 Explicitly cover all paths through multi-way selection statements

rule.header: All 'if...else-if' constructs shall be terminated with an 'else' clause
The final clause of a switch statement shall be the default clause

category.description: HIC++ 6.1.3 Ensure that a non-empty case statement block does not fall through to the next label

rule.header: An unconditional throw or break statement shall terminate every non-empty switch-clause

category.description: HIC++ 6.1.4 Ensure that a switch statement has at least two case labels, distinct from the default label

rule.header: Every switch statement will have at least two cases and a potential default
A switch expression shall not represent a value that is effectively Boolean

category.description: HIC++ 6.2.1 Implement a loop that only uses element values as a range-based loop

rule.header: A for-loop that loops through all elements of the container and does not use its loop-counter shall not be used

category.description: HIC++ 6.2.2 Ensure that a loop has a single loop counter, an optional control variable, and is not degenerate

rule.header: There shall only be one loop counter in a 'for' loop, which shall not be modified in the 'for' loop body

category.description: HIC++ 6.2.3 Do not alter a control or counter variable more than once in a loop

rule.header: Do not modify for loop counter within a body of the loop

category.description: HIC++ 6.2.4 Only modify a for loop counter in the for expression

rule.header: The third clause of a 'for' statement shall be well-formed

category.description: HIC++ 6.3.1 Ensure that the label(s) for a jump statement or a switch condition appear later, in the same or an enclosing block

rule.header: A switch label shall only be used when the most closely-enclosing compound statement is the body of a switch statement
The goto statement shall jump to a label declared later in the same function body
Any label referenced by a goto statement shall be declared in the same block, or in a block enclosing the goto statement

category.description: HIC++ 6.3.2 Ensure that execution of a function with a non-void return type ends in a return statement with a value

rule.header: All exit paths from a function, except main(), with non-void return type shall have an explicit return statement with an expression

category.description: HIC++ 6.4.1 Postpone variable definitions as long as possible

rule.header: Declare variables as locally as possible
Postpone variable definitions as long as possible

category.description: HIC++ 7.1.1 Declare each identifier on a separate line in a separate declaration

rule.header: Multiple variable declarations shall not be allowed on the same line
Each variable should be declared in a separate declaration statement

category.description: HIC++ 7.1.10 Use static assert for assertions involving compile time constants

rule.header: Use static_assert for assertions involving compile time constants

category.description: HIC++ 7.1.2 Use const whenever possible

rule.header: Declare local variable as const whenever possible
Declare parameters as const whenever possible

category.description: HIC++ 7.1.3 Do not place type specifiers before non-type specifiers in a declaration

rule.header: Do not place type specifiers before non-type specifiers in a declaration

category.description: HIC++ 7.1.4 Place CV-qualifiers on the right hand side of the type they apply to

rule.header: Place CV-qualifiers on the right hand side of the type they apply to

category.description: HIC++ 7.1.5 Do not inline large functions

rule.header: Do not inline large functions

category.description: HIC++ 7.1.6 Use class types or typedefs to abstract scalar quantities and standard integer types

rule.header: The plain char type shall be used only for the storage and use of character values
Use class types or typedefs to abstract scalar quantities and standard integer types
Use class types or typedefs to abstract scalar quantities and standard integer types

category.description: HIC++ 7.1.7 Use a trailing return type in preference to type disambiguation using typename

rule.header: Use a trailing return type syntax if the return type is preceded by the 'typename' keyword

category.description: HIC++ 7.1.8 Use auto id = expr when declaring a variable to have the same type as its initializer function call

rule.header: Use auto id = expr when declaring a variable that is the same type as the initializer function call

category.description: HIC++ 7.1.9 Do not explicitly specify the return type of a lambda

rule.header: Do not explicitly specify the return type of a lambda

category.description: HIC++ 7.2.1 Use an explicit enumeration base and ensure that it is large enough to store all enumerators

rule.header: Use an explicit enumeration base and ensure that it is large enough to store all enumerators

category.description: HIC++ 7.2.2 Initialize none, the first only or all enumerators in an enumeration

rule.header: Initialize all, only the first, or none of the enumerators in an enumeration

category.description: HIC++ 7.3.1 Do not use using directives

rule.header: using-directives shall not be used

category.description: HIC++ 7.4.1 Ensure that any objects, functions or types to be used from a single translation unit are defined in an unnamed namespace in the main source file

rule.header: Do not use static keyword except inside functions and classes

category.description: HIC++ 7.5.1 Do not use the asm declaration

rule.header: Do not use the asm declaration

category.description: HIC++ 8.1.1 Do not use multiple levels of pointer indirection

rule.header: The declaration should not contain more than one level of pointer indirection

category.description: HIC++ 8.2.1 Make parameter names absent or identical in all declarations

rule.header: The identifiers used in the declaration and definition of a function shall be identical

category.description: HIC++ 8.2.2 Do not declare functions with an excessive number of parameters

rule.header: Avoid functions with more than 5 parameters

category.description: HIC++ 8.2.3 Pass small objects with a trivial copy constructor by value

rule.header: Pass small objects with a trivial copy constructor by value

category.description: HIC++ 8.2.4 Do not pass std::unique ptr by const reference

rule.header: Do not pass std::unique_ptr by const reference

category.description: HIC++ 8.3.1 Do not write functions with an excessive McCabe Cyclomatic Complexity

rule.header: Follow the Cyclomatic Complexity limit of 10

category.description: HIC++ 8.3.3 Do not use default arguments

rule.header: Do not use default arguments

category.description: HIC++ 8.3.4 Define =delete functions with parameters of type rvalue reference to const

rule.header: Define rvalue reference functions that have a const parameter as =delete

category.description: HIC++ 8.4.1 Do not access an invalid object or an object with indeterminate value

rule.header: All automatic variables shall have been assigned a value before being used

category.description: HIC++ 8.4.2 Ensure that a braced aggregate initializer matches the layout of the aggregate object

rule.header: The initializer for an aggregate or union shall be enclosed in braces

category.description: HIC++ 9.1.1 Declare static any member function that does not require this. Alternatively, declare const any member function that does not modify the externally visible state of the object

rule.header: If a member function can be made static then it shall be made static, otherwise if it can be made const then it shall be made const

category.description: HIC++ 9.1.2 Make default arguments the same or absent when overriding a virtual function

rule.header: Do not redefine an inherited virtual function with a different default parameter value

category.description: HIC++ 9.1.3 Do not return non-const handles to class data from const member functions

rule.header: Const member functions shall not return non-const pointers or references to class-data

category.description: HIC++ 9.1.4 Do not write member functions which return non-const handles to data less accessible than the member function

rule.header: Public member functions shall not return non-const handles to private/protected class-data

category.description: HIC++ 9.1.5 Do not introduce virtual functions in a final class

rule.header: Do not introduce virtual functions in a final class

category.description: HIC++ 9.2.1 Declare bit-fields with an explicitly unsigned integral or enumeration type

rule.header: Bit-fields shall have explicitly unsigned integral or enumeration types only

category.description: HIC++ 2.3.2 Do not comment out code

rule.header: Do not use comments to remove sections of code

category.description: HIC++ 2.5.3 Use nullptr for the null pointer constant

rule.header: Prefer 'nullptr' over 'NULL' or '0'(zero)

category.description: HIC++ 3.4.3 Use RAII for resources

rule.header: Prefer smart pointers over raw local pointers
Do not call lock() directly on a mutex
Use RAII to prevent resource leaks

category.description: HIC++ 1.3.2 Do not use the register keyword

rule.header: The 'register' storage class specifier shall not be used

category.description: HIC++ 2.1.1 Do not use tab characters in source files

rule.header: Tabs that do not use ASCII spaces shall not be used
Do not initialize a reference to an object whose address can be changed
All member variables should be initialized in constructor
Initialize static class members
Do not use uninitialized nonstatic member variables in base class constructors
Do not use uninitialized nonstatic member variables of nonvirtual base classes in virtual base class constructors
Initialize all pointer variables
An assignment operator shall assign all data members
Objects with external linkage should not be initialized in a header file
Do not initialize unsigned integer variables with signed constants
Initialize all variables
Make class members' initialization explicit by providing user-defined constructor
User-defined constructor must be provided to ensure the proper initialization of dynamically allocated class objects
List members in an initialization list in the order in which they are declared
Avoid initialization order problems across translation units by replacing non-local static objects with local static objects
Do not assume that members are initialized in any special order in constructors
Do not use possibly uninitialized nonstatic member variables of base classes in base class constructors
The initializer for an aggregate or union shall be enclosed in braces
The data members initialized with the same constant values across all constructors should be initialized using NSDMI
User-defined constructors that initialize data members with the same constant values across all constructors should initialize using NSDMI instead
Both NSDMI and a non-static member initializer in a constructor shall not be used in the same type
Consider adding constructor to initialize 'struct' member variables
Prefer initialization to assignment in constructors

category.description: MISRA C 2004
category.name: MISRA2004

rule.header: Don't write code that depends on the order of evaluation of function arguments
Avoid implicit conversions between signed and unsigned integer types
There shall be no implicit conversions from integral to floating type
Avoid implicit conversions of complex expressions
Avoid implicit conversions from wider to narrower types
Avoid implicit conversions of function return expressions
Avoid implicit conversions of complex expressions
Avoid implicit conversions of function arguments
Avoid implicit conversions of complex expressions
Avoid implicit conversions from floating to integral type
Avoid implicit conversions from wider to narrower floating type
Avoid implicit conversions from narrower to wider floating type
Avoid implicit conversions of floating point numbers from wider to narrower floating type
The value of a complex expression of integer type shall only be cast to a type of the same signedness that is no wider than the underlying type of the expression
The value of a complex expression of floating type should not be cast to a wider floating type
The value of a complex expression of floating type should not be cast to an integer type
If the bitwise operators ~ and << are applied to an operand of underlying type unsigned char or unsigned short, the result shall be immediately cast to the underlying type of the operand
Conversions shall not be performed between a pointer to a function and any type other than an integral type
Conversions shall not be performed between a pointer to object and any type other than an integral type, another pointer to object type or a pointer to void
Conversions shall not be performed between a pointer to object and any type other than an integral type, another pointer to object type or a pointer to void
Conversions shall not be performed between a pointer to object and any type other than an integral type, another pointer to object type or a pointer to void
A cast should not convert a pointer type to an integral type
A cast should not convert an integral type to a pointer type
A cast should not be performed between a pointer to object type and a different pointer to object type
A cast shall not remove any 'const' or 'volatile' qualification from the type of a pointer or reference
The comma operator shall not be used
The underlying bit representations of floating-point values shall not be used
The increment (++) and decrement (--) operators should not be mixed with other operators in an expression
Use parenthesis for the right-hand operand of an assignment operator when it contains an assignment expression
Limited dependence should be placed on C's operator precedence rules in expressions
Use parentheses unless all operators in the expression are the same
The value of an expression shall be the same under any order of evaluation that the standard permits
Don't write code that depends on the order of evaluation of function designator and function arguments
Don't write code that depends on the order of evaluation of expression that involves a function call
Between sequence points an object shall have its stored value modified at most once by the evaluation of an expression
Do not use more than one volatile between two adjacent sequence points
Don't write code that depends on the order of evaluation of function calls
The operand of the sizeof operator shall not contain any expression which has side effects
Object designated by a volatile lvalue should not be accessed in the operand of the sizeof operator
The function call that causes the side effect shall not be the operand of the sizeof operator
The right-hand operand of a logical && or || operator shall not contain side effects
The operands of a logical && or || shall be primary-expressions
The operands of logical operators (&&, || and !) should be effectively Boolean
Expressions that are effectively Boolean should not be used as operands to operators other than (&&, ||, !, =, ==, !=, ?:)
Bitwise operators shall not be applied to operands whose underlying type is signed
The right-hand operand of a shift operator shall lie between zero and one less than the width in bits of the underlying type of the left-hand operand
The unary minus operator shall not be applied to an expression whose underlying type is unsigned
Assignment operators shall not be used in expressions that yield a Boolean value
Tests of a value against zero should be made explicit, unless the operand is effectively Boolean
Floating-point expressions shall not be tested for equality or inequality
The controlling expression of a for statement shall not contain any objects of floating type
The three expressions of a for statement shall be concerned only with loop control
Do not modify for loop counter within a body of the loop
Boolean operations whose results are invariant shall not be permitted
Boolean operations whose results are invariant shall not be permitted
Boolean operations whose results are invariant shall not be permitted
Boolean operations whose results are invariant shall not be permitted
Boolean operations whose results are invariant shall not be permitted
Boolean operations whose results are invariant shall not be permitted
Boolean operations whose results are invariant shall not be permitted
Boolean operations whose results are invariant shall not be permitted
Boolean operations whose results are invariant shall not be permitted
Boolean operations whose results are invariant shall not be permitted
Boolean operations whose results are invariant shall not be permitted
Boolean operations whose results are invariant shall not be permitted
Boolean operations whose results are invariant shall not be permitted
Boolean operations whose results are invariant shall not be permitted
Boolean operations whose results are invariant shall not be permitted
Boolean operations whose results are invariant shall not be permitted
Boolean operations whose results are invariant shall not be permitted
Boolean operations whose results are invariant shall not be permitted
Boolean operations whose results are invariant shall not be permitted
Boolean operations whose results are invariant shall not be permitted
Boolean operations whose results are invariant shall not be permitted
Boolean operations whose results are invariant shall not be permitted
Boolean operations whose results are invariant shall not be permitted
Boolean operations whose results are invariant shall not be permitted
Boolean operations whose results are invariant shall not be permitted
Boolean operations whose results are invariant shall not be permitted
Boolean operations whose results are invariant shall not be permitted
Boolean operations whose results are invariant shall not be permitted
All 'if...else-if' constructs shall be terminated with an 'else' clause
There shall be no unreachable code in "else" block
There shall be no unreachable code after 'return', 'break', 'continue', and 'goto' statements
There shall be no unreachable code in "if/else/while/for" block
There shall be no unreachable code in switch statement
There shall be no unreachable code in 'for' loop
There shall be no unreachable code after 'if' or 'switch' statement
There shall be no unreachable code after "if" or "switch" statement inside while/for/do...while loop
All non-null statements shall either have at least one side-effect however executed or cause control flow to change
A null statement shall occur on a line by itself or be followed by a comment
The goto statement shall not be used
The continue statement shall not be used
For any iteration statement there shall be at most one break statement used for loop termination
A function shall have a single point of exit at the end of the function
The statement forming the body of a 'switch', 'while', 'do...while' or 'for' statement shall be a compound statement
'if' and 'else' should be followed by a compound statement
A break statement should be placed only at the end of switch clause
A switch statement shall only contain switch labels and switch clauses, and no other code
A switch label shall only be used when the most closely-enclosing compound statement is the body of a switch statement
An unconditional break statement shall terminate every non-empty case clause
An unconditional break statement shall terminate every non-empty default clause
The final clause of a switch statement shall be the default clause
A switch expression shall not represent a value that is effectively Boolean
A switch expression shall not represent a value that is effectively Boolean
Every switch statement shall have at least one case clause
Functions shall not be defined with a variable number of arguments
If a function returns error information, then that error information shall be tested
Functions shall not call themselves, either directly or indirectly
Identifiers shall be given for all of the parameters in a function prototype declaration
The identifiers used in the declaration and definition of a function shall be identical
Functions with no parameters shall be declared with parameter type void
The number of arguments passed to a function shall match the number of parameters
A pointer parameter in a function prototype should be declared as pointer to const if the pointer is not used to modify the addressed object
Declare a type of parameter as typedef to pointer to const if the pointer is not used to modify the addressed object
All exit paths from a function with non-void return type shall have an explicit return statement with an expression
All exit paths from a function, except main(), with non-void return type shall have an explicit return statement with an expression
A function identifier shall only be used with either a preceding '&', or with a parenthesised parameter list, which may be empty
Do not apply arithmetic to pointers that don't address an array or array element
Pointer subtraction shall only be applied to pointers that address elements of the same array
>, >=, <, <= shall not be applied to pointer types except where they point to the same array
Array indexing shall be the only allowed form of pointer arithmetic
The declaration of objects should contain no more than 2 levels of pointer indirection
The address of an object with automatic storage shall not be returned from a function
The address of an object with automatic storage shall not be assigned to another object that may persist after the first object has ceased to exist
All structure and union types shall be complete at the end of a translation unit
An object shall not be assigned to an overlapping object
An object shall not be assigned to an overlapping object
Unions shall not be used
#include statements in a file should only be preceded by other preprocessor directives or comments
In the definition of a function-like macro each instance of a parameter shall be enclosed in parentheses unless it is used as the operand of # or ##
Do not use in preprocessor directives #if and #elif macros not defined in translation unit
There shall be at most one occurrence of the # or ## preprocessor operators in a single macro definition
The # and ## preprocessor operators should not be used
The defined preprocessor operator shall only be used in one of the two standard forms
Precautions shall be taken in order to prevent the contents of a header file being included twice
Preprocessing directives shall be syntactically meaningful even when excluded by the preprocessor
All #else, #elif and #endif preprocessor directives shall reside in the same file as the #if or #ifdef directive to which they are related
Non-standard characters should not occur in header file names in #include directives
The #include directive shall be followed by either a <filename> or "filename" sequence
Avoid keywords and basic types in macros
Macros shall not be #define'd or #undef'd within a block
#undef shall not be used
A function should be used in preference to a function-like macro
A function-like macro shall not be invoked without all of its arguments
Arguments to a function-like macro shall not contain tokens that look like preprocessing directives
The library functions atof, atoi and atol from library stdlib.h shall not be used
The 'abort()' function from the 'stdlib.h' or 'cstdlib' library shall not be used
The 'exit()' function from the 'stdlib.h' or 'cstdlib' library shall not be used
The 'getenv()' function from the 'stdlib.h' or 'cstdlib' library shall not be used
The 'system()' function from the 'stdlib.h' or 'cstdlib' library shall not be used
The standard header files <time.h> or <ctime> shall not be used
The time handling functions and macros of the library <time.h> shall not be used
The types defined in the library <time.h> shall not be used
Do not #define or #undef identifiers with names which start with underscore
Do not redefine reserved words
Reserved identifiers, macros and functions in the standard library, shall not be defined, redefined or undefined (C90 code)
Do not #define nor #undef identifier 'defined'
The names of standard library macros, objects and functions shall not be reused
The names of standard library macros, objects and functions shall not be reused (C90)
The names of standard library macros, objects and functions shall not be reused (C99)
The validity of values passed to library functions shall be checked
Dynamic heap memory allocation shall not be used
The error indicator 'errno' shall not be used
The macro offsetof, in library stddef.h, shall not be used
The facilities provided by <setjmp.h> should not be used
The standard header files <setjmp.h> or <csetjmp> shall not be used
The standard header files <signal.h> or <csignal> shall not be used
The signal handling facilities of <signal.h> shall not be used
The input/output library stdio.h shall not be used
Assembly language shall be encapsulated and isolated
Source code shall only use /* ... */ style comments
The character sequence /* shall not be used within a C-style comment
All uses of the #pragma directive shall be documented and explained
Do not mix bit-fields and other data within the same structure
Only those escape sequences that are defined in the ISO C standard shall be used
Trigraphs shall not be used
User-specified C external identifiers should differ in the first 31 characters
User-specified C internal identifiers should differ from external identifiers in the first 31 characters
User-specified C internal identifiers declared in the same scope should differ in the first 31 characters
Identifier declared in a local or function prototype scope shall not hide an identifier declared in a global or namespace scope
Identifiers declared in an inner local scope should not hide identifiers declared in an outer local scope
Do not reuse typedef names
Do not reuse typedef names as a typedef name
A tag name shall not be reused for other purpose within the program
A tag name shall not be reused to define a different tag
The name of typedef should not be the same as the name of type that is typedef'd
The plain char type shall be used only for the storage and use of character values
signed and unsigned char type shall be used only for the storage and use of numeric values
typedefs to basic types should contain some digits in their name
typedefs should be used in place of the basic types
Bit fields shall only be defined to be of type unsigned int or signed int
Named bit-fields with signed integer type shall have a length of more than one bit
Unnamed bit-fields with signed integer type shall have a length of more than one bit
Octal constants (other than zero) shall not be used
Octal escape sequences shall not be used
The static storage class specifier shall be used in definitions and declarations of objects and functions that have internal linkage
When an array is declared with external linkage, its size shall be stated explicitly or defined implicitly by initialisation
Functions shall have prototype declarations and the prototype shall be visible at both the function definition and call
Functions shall always have visible prototype at the function call
Whenever a function is declared or defined, its type shall be explicitly stated
Whenever an object is declared or defined, its type shall be explicitly stated
Use identical types in declaration and definition
Use identical types in declaration and definition
If objects or functions are declared more than once their types shall be compatible
There shall be no definitions of objects or functions in a header file
Always declare functions at file scope
Objects shall be defined at block scope if they are only accessed from within a single function
All automatic variables shall have been assigned a value before being used
The initializer for an aggregate or union shall be enclosed in braces
Arrays shall not be partially initialized
The non-zero initialization of structures requires an explicit initializer for each element
In an enumerator list, the "=" construct shall not be used to explicitly initialise members other than the first, unless all items are explicitly initialised
Sections of code should not be "commented out"
No object or function identifier with static storage duration should be reused
No object or function identifier with static storage duration should be reused
No identifier in one name space should have the same spelling as an identifier in another name space, with the exception of structure and union member names
