No identifier name should be reused
Objects or functions with external linkage shall be declared in a header file
A 'U' suffix shall be applied to all constants of unsigned type
Limited dependence should be placed on C's operator precedence rules in expressions
No parentheses are required for the operand of a unary operator
Limited dependence should be placed on C's operator precedence rules in expressions

category.description: MISRA C 2012 (Legacy)
category.name: MISRA2012

category.description: MISRA C 2012 Rules
category.name: RULE

rule.header: The 'sizeof' operator shall not have an operand which is a function parameter declared as "array of type"
A function shall not be declared implicitly
All exit paths from a function with non-void return type shall have an explicit return statement with an expression
All exit paths from a function, except main(), with non-void return type shall have an explicit return statement with an expression
The declaration of an array parameter shall not contain the 'static' keyword between the [ ]
Pointers to variably-modified array types should not be used
An object shall not be assigned or copied to an overlapping object
An object shall not be assigned or copied to an overlapping object
The pointers returned by the Standard Library functions 'localeconv', 'getenv', 'setlocale' or, 'strerror' shall only be used as if they have pointer to const-qualified type
Strings pointed by members of the structure 'lconv' should not be modified
All arguments to any type-generic macros declared in <tgmath.h> shall have appropriate essential type
Thread objects, thread synchronization objects, and thread-specific storage pointers shall only be accessed by the appropriate Standard Library functions
The second argument passed to the 'mtx_init()' function call should be either 'mtx_plain', 'mtx_timed', 'mtx_plain | mtx_recursive', or 'mtx_timed | mtx_recursive'
A pointer to a FILE object shall not be dereferenced
A pointer to a FILE object shall not be dereferenced by a library function
The argument of an integer-constant macro shall have an appropriate form
An expression of essentially Boolean type should always be used where an operand is interpreted as a Boolean value
An operand of essentially Boolean type should not be used where an operand is interpreted as a numeric value
An operand of essentially character type should not be used where an operand is interpreted as a numeric value
An operand of essentially enum type should not be used in an arithmetic operation
Shift and bitwise operations should not be performed on operands of essentially signed or enum type
An operand of essentially signed or enum type should not be used as right hand side operand to the bitwise shifting operator
An operand of essentially unsigned type should not be used as the operand to the unary minus operator
Floating-point expressions shall not be explicitly (syntactically) tested for equality (==) or inequality (!=)
Expressions of essentially character type shall not be used inappropriately in addition and subtraction operations
The value of an expression shall not be assigned to an object with a narrower essential type
The value of an expression shall not be assigned to an object of a different essential type category
Both operands of an operator in which the usual arithmetic conversions are performed shall have the same essential type category
The second and third operands of the ternary operator shall have the same essential type category
The value of a composite expression shall not be assigned to an object with wider essential type
If a composite expression is used as one operand of an operator in which the usual arithmetic conversions are performed then the other operand shall not have wider essential type
If a composite expression is used as one (second or third) operand of a conditional operator then the other operand shall not have wider essential type
The value of a composite expression shall not be cast to a different essential type category or a wider essential type
The _Atomic qualifier shall not be applied to the incomplete type void
Conversions shall not be performed between a pointer to a function and any other type
Conversions shall not be performed between a pointer to a function and any other type
Conversions shall not be performed between a pointer to an incomplete type and any other type
A cast shall not be performed between a pointer to object type and a pointer to a different object type
A cast shall not be performed between pointer to void and an arithmetic type
A cast shall not be performed between pointer to object and a non-integer arithmetic type
The macro NULL shall be the only permitted form of integer null pointer constant
The macro NULL shall be the only permitted form of integer null pointer constant
Structure and union members of atomic objects shall not be directly accessed
Initializer lists shall not contain persistent side effects
The value of an expression shall be the same under any order of evaluation that the standard permits
Don't write code that depends on the order of evaluation of function arguments
Don't write code that depends on the order of evaluation of function designator and function arguments
Don't write code that depends on the order of evaluation of expression that involves a function call
Between sequence points an object shall have its stored value modified at most once by the evaluation of an expression
Do not use more than one volatile in one expression
Don't write code that depends on the order of evaluation of function calls
The value of an expression with atomic type should be independent from thread interleaving
The right hand operand of a logical && or || operator shall not contain persistent side effects
The operand of the sizeof operator shall not contain any expression which has potential side effects
The operand of the sizeof operator shall not contain any expression which has potential side effects
The operand of the sizeof operator shall not contain any expression which has potential side effects
A loop counter in a 'for' loop shall not have essentially floating type
A loop counter in 'while' and 'do-while' loops shall not have essentially floating type
There shall only be one loop counter in a 'for' loop, which shall not be modified in the 'for' loop body
The first clause of a 'for' loop shall be well-formed
The second clause of a 'for' loop shall be well-formed
The third clause of a 'for' statement shall be well-formed
The controlling expression of an if statement and the controlling expression of an iteration-statement shall have essentially Boolean type
The goto statement shall jump to a label declared later in the same function
Any label referenced by a goto statement shall be declared in the same block, or in any block enclosing the goto statement
The body of an iteration-statement or a selection-statement shall be a compound-statement
The body of an iteration-statement or a selection-statement shall be a compound-statement
All 'if ... else if' constructs shall be terminated with an 'else' statement
A switch statement shall only contain switch labels and switch clauses, and no other code
A switch label shall only be used when the most closely-enclosing compound statement is the body of a switch statement
An unconditional break statement shall terminate every non-empty case clause
An unconditional break statement shall terminate every non-empty default clause
Always provide a default branch for switch statements
A 'default' label shall have a statement or a comment before terminating 'break'
A 'default' label, if it exists, shall appear as either the first or the last switch label of a switch statement
Every switch statement shall have at least two switch-clauses
A switch label shall only be used when the most closely-enclosing compound statement is the body of a switch statement
An unconditional break statement shall terminate every switch-clause
An unconditional break statement shall terminate every switch-clause
Every 'switch' statement shall have a 'default' label
A 'default' label shall have a statement or a comment before terminating 'break'
A default label shall appear as either the first or the last switch label of a switch statement
Every switch statement shall have at least two switch-clauses
A switch-expression shall not have essentially Boolean type
A switch-expression shall not have essentially Boolean type
A function declared with a _Noreturn function specifier shall have void return type
A function type shall not be type qualified
The features of <stdarg.h> shall not be used
The features of <stdarg.h> shall not be used
The standard header file <stdarg.h> shall not be used
Functions shall not call themselves, either directly or indirectly
The function argument corresponding to a parameter declared to have an array type shall have an appropriate number of elements
The value returned by a function having non-void return type shall be used
The value returned by a function having non-void return type shall be used
The address of an object with automatic storage shall not be returned from a function
The address of an object with automatic storage shall not be assigned to another object that may persist after the first object has ceased to exist
The address of an object with thread storage duration shall not be assigned to an object with static storage duration
Flexible array members shall not be declared
Variable-length arrays should not be used
An object shall not be used outside its lifetime
A program should not exceed the translation limits imposed by The Standard (c90)
A program should not exceed the translation limits imposed by The Standard (c99)
A program should not exceed the translation limits imposed by The Standard (c90)
A program should not exceed the translation limits imposed by The Standard (c99)
The value of an expression shall be the same under any order of evaluation that the standard permits
Don't write code that depends on the order of evaluation of function arguments
Don't write code that depends on the order of evaluation of function designator and function arguments
Don't write code that depends on the order of evaluation of expression that involves a function call
Between sequence points an object shall have its stored value modified at most once by the evaluation of an expression
Do not use more than one volatile in one expression
Don't write code that depends on the order of evaluation of function calls
A function shall not return a pointer or reference to a non-static local object
The address of an object with automatic storage shall not be assigned to an object which persists after the object has ceased to exist
The left-hand operand of a right-shift operator shall not have a negative value
The '__STDC_WANT_LIB_EXT1__' macro should not be defined to the value other than '0'
The 'rsize_t' type should not be used
The 'errno_t' type should not be used
Do not use following macros: RSIZE_MAX, L_tmpnam_s, TMP_MAX_S
Do not use the functions defined in Annex K of ISO/IEC 9899:2011 standard
The static storage class specifier shall be used in definitions and declarations of objects and functions that have internal linkage
Storage type modifiers shall be associated with the type, not the variable or the function
Function types shall be in prototype form
Do not use macro ATOMIC_VAR_INIT
Do not use 'bool', 'false' or 'true' identifiers in the #undef directive
A macro parameter immediately following a # operator shall not immediately be followed by a ## operator
A macro parameter used as an operand to the # or ## operators, which is itself subject to further macro replacement, shall only be used as an operand to these operators
A line whose first token is # shall be a valid preprocessing directive
All #else, #elif and #endif preprocessor directives shall reside in the same file as the #if, #ifdef or #ifndef directive to which they are related
The ', & or \ characters and the /* or // character sequences shall not occur in a header file name
The ', & or \ characters and the /* or // character sequences shall not occur in a header file name
The #include directive shall be followed by either a <filename> or "filename" sequence
A macro shall not be defined with the same name as a keyword
A macro shall not be defined with the same name as a keyword
Tokens that look like a preprocessing directive shall not occur within a macro argument
Expressions resulting from the expansion of macro parameters shall be enclosed in parentheses
The controlling expression of a #if or #elif preprocessing directive shall evaluate to 0 or 1
All identifiers used in the controlling expression of #if or #elif preprocessing directives shall be #define'd before evaluation
The standard header file <time.h> shall not be used
The time handling functions and macros of library <time.h> shall not be used
The types defined in the library <time.h> shall not be used
The standard header file <tgmath.h> shall not be used
The features provided by <fenv.h> should not be used
The standard header file <fenv.h> shall not be used
The pointer arguments to the Standard Library functions 'memcmp', 'memmove' and 'memcmp' shall be pointers to qualified or unqualified versions of compatible types

The pointer arguments to the Standard Library function 'memcmp' shall point to either a pointer type, an essentially signed type, an essentially unsigned type, an essentially Boolean type or an essentially enum type
Do not #define or #undef identifiers with names which start with underscore
#define and #undef shall not be used on a reserved identifier or reserved macro name (for C90 code)
#define and #undef shall not be used on a reserved identifier or reserved macro name (for C99 code)
Do not #define nor #undef identifier 'defined'
The library function 'system' of <stdlib.h> shall not be used
All arguments to any multi-argument type-generic macros declared in <tgmath.h> shall have the same standard type
The random number generator functions of <stdlib.h> shall not be used
Only 'memory_order_seq_cst' should be used as an explicit memory order argument
An identifier with name which starts with underscore shall not be declared
A reserved identifier or macro name shall not be declared (for C90 code)
A reserved identifier or macro name shall not be declared (for C99 code)
The memory allocation and deallocation functions of <stdlib.h> shall not be used
The standard header file <setjmp.h> shall not be used
The standard header file <setjmp.h> shall not be used
The standard header file <signal.h> shall not be used
The standard header file <signal.h> shall not be used
The Standard Library input/output functions shall not be used
The atof, atoi, atol and atoll functions of <stdlib.h> shall not be used
The library function 'abort' of <stdlib.h> shall not be used
The library function 'exit' of <stdlib.h> shall not be used
The library functions 'quick_exit' and '_Exit' of <stdlib.h> shall not be used
The library functions bsearch and qsort of <stdlib.h> shall not be used
A generic selection that is not expanded from a macro shall not contain potential side effects in the controlling expression
A generic association shall list an appropriate type
The controlling expression of a generic selection shall have an essential type that matches its standard type
Enumerated types should not be mixed with integer types in generic selections
A default association shall appear as either the first or the last association of a generic selection
There shall be no unreachable code in 'else' block
There shall be no unreachable code after 'return', 'break', 'continue', and 'goto' statements
There shall be no unreachable code in 'if', 'else', 'while', 'for' block
There shall be no unreachable code in 'switch' statement
There shall be no unreachable code in 'for' loop
There shall be no unreachable code after 'if' or 'switch' statement
There shall be no unreachable code after 'if' or 'switch' statement inside 'while'/'for'/'do...while' loop
All non-null statements shall either have at least one side-effect however executed or cause control flow to change
The character sequence /* shall not be used within a C-style comment
The character sequence // shall not be used within a C-style comment
The character sequence /* shall not be used within a C++-style comment
Line-splicing shall not be used in // comments
Octal and hexadecimal escape sequences shall be terminated
External identifiers shall be distinct
Identifiers declared in the file scope and in the same name space shall be distinct (c90)
Identifiers declared in the file scope and in the same name space shall be distinct (c99)
Identifiers declared in the same block scope and name space shall be distinct (c90)
Identifiers declared in the same block scope and name space shall be distinct (c99)
An identifier declared in an inner scope shall not hide an identifier declared in an outer scope
An identifier declared in an inner scope shall not hide an identifier declared in an outer scope
The name of a macro should be distinct from the names of its parameters(c90)
The name of a macro should be distinct from the names of its parameters(c99)
The name of a macro should be distinct from the names of other macros that are currently defined(c90)
The name of a macro should be distinct from the names of other macros that are currently defined(c99)
Identifiers shall be distinct from macro names (c90)
Identifiers shall be distinct from macro names (c99)
Bit-fields shall only be declared with an appropriate type
Single-bit named bit fields shall not be of a signed type
A bit field shall not be declared as a member of a union
Octal constants shall not be used
A 'u' or 'U' suffix shall be applied to all integer constants that are represented in an unsigned type
The lowercase character 'l' shall not be used in a literal suffix
A string literal shall not be assigned to an object unless the object's type is pointer to const-qualified char
An inline function shall be declared with the static storage class
Within an enumerator list, the value of an implicitly-specified enumeration constant shall be unique
The restrict type qualifier shall not be used
All declarations of an object with internal linkage and an explicit alignment specification shall specify the same alignment
Whenever a function is declared or defined, its type shall be explicitly stated
Whenever an object is declared or defined, its type shall be explicitly stated
Identifiers shall be given for all of the parameters in a function prototype declaration
Function types shall have named parameters
Function types shall be in prototype form
If objects or functions are declared more than once their types shall be compatible
The identifiers used in the declaration and definition of a function shall be identical
A compatible declaration shall be visible when an object or function with external linkage is defined
A compatible declaration shall be visible when an object or function with external linkage is defined
An external object or function shall not have more than one non-defining declaration in translation unit
The static storage class specifier shall be used in all declarations of objects and functions that have internal linkage
The initializer for an aggregate or union shall be enclosed in braces
Arrays shall not be partially initialized
An element of an object shall not be initialized more than once
Where designated initializers are used to initialize an array object the size of the array shall be specified explicitly
An initializer using chained designators shall not contain initializers without designators
The cast operation to essentially enumeration type is not allowed
Do not cast from or to essentially Boolean type
Do not use casts between essentially character types and essentially floating types
A conversion should not be performed between a pointer to object and an integer type
A conversion should not be performed from pointer to void into pointer to object
Use parentheses unless all operators in the expression are the same
The operands of a logical && or || shall be primary-expressions
Parenthesis shall be used with 'sizeof' statement
The comma operator should not be used
Integer overflow or underflow in constant expression in '+', '-', '*' operator
Integer overflow or underflow in constant expression in '<<' operator
A full expression containing an increment (++) or decrement (--) operator should have no other potential side effects other than that caused by the increment or decrement operator
The result of an assignment operator should not be used
The goto statement should not be used
There should be no more than one break or goto statement used to terminate any iteration statement
A function should have a single point of exit at the end
A function identifier shall only be used with either a preceding &, or with a parenthesised parameter list
A function parameter should not be modified
The +, -, += and -= operators should not be applied to an expression of pointer type
Declarations should contain no more than two levels of pointer nesting
The union keyword should not be used
#include directives should only be preceded by preprocessor directives or comments
The # and ## preprocessor operators should not be used
#undef should not be used
A generic selection should only be expanded from a macro
A generic selection used in a macro definition should have a macro parameter in the controlling expression
A generic selection should contain at least one non-default association
A generic selection should not depend on implicit pointer type conversion
A generic selection that is expanded from a macro should evaluate its argument only once
A function should not contain unused type declarations
A source file should not contain unused type declarations
A function should not contain unused local tag declarations
A source file should not contain unused tag declarations
A source file should not contain unused macro definitions
A function should not contain unused label declarations
There should be no unused parameters in functions
A project should not contain unused variables with internal linkage
Avoid unused local variables
Trigraphs should not be used
The small integer variants of the minimum-width integer constant macros should not be used
When an array with external linkage is declared, its size should be explicitly specified
A pointer parameter in a function prototype should be declared as pointer to const if the pointer is not used to modify the addressed object
Declare a type of parameter as typedef to pointer to const if the pointer is not used to modify the addressed object
The alignment specification of zero should not appear in an object declaration
At most one explicit alignment specifier should appear in an object declaration
An object should be defined at block scope if its identifier only appears in a single function

category.description: MISRA C 2012 Directives
category.name: DIR

rule.header: Precautions shall be taken in order to prevent the contents of a header file being included more than once
Dynamic memory allocation shall not be used
Assembly language shall be encapsulated and isolated
All usage of assembly language should be documented
Sections of code should not be "commented out"
Identifiers in the same name space with overlapping visibility should be typographically unambiguous
typedefs to basic types should contain some digits in their name
typedefs should be used in place of the basic types
Use typedefs from stdint.h instead of declaring your own in C99 code
If a pointer to a structure or union is never dereferenced within a translation unit, then the implementation of the object should be hidden
A function should be used in preference to a function-like macro where they are interchangeable

category.description: MISRA C 2023 (MISRA C 2012)
category.name: MISRAC2012

category.description: Rule 12.5 (Mandatory) The sizeof operator shall not have an operand which is a function parameter declared as "array of type"
category.name: RULE_12_5

rule.header: The 'sizeof' operator shall not have an operand which is a function parameter declared as "array of type"

category.description: Rule 17.3 (Mandatory) A function shall not be declared implicitly
category.name: RULE_17_3

rule.header: Functions shall always have visible prototype at the function call

category.description: Rule 17.4 (Mandatory) All exit paths from a function with non-void return type shall have an explicit return statement with an expression
category.name: RULE_17_4

rule.header: All exit paths from a function with non-void return type shall have an explicit return statement with an expression
All exit paths from a function, except main(), with non-void return type shall have an explicit return statement with an expression

category.description: Rule 17.6 (Mandatory) The declaration of an array parameter shall not contain the static keyword between the [ ]
category.name: RULE_17_6

rule.header: The declaration of an array parameter shall not contain the 'static' keyword between the [ ]

category.description: Rule 18.10 (Mandatory) Pointers to variably-modified array types shall not be used
category.name: RULE_18_10

rule.header: Pointers to variably-modified array types should not be used

category.description: Rule 19.1 (Mandatory) An object shall not be assigned or copied to an overlapping object
category.name: RULE_19_1

rule.header: An object shall not be assigned to an overlapping object
An object shall not be assigned to an overlapping object

category.description: Rule 21.19 (Mandatory) The pointers returned by the Standard Library functions localeconv, getenv, setlocale or, strerror shall only be used as if they have pointer to const-qualified type
category.name: RULE_21_19

rule.header: The pointers returned by the Standard Library functions 'localeconv', 'getenv', 'setlocale' or, 'strerror' shall only be used as if they have pointer to const-qualified type
Strings pointed by members of the structure 'lconv' should not be modified

category.description: Rule 21.22 (Mandatory) All arguments to any type-generic macros declared in <tgmath.h> shall have appropriate essential type
category.name: RULE_21_22

rule.header: All arguments to any type-generic macros declared in <tgmath.h> shall have appropriate essential type

category.description: Rule 22.12 (Mandatory) Thread objects, thread synchronization objects, and thread-specific storage pointers shall only be accessed by the appropriate Standard Library functions
category.name: RULE_22_12

rule.header: Thread objects, thread synchronization objects, and thread-specific storage pointers shall only be accessed by the appropriate Standard Library functions

category.description: Rule 22.14 (Mandatory) Thread synchronization objects shall be initialized before being accessed
category.name: RULE_22_14

rule.header: The second argument passed to the 'mtx_init()' function call should be either 'mtx_plain', 'mtx_timed', 'mtx_plain | mtx_recursive', or 'mtx_timed | mtx_recursive'

category.description: Rule 22.5 (Mandatory) A pointer to a FILE object shall not be dereferenced
category.name: RULE_22_5

rule.header: A pointer to a FILE object shall not be dereferenced
A pointer to a FILE object shall not be dereferenced by a library function

category.description: Rule 7.5 (Mandatory) The argument of an integer-constant macro shall have an appropriate form
category.name: RULE_7_5

rule.header: Arguments of integer-constant macros should be decimal, octal, or hexadecimal constants with appropriate values

category.description: Dir 4.10 (Required) Precautions shall be taken in order to prevent the contents of a header file being included more than once
category.name: DIR_4_10

rule.header: Use multiple include guards

category.description: Dir 4.12 (Required) Dynamic memory allocation shall not be used
category.name: DIR_4_12

rule.header: Dynamic heap memory allocation shall not be used

category.description: Dir 4.3 (Required) Assembly language shall be encapsulated and isolated
category.name: DIR_4_3

rule.header: Assembly language shall be encapsulated and isolated

category.description: Rule 10.1 (Required) Operands shall not be of an inappropriate essential type
category.name: RULE_10_1

rule.header: An expression of essentially Boolean type should always be used where an operand is interpreted as a Boolean value
An operand of essentially Boolean type should not be used where an operand is interpreted as a numeric value
An operand of essentially character type should not be used where an operand is interpreted as a numeric value
An operand of essentially enum type should not be used in an arithmetic operation
Shift and bitwise operations should not be performed on operands of essentially signed or enum type
An operand of essentially signed or enum type should not be used as the right hand operand to the bitwise shifting operator
An operand of essentially unsigned type should not be used as the operand to the unary minus operator
Floating-point expressions shall not be explicitly (syntactically) tested for equality (==) or inequality (!=)

category.description: Rule 10.2 (Required) Expressions of essentially character type shall not be used inappropriately in addition and subtraction operations
category.name: RULE_10_2

rule.header: Expressions of essentially character type shall not be used inappropriately in addition and subtraction operations

category.description: Rule 10.3 (Required) The value of an expression shall not be assigned to an object with a narrower essential type or of a different essential type category
category.name: RULE_10_3

rule.header: The value of an expression shall not be assigned to an object with a narrower essential type
The value of an expression shall not be assigned to an object of a different essential type category

category.description: Rule 10.4 (Required) Both operands of an operator in which the usual arithmetic conversions are performed shall have the same essential type category
category.name: RULE_10_4

rule.header: Both operands of an operator in which the usual arithmetic conversions are performed shall have the same essential type category
The second and third operands of the ternary operator shall have the same essential type category

category.description: Rule 10.6 (Required) The value of a composite expression shall not be assigned to an object with wider essential type
category.name: RULE_10_6

rule.header: The value of a composite expression shall not be assigned to an object with wider essential type

category.description: Rule 10.7 (Required) If a composite expression is used as one operand of an operator in which the usual arithmetic conversions are performed then the other operand shall not have wider essential type
category.name: RULE_10_7

rule.header: If a composite expression is used as one operand of an operator in which the usual arithmetic conversions are performed then the other operand shall not have wider essential type
If a composite expression is used as one (second or third) operand of a conditional operator then the other operand shall not have wider essential type

category.description: Rule 10.8 (Required) The value of a composite expression shall not be cast to a different essential type category or a wider essential type
category.name: RULE_10_8

rule.header: The value of a composite expression shall not be cast to a different essential type category or a wider essential type

category.description: Rule 11.1 (Required) Conversions shall not be performed between a pointer to a function and any other type
category.name: RULE_11_1

rule.header: Conversions shall not be performed between a pointer to a function and any other type than pointer to function
Conversions shall not be performed between non compatible pointer to a function types

category.description: Rule 11.10 (Required) The _Atomic qualifier shall not be applied to the incomplete type void
category.name: RULE_11_10

rule.header: The '_Atomic' qualifier should not be used with the 'void' type

category.description: Rule 11.2 (Required) Conversions shall not be performed between a pointer to an incomplete type and any other type
category.name: RULE_11_2

rule.header: Conversions shall not be performed between a pointer to an incomplete type and any other type

category.description: Rule 11.3 (Required) A conversion shall not be performed between a pointer to object type and a pointer to a different object type
category.name: RULE_11_3

rule.header: A cast shall not be performed between a pointer to object type and a pointer to a different object type

category.description: Rule 11.6 (Required) A cast shall not be performed between pointer to void and an arithmetic type
category.name: RULE_11_6

rule.header: A cast shall not be performed between pointer to void and an arithmetic type

category.description: Rule 11.7 (Required) A cast shall not be performed between pointer to object and a non-integer arithmetic type
category.name: RULE_11_7

rule.header: A cast shall not be performed between pointer to object and a non-integer arithmetic type

category.description: Rule 11.9 (Required) The macro NULL shall be the only permitted form of integer null pointer constant
category.name: RULE_11_9

rule.header: Literal zero (0) shall not be used as the null-pointer-constant
Use NULL instead of literal zero (0) as the null-pointer-constant

category.description: Rule 12.6 (Required) Structure and union members of atomic objects shall not be directly accessed
category.name: RULE_12_6

rule.header: Members of atomic objects of structure and union types should not be directly accessed

category.description: Rule 13.1 (Required) Initializer lists shall not contain persistent side effects
category.name: RULE_13_1

rule.header: Initializer lists shall not contain persistent side effects

category.description: Rule 13.2 (Required) The value of an expression and its persistent side effects shall be the same under all permitted evaluation orders and shall be independent from thread interleaving
category.name: RULE_13_2

rule.header: The value of an expression shall be the same under any order of evaluation that the standard permits
Don't write code that depends on the order of evaluation of function arguments
Don't write code that depends on the order of evaluation of function designator and function arguments
Don't write code that depends on the order of evaluation of expression that involves a function call
Between sequence points an object shall have its stored value modified at most once by the evaluation of an expression
Do not use more than one volatile between two adjacent sequence points
Don't write code that depends on the order of evaluation of function calls
The value of an expression with atomic type should be independent from thread interleaving

category.description: Rule 13.5 (Required) The right hand operand of a logical && or || operator shall not contain persistent side effects
category.name: RULE_13_5

rule.header: The right-hand operand of a logical && or || operator shall not contain side effects

category.description: Rule 13.6 (Required) The operand of the sizeof operator shall not contain any expression which has potential side effects
category.name: RULE_13_6

rule.header: The operand of the sizeof operator shall not contain any expression which has side effects
Object designated by a volatile lvalue should not be accessed in the operand of the sizeof operator
The function call shall not be the operand of the sizeof operator

category.description: Rule 14.1 (Required) A loop counter shall not have essentially floating type
category.name: RULE_14_1

rule.header: A loop counter in a 'for' loop shall not have essentially floating type
A loop counter in 'while' and 'do-while' loops shall not have essentially floating type

category.description: Rule 14.2 (Required) A for loop shall be well-formed
category.name: RULE_14_2

rule.header: There shall only be one loop counter in a 'for' loop, which shall not be modified in the 'for' loop body
The first clause of a 'for' loop shall be well-formed
The second clause of a 'for' loop shall be well-formed
The third clause of a 'for' statement shall be well-formed

category.description: Rule 14.4 (Required) The controlling expression of an if statement and the controlling expression of an iteration-statement shall have essentially Boolean type
category.name: RULE_14_4

rule.header: Tests of a value against zero should be made explicit, unless the operand is effectively Boolean

category.description: Rule 15.2 (Required) The goto statement shall jump to a label declared later in the same function
category.name: RULE_15_2

rule.header: The goto statement shall jump to a label declared later in the same function body

category.description: Rule 15.3 (Required) Any label referenced by a goto statement shall be declared in the same block, or in any block enclosing the goto statement
category.name: RULE_15_3

rule.header: Any label referenced by a goto statement shall be declared in the same block, or in a block enclosing the goto statement

category.description: Rule 15.6 (Required) The body of an iteration-statement or a selection-statement shall be a compound-statement
category.name: RULE_15_6

rule.header: The statement forming the body of a 'switch', 'while', 'do...while' or 'for' statement shall be a compound statement
'if' and 'else' should be followed by a compound statement

category.description: Rule 15.7 (Required) All if ... else if constructs shall be terminated with an else statement
category.name: RULE_15_7

rule.header: All 'if...else-if' constructs shall be terminated with an 'else' clause

category.description: Rule 16.1 (Required) All switch statements shall be well-formed
category.name: RULE_16_1

rule.header: A switch statement shall only contain switch labels and switch clauses, and no other code
A switch label shall only be used when the most closely-enclosing compound statement is the body of a switch statement
An unconditional break statement shall terminate every non-empty case clause
An unconditional break statement shall terminate every non-empty default clause
Always provide a default branch for switch statements
A 'default' label shall have a statement or a comment before terminating 'break'
A 'default' label, if it exists, shall appear as either the first or the last switch label of a switch statement
Every switch statement shall have at least two switch-clauses

category.description: Rule 16.2 (Required) A switch label shall only be used when the most closely-enclosing compound statement is the body of a switch statement
category.name: RULE_16_2

rule.header: A switch label shall only be used when the most closely-enclosing compound statement is the body of a switch statement

category.description: Rule 16.3 (Required) An unconditional break statement shall terminate every switch-clause
category.name: RULE_16_3

rule.header: An unconditional break statement shall terminate every non-empty case clause
An unconditional break statement shall terminate every non-empty default clause

category.description: Rule 16.4 (Required) Every switch statement shall have a default label
category.name: RULE_16_4

rule.header: Always provide a default branch for switch statements
A 'default' label shall have a statement or a comment before terminating 'break'

category.description: Rule 16.5 (Required) A default label shall appear as either the first or the last switch label of a switch statement
category.name: RULE_16_5

rule.header: A 'default' label, if it exists, shall appear as either the first or the last switch label of a switch statement

category.description: Rule 16.6 (Required) Every switch statement shall have at least two switch-clauses
category.name: RULE_16_6

rule.header: Every switch statement shall have at least two switch-clauses

category.description: Rule 16.7 (Required) A switch-expression shall not have essentially Boolean type
category.name: RULE_16_7

rule.header: A switch expression shall not represent a value that is effectively Boolean
A switch expression shall not represent a value that is effectively Boolean

category.description: Rule 17.1 (Required) The features of <stdarg.h> shall not be used
category.name: RULE_17_1

rule.header: The identifiers va_list, va_arg, va_start, va_end, va_copy should not be used
The identifiers va_list, va_arg, va_start, va_end should not be used
The standard header file <stdarg.h> or <cstdarg> shall not be used

category.description: Rule 17.10 (Required) A function declared with a _Noreturn function specifier shall have void return type
category.name: RULE_17_10

rule.header: Functions declared as 'noreturn' shall have the 'void' return type

category.description: Rule 17.13 (Required) A function type shall not be type qualified
category.name: RULE_17_13

rule.header: Do not include any type qualifiers in the specification of a function type

category.description: Rule 17.2 (Required) Functions shall not call themselves, either directly or indirectly
category.name: RULE_17_2

rule.header: Functions shall not call themselves, either directly or indirectly

category.description: Rule 17.5 (Required) The function argument corresponding to a parameter declared to have an array type shall have an appropriate number of elements
category.name: RULE_17_5

rule.header: The function argument corresponding to a parameter declared to have an array type shall have an appropriate number of elements

category.description: Rule 17.7 (Required) The value returned by a function having non-void return type shall be used
category.name: RULE_17_7

rule.header: The value returned by a function having non-void return type shall be used
The value returned by a function having non-void return type shall be used

category.description: Rule 18.6 (Required) The address of an object with automatic or thread-local storage shall not be copied to another object that persists after the first object has ceased to exist
category.name: RULE_18_6

rule.header: The address of an object with automatic storage shall not be returned from a function
The address of an object with automatic storage shall not be assigned to another object that may persist after the first object has ceased to exist
The address of an object with thread storage duration shall not be assigned to an object with static storage duration

category.description: Rule 18.7 (Required) Flexible array members shall not be declared
category.name: RULE_18_7

rule.header: Flexible array members shall not be declared

category.description: Rule 18.8 (Required) Variable-length arrays shall not be used
category.name: RULE_18_8

rule.header: Variable-length arrays should not be used

category.description: Rule 18.9 (Required) An object with temporary lifetime shall not undergo array-to-pointer conversion
category.name: RULE_18_9

rule.header: Do not modify objects with temporary lifetime

category.description: Rule 1.1 (Required) The program shall contain no violations of the standard C syntax and constraints, and shall not exceed the implementation's translation limits
category.name: RULE_1_1

rule.header: A program should not exceed the translation limits imposed by The Standard (c90)
A program should not exceed the translation limits imposed by The Standard (c99)
A program should not exceed the translation limits imposed by The Standard (c90)
A program should not exceed the translation limits imposed by The Standard (c99)

category.description: Rule 1.3 (Required) There shall be no occurrence of undefined or critical unspecified behaviour
category.name: RULE_1_3

rule.header: The value of an expression shall be the same under any order of evaluation that the standard permits
Don't write code that depends on the order of evaluation of function arguments
Don't write code that depends on the order of evaluation of function designator and function arguments
Don't write code that depends on the order of evaluation of expression that involves a function call
Between sequence points an object shall have its stored value modified at most once by the evaluation of an expression
Do not use more than one volatile between two adjacent sequence points
Don't write code that depends on the order of evaluation of function calls
The address of an object with automatic storage shall not be returned from a function
The address of an object with automatic storage shall not be assigned to another object that may persist after the first object has ceased to exist
The left-hand operand of a right-shift operator shall not have a negative value

category.description: Rule 1.4 (Required) Emergent language features shall not be used
category.name: RULE_1_4

rule.header: The '__STDC_WANT_LIB_EXT1__' macro should not be defined to the value other than '0'
The 'rsize_t' type should not be used
The 'errno_t' type should not be used
Do not use following macros: RSIZE_MAX, L_tmpnam_s, TMP_MAX_S
Do not use the functions defined in Annex K of ISO/IEC 9899:2011 standard

category.description: Rule 1.5 (Required) Obsolescent language features shall not be used
category.name: RULE_1_5

rule.header: The static storage class specifier shall be used in definitions and declarations of objects and functions that have internal linkage
Storage type modifiers shall be associated with the type, not the variable or the function
Function types shall be in prototype form
Do not use the macro ATOMIC_VAR_INIT
Do not use the 'bool', 'false' or 'true' identifiers in the #undef directive

category.description: Rule 20.11 (Required) A macro parameter immediately following a # operator shall not immediately be followed by a ## operator
category.name: RULE_20_11

rule.header: A macro parameter immediately following a # operator shall not immediately be followed by or preceded by a ## operator

category.description: Rule 20.12 (Required) A macro parameter used as an operand to the # or ## operators, which is itself subject to further macro replacement, shall only be used as an operand to these operators
category.name: RULE_20_12

rule.header: A macro parameter used as an operand to the # or ## operators, which is itself subject to further macro replacement, shall only be used as an operand to these operators

category.description: Rule 20.13 (Required) A line whose first token is # shall be a valid preprocessing directive
category.name: RULE_20_13

rule.header: Preprocessing directives shall be syntactically meaningful even when excluded by the preprocessor

category.description: Rule 20.14 (Required) All #else, #elif and #endif preprocessor directives shall reside in the same file as the #if, #ifdef or #ifndef directive to which they are related
category.name: RULE_20_14

rule.header: All #else, #elif and #endif preprocessor directives shall reside in the same file as the #if or #ifdef directive to which they are related

category.description: Rule 20.2 (Required) The ', " or \ characters and the /* or // character sequences shall not occur in a header file name
category.name: RULE_20_2

rule.header: The ', ", /* or // characters shall not occur in a header file name
The \ character should not occur in a header file name

category.description: Rule 20.3 (Required) The #include directive shall be followed by either a <filename> or "filename" sequence
category.name: RULE_20_3

rule.header: The #include directive shall be followed by either a <filename> or "filename" sequence

category.description: Rule 20.4 (Required) A macro shall not be defined with the same name as a keyword
category.name: RULE_20_4

rule.header: A macro shall not be defined with the same name as a keyword in C90
A macro shall not be defined with the same name as a keyword in C99

category.description: Rule 20.6 (Required) Tokens that look like a preprocessing directive shall not occur within a macro argument
category.name: RULE_20_6

rule.header: Arguments to a function-like macro shall not contain tokens that look like preprocessing directives

category.description: Rule 20.7 (Required) Expressions resulting from the expansion of macro parameters shall be enclosed in parentheses
category.name: RULE_20_7

rule.header: In the definition of a function-like macro each instance of a parameter shall be enclosed in parentheses unless it is used as the operand of # or ##

category.description: Rule 20.8 (Required) The controlling expression of a #if or #elif preprocessing directive shall evaluate to 0 or 1
category.name: RULE_20_8

rule.header: The controlling expression of a #if or #elif preprocessing directive shall evaluate to 0 or 1

category.description: Rule 20.9 (Required) All identifiers used in the controlling expression of #if or #elif preprocessing directives shall be #define'd before evaluation
category.name: RULE_20_9

rule.header: Do not use in preprocessor directives #if and #elif macros not defined in translation unit

category.description: Rule 21.1 (Required) #define and #undef shall not be used on a reserved identifier or reserved macro name
category.name: RULE_21_1

rule.header: Do not #define or #undef identifiers with names which start with underscore
Reserved identifiers, macros and functions in the standard library, shall not be defined, redefined or undefined (C90 code)
Reserved identifiers, macros and functions in the standard library, shall not be defined, redefined or undefined (C99 code)
Do not #define nor #undef identifier 'defined'

category.description: Rule 21.10 (Required) The Standard Library time and date functions shall not be used
category.name: RULE_21_10

rule.header: The standard header files <time.h> or <ctime> shall not be used
The time handling functions and macros of the library <time.h> shall not be used
The types defined in the library <time.h> shall not be used

category.description: Rule 21.11 (Required) The standard header file <tgmath.h> shall not be used
category.name: RULE_21_11

rule.header: The standard header file <tgmath.h> shall not be used

category.description: Rule 21.12 (Required) The standard header file <fenv.h> shall not be used
category.name: RULE_21_12

rule.header: The features provided by <fenv.h> should not be used
The standard header file <fenv.h> shall not be used

category.description: Rule 21.15 (Required) The pointer arguments to the Standard Library functions memcpy, memmove and memcmp shall be pointers to qualified or unqualified versions of compatible types
category.name: RULE_21_15

rule.header: The pointer arguments to the Standard Library functions 'memcmp', 'memmove' and 'memcmp' shall be pointers to qualified or unqualified versions of compatible types

category.description: Rule 21.16 (Required) The pointer arguments to the Standard Library function memcmp shall point to either a pointer type, an essentially signed type, an essentially unsigned type, an essentially Boolean type or an essentially enum type
category.name: RULE_21_16

rule.header: The pointer arguments to the Standard Library function 'memcmp' shall point to either a pointer type, an essentially signed type, an essentially unsigned type, an essentially Boolean type or an essentially enum type

category.description: Rule 21.2 (Required) A reserved identifier or macro name shall not be declared
category.name: RULE_21_2

rule.header: The names of standard library macros, objects and functions shall not be reused
The names of standard library macros, objects and functions shall not be reused (C90)
The names of standard library macros, objects and functions shall not be reused (C99)

category.description: Rule 21.21 (Required) The Standard Library function system of <stdlib.h> shall not be used
category.name: RULE_21_21

rule.header: The 'system()' function from the 'stdlib.h' or 'cstdlib' library shall not be used

category.description: Rule 21.23 (Required) All arguments to any multi-argument type-generic macros declared in <tgmath.h> shall have the same standard type
category.name: RULE_21_23

rule.header: All arguments to any multi-argument type-generic macros declared in <tgmath.h> shall have the same standard type

category.description: Rule 21.24 (Required) The random number generator functions of <stdlib.h> shall not be used
category.name: RULE_21_24

rule.header: The random number generator functions 'rand()' and 'srand()' should not be used

category.description: Rule 21.25 (Required) All memory synchronization operations shall be executed in sequentially consistent order
category.name: RULE_21_25

rule.header: Only 'memory_order_seq_cst' should be used as an explicit memory order argument

category.description: Rule 21.3 (Required) The memory allocation and deallocation functions of <stdlib.h> shall not be used
category.name: RULE_21_3

rule.header: Dynamic heap memory allocation shall not be used

category.description: Rule 21.4 (Required) The standard header file <setjmp.h> shall not be used
category.name: RULE_21_4

rule.header: The facilities provided by <setjmp.h> should not be used
The standard header files <setjmp.h> or <csetjmp> shall not be used

category.description: Rule 21.5 (Required) The standard header file <signal.h> shall not be used
category.name: RULE_21_5

rule.header: The standard header files <signal.h> or <csignal> shall not be used
The signal handling facilities of <signal.h> shall not be used

category.description: Rule 21.6 (Required) The Standard Library input/output functions shall not be used
category.name: RULE_21_6

rule.header: The Standard Library input/output functions shall not be used

category.description: Rule 21.7 (Required) The atof, atoi, atol and atoll functions of <stdlib.h> shall not be used
category.name: RULE_21_7

rule.header: The library functions atof, atoi and atol from library stdlib.h shall not be used

category.description: Rule 21.8 (Required) The Standard Library termination functions of <stdlib.h> shall not be used
category.name: RULE_21_8

rule.header: The 'abort()' function from the 'stdlib.h' or 'cstdlib' library shall not be used
The 'exit()' function from the 'stdlib.h' or 'cstdlib' library shall not be used
The 'quick_exit()' and '_Exit()' functions from the 'stdlib.h' or 'cstdlib' library shall not be used

category.description: Rule 21.9 (Required) The library functions bsearch and qsort of <stdlib.h> shall not be used
category.name: RULE_21_9

rule.header: The library functions bsearch and qsort of <stdlib.h> shall not be used

category.description: Rule 23.2 (Required) A generic selection that is not expanded from a macro shall not contain potential side effects in the controlling expression
category.name: RULE_23_2

rule.header: A generic selection that is not expanded from a macro shall not contain potential side effects in the controlling expression

category.description: Rule 23.4 (Required) A generic association shall list an appropriate type
category.name: RULE_23_4

rule.header: A generic association shall list an appropriate type

category.description: Rule 23.6 (Required) The controlling expression of a generic selection shall have an essential type that matches its standard type
category.name: RULE_23_6

rule.header: The controlling expression of a generic selection shall have an essential type that matches its standard type
Enumerated types should not be mixed with integer types in generic selections

category.description: Rule 23.8 (Required) A default association shall appear as either the first or the last association of a generic selection
category.name: RULE_23_8

rule.header: The default association shall be placed first or last in the association list

category.description: Rule 2.1 (Required) A project shall not contain unreachable code
category.name: RULE_2_1

rule.header: There shall be no unreachable code in "else" block
There shall be no unreachable code after 'return', 'break', 'continue', and 'goto' statements
There shall be no unreachable code in "if/else/while/for" block
There shall be no unreachable code in switch statement
There shall be no unreachable code in 'for' loop
There shall be no unreachable code after 'if' or 'switch' statement
There shall be no unreachable code after "if" or "switch" statement inside while/for/do...while loop

category.description: Rule 2.2 (Required) A project shall not contain dead code
category.name: RULE_2_2

rule.header: All non-null statements shall either have at least one side-effect however executed or cause control flow to change

category.description: Rule 3.1 (Required) The character sequences /* and // shall not be used within a comment
category.name: RULE_3_1

rule.header: The character sequence /* shall not be used within a C-style comment
The character sequence // shall not be used within a C-style comment
The character sequence /* shall not be used within a C++-style comment

category.description: Rule 3.2 (Required) Line-splicing shall not be used in // comments
category.name: RULE_3_2

rule.header: Line-splicing shall not be used in // comments

category.description: Rule 4.1 (Required) Octal and hexadecimal escape sequences shall be terminated
category.name: RULE_4_1

rule.header: Octal and hexadecimal escape sequences shall be terminated

category.description: Rule 5.1 (Required) External identifiers shall be distinct
category.name: RULE_5_1

rule.header: External identifiers shall be distinct

category.description: Rule 5.2 (Required) Identifiers declared in the same scope and name space shall be distinct
category.name: RULE_5_2

rule.header: Identifiers declared in the file scope and in the same name space shall be distinct (c90)
Identifiers declared in the file scope and in the same name space shall be distinct (c99)
Identifiers declared in the same block scope and name space shall be distinct (c90)
Identifiers declared in the same block scope and name space shall be distinct (c99)

category.description: Rule 5.3 (Required) An identifier declared in an inner scope shall not hide an identifier declared in an outer scope
category.name: RULE_5_3

rule.header: Identifier declared in a local or function prototype scope shall not hide an identifier declared in a global or namespace scope
Identifiers declared in an inner local scope should not hide identifiers declared in an outer local scope

category.description: Rule 5.4 (Required) Macro identifiers shall be distinct
category.name: RULE_5_4

rule.header: The name of a macro should be distinct from the names of its parameters(c90)
The name of a macro should be distinct from the names of its parameters(c99)
The name of a macro should be distinct from the names of other macros that are currently defined(c90)
The name of a macro should be distinct from the names of other macros that are currently defined(c99)

category.description: Rule 5.5 (Required) Identifiers shall be distinct from macro names
category.name: RULE_5_5

rule.header: The names of macros that exist prior to preprocessing should be distinct from the identifiers that exist after preprocessing (c90)
The names of macros that exist prior to preprocessing should be distinct from the identifiers that exist after preprocessing (c99)

category.description: Rule 6.1 (Required) Bit-fields shall only be declared with an appropriate type
category.name: RULE_6_1

rule.header: Bit fields shall only be defined to be of type unsigned int or signed int

category.description: Rule 6.2 (Required) Single-bit named bit fields shall not be of a signed type
category.name: RULE_6_2

rule.header: Named bit-fields with signed integer type shall have a length of more than one bit

category.description: Rule 6.3 (Required) A bit field shall not be declared as a member of a union
category.name: RULE_6_3

rule.header: A member of a union shall not be declared as a bit-field

category.description: Rule 7.1 (Required) Octal constants shall not be used
category.name: RULE_7_1

rule.header: Octal constants (other than zero) shall not be used

category.description: Rule 7.2 (Required) A "u" or "U" suffix shall be applied to all integer constants that are represented in an unsigned type
category.name: RULE_7_2

rule.header: A 'U' suffix shall be applied to all constants of unsigned type

category.description: Rule 7.3 (Required) The lowercase character "l" shall not be used in a literal suffix
category.name: RULE_7_3

rule.header: Use capital 'L' instead of lowercase 'l' to indicate long

category.description: Rule 7.4 (Required) A string literal shall not be assigned to an object unless the object's type is "pointer to const-qualified char"
category.name: RULE_7_4

rule.header: A string literal shall not be modified

category.description: Rule 7.6 (Required) The small integer variants of the minimum-width integer constant macros shall not be used
category.name: RULE_7_6

rule.header: The small integer variants of the minimum-width integer constant macros should not be used

category.description: Rule 8.1 (Required) Types shall be explicitly specified
category.name: RULE_8_1

rule.header: Whenever a function is declared or defined, its type shall be explicitly stated
Whenever an object is declared or defined, its type shall be explicitly stated

category.description: Rule 8.10 (Required) An inline function shall be declared with the static storage class
category.name: RULE_8_10

rule.header: An inline function shall be declared with the static storage class

category.description: Rule 8.12 (Required) Within an enumerator list, the value of an implicitly-specified enumeration constant shall be unique
category.name: RULE_8_12

rule.header: Within an enumerator list, the value of an implicitly-specified enumeration constant shall be unique

category.description: Rule 8.14 (Required) The restrict type qualifier shall not be used
category.name: RULE_8_14

rule.header: The restrict type qualifier shall not be used

category.description: Rule 8.15 (Required) All declarations of an object with an explicit alignment specification shall specify the same alignment
category.name: RULE_8_15

rule.header: Explicit alignment specifiers in all declarations of an object with internal linkage shall be the same

category.description: Rule 8.2 (Required) Function types shall be in prototype form with named parameters
category.name: RULE_8_2

rule.header: Identifiers shall be given for all of the parameters in a function prototype declaration
Function types shall have named parameters
Function types shall be in prototype form

category.description: Rule 8.3 (Required) All declarations of an object or function shall use the same names and type qualifiers
category.name: RULE_8_3

rule.header: If objects or functions are declared more than once their types shall be compatible
The identifiers used in the declaration and definition of a function shall be identical

category.description: Rule 8.4 (Required) A compatible declaration shall be visible when an object or function with external linkage is defined
category.name: RULE_8_4

rule.header: A declaration shall be visible when an object or function with external linkage is defined
If objects or functions are declared more than once their types shall be compatible

category.description: Rule 8.5 (Required) An external object or function shall be declared once in one and only one file
category.name: RULE_8_5

rule.header: An external object or function shall not have more than one non-defining declaration in translation unit

category.description: Rule 8.8 (Required) The static storage class specifier shall be used in all declarations of objects and functions that have internal linkage
category.name: RULE_8_8

rule.header: The static storage class specifier shall be used in definitions and declarations of objects and functions that have internal linkage

category.description: Rule 9.2 (Required) The initializer for an aggregate or union shall be enclosed in braces
category.name: RULE_9_2

rule.header: The initializer for an aggregate or union shall be enclosed in braces

category.description: Rule 9.3 (Required) Arrays shall not be partially initialized
category.name: RULE_9_3

rule.header: Arrays shall not be partially initialized

category.description: Rule 9.4 (Required) An element of an object shall not be initialized more than once
category.name: RULE_9_4

rule.header: An element of an object shall not be initialized more than once

category.description: Rule 9.5 (Required) Where designated initializers are used to initialize an array object the size of the array shall be specified explicitly
category.name: RULE_9_5

rule.header: Where designated initializers are used to initialize an array object the size of the array shall be specified explicitly

category.description: Rule 9.6 (Required) An initializer using chained designators shall not contain initializers without designators
category.name: RULE_9_6

rule.header: An initializer using chained designators shall not contain initializers without designators

category.description: Dir 4.2 (Advisory) All usage of assembly language should be documented
category.name: DIR_4_2

rule.header: All usage of assembler shall be documented

category.description: Dir 4.4 (Advisory) Sections of code should not be "commented out"
category.name: DIR_4_4

rule.header: Sections of code should not be "commented out"

category.description: Dir 4.5 (Advisory) Identifiers in the same name space with overlapping visibility should be typographically unambiguous
category.name: DIR_4_5

rule.header: Identifiers in the same name space with overlapping visibility should be typographically unambiguous

category.description: Dir 4.6 (Advisory) typedefs that indicate size and signedness should be used in place of the basic numerical types
category.name: DIR_4_6

rule.header: typedefs to basic types should contain some digits in their name
typedefs should be used in place of the basic types
Use typedefs from stdint.h instead of declaring your own in C99 code

category.description: Dir 4.8 (Advisory) If a pointer to a structure or union is never dereferenced within a translation unit, then the implementation of the object should be hidden
category.name: DIR_4_8

rule.header: If a pointer to a structure or union is never dereferenced within a translation unit, then the implementation of the object should be hidden

category.description: Dir 4.9 (Advisory) A function should be used in preference to a function-like macro where they are interchangeable
category.name: DIR_4_9

rule.header: A function should be used in preference to a function-like macro

category.description: Rule 10.5 (Advisory) The value of an expression should not be cast to an inappropriate essential type
category.name: RULE_10_5

rule.header: The cast operation to essentially enumeration type is not allowed
Do not cast from or to essentially Boolean type
Do not use casts between essentially character types and essentially floating types

category.description: Rule 11.4 (Advisory) A conversion should not be performed between a pointer to object and an integer type
category.name: RULE_11_4

rule.header: A conversion should not be performed between a pointer to object and an integer type

category.description: Rule 11.5 (Advisory) A conversion should not be performed from pointer to void into pointer to object
category.name: RULE_11_5

rule.header: A conversion should not be performed from pointer to void into pointer to object

category.description: Rule 12.1 (Advisory) The precedence of operators within expressions should be made explicit
category.name: RULE_12_1

rule.header: Use parentheses unless all operators in the expression are the same
The operands of a logical && or || shall be primary-expressions
The operand of the 'sizeof' operator should be enclosed in parentheses

category.description: Rule 12.3 (Advisory) The comma operator should not be used
category.name: RULE_12_3

rule.header: The comma operator shall not be used

category.description: Rule 12.4 (Advisory) Evaluation of constant expressions should not lead to unsigned integer wrap-around
category.name: RULE_12_4

rule.header: Integer overflow or underflow in constant expression in '+', '-', '*' operator
Integer overflow or underflow in constant expression in '<<' operator

category.description: Rule 13.3 (Advisory) A full expression containing an increment (++) or decrement (--) operator should have no other potential side effects other than that caused by the increment or decrement operator
category.name: RULE_13_3

rule.header: A full expression containing an increment (++) or decrement (--) operator should have no other potential side effects

category.description: Rule 13.4 (Advisory) The result of an assignment operator should not be used
category.name: RULE_13_4

rule.header: The result of a built-in assignment operator should not be used

category.description: Rule 15.1 (Advisory) The goto statement should not be used
category.name: RULE_15_1

rule.header: The goto statement shall not be used

category.description: Rule 15.4 (Advisory) There should be no more than one break or goto statement used to terminate any iteration statement
category.name: RULE_15_4

rule.header: For any iteration statement there shall be no more than one break or goto statement used for loop termination

category.description: Rule 15.5 (Advisory) A function should have a single point of exit at the end
category.name: RULE_15_5

rule.header: A function shall have a single point of exit at the end of the function

category.description: Rule 17.12 (Advisory) A function identifier should only be used with either a preceding &, or with a parenthesised parameter list
category.name: RULE_17_12

rule.header: A function identifier shall only be used with either a preceding '&', or with a parenthesised parameter list, which may be empty

category.description: Rule 17.8 (Advisory) A function parameter should not be modified
category.name: RULE_17_8

rule.header: A function parameter should not be modified

category.description: Rule 18.4 (Advisory) The +, -, += and -= operators should not be applied to an expression of pointer type
category.name: RULE_18_4

rule.header: The +, -, += and -= operators should not be applied to an expression of pointer type

category.description: Rule 18.5 (Advisory) Declarations should contain no more than two levels of pointer nesting
category.name: RULE_18_5

rule.header: The declaration of objects should contain no more than 2 levels of pointer indirection

category.description: Rule 19.2 (Advisory) The union keyword should not be used
category.name: RULE_19_2

rule.header: The union keyword should not be used

category.description: Rule 20.1 (Advisory) #include directives should only be preceded by preprocessor directives or comments
category.name: RULE_20_1

rule.header: #include statements in a file should only be preceded by other preprocessor directives or comments

category.description: Rule 20.10 (Advisory) The # and ## preprocessor operators should not be used
category.name: RULE_20_10

rule.header: The # and ## preprocessor operators should not be used

category.description: Rule 20.5 (Advisory) #undef should not be used
category.name: RULE_20_5

rule.header: #undef shall not be used

category.description: Rule 23.1 (Advisory) A generic selection should only be expanded from a macro
category.name: RULE_23_1

rule.header: A generic selection should only be expanded from a macro
A generic selection used in a macro definition should have a macro parameter in the controlling expression

category.description: Rule 23.3 (Advisory) A generic selection should contain at least one non-default association
category.name: RULE_23_3

rule.header: A generic selection shall indicate at least one non-default association

category.description: Rule 23.5 (Advisory) A generic selection should not depend on implicit pointer type conversion
category.name: RULE_23_5

rule.header: A generic selection should not depend on implicit pointer type conversion

category.description: Rule 23.7 (Advisory) A generic selection that is expanded from a macro should evaluate its argument only once
category.name: RULE_23_7

rule.header: A generic selection that is expanded from a macro shall evaluate its argument only once

category.description: Rule 2.3 (Advisory) A project should not contain unused type declarations
category.name: RULE_2_3

rule.header: A function should not contain unused type declarations
A source file should not contain unused type declarations

category.description: Rule 2.4 (Advisory) A project should not contain unused tag declarations
category.name: RULE_2_4

rule.header: A function should not contain unused local tag declarations
A source file should not contain unused tag declarations

category.description: Rule 2.5 (Advisory) A project should not contain unused macro definitions
category.name: RULE_2_5

rule.header: A source file should not contain unused macro definitions

category.description: Rule 2.6 (Advisory) A function should not contain unused label declarations
category.name: RULE_2_6

rule.header: A function should not contain unused label declarations

category.description: Rule 2.7 (Advisory) A function should not contain unused parameters
category.name: RULE_2_7

rule.header: There should be no unused parameters in functions

category.description: Rule 2.8 (Advisory) A project should not contain unused object definitions
category.name: RULE_2_8

rule.header: A project should not contain unused variables with internal linkage
Avoid unused local variables

category.description: Rule 4.2 (Advisory) Trigraphs should not be used
category.name: RULE_4_2

rule.header: Trigraphs shall not be used

category.description: Rule 8.11 (Advisory) When an array with external linkage is declared, its size should be explicitly specified
category.name: RULE_8_11

rule.header: When an array is declared with external linkage, its size shall be stated explicitly or defined implicitly by initialisation

category.description: Rule 8.13 (Advisory) A pointer should point to a const-qualified type whenever possible
category.name: RULE_8_13

rule.header: A pointer parameter in a function prototype should be declared as pointer to const if the pointer is not used to modify the addressed object
Declare a type of parameter as typedef to pointer to const if the pointer is not used to modify the addressed object

category.description: Rule 8.16 (Advisory) The alignment specification of zero should not appear in an object declaration
category.name: RULE_8_16

rule.header: The zero-alignment specifier should not be used in an object declaration

category.description: Rule 8.17 (Advisory) At most one explicit alignment specifier should appear in an object declaration
category.name: RULE_8_17

rule.header: A declaration of an object should contain at most one explicit alignment specifier

category.description: Rule 8.9 (Advisory) An object should be declared at block scope if its identifier only appears in a single function
category.name: RULE_8_9

rule.header: Objects shall be defined at block scope if they are only accessed from within a single function

category.description: Memory and Resource Management
category.name: MRM

rule.header: Do not allocate resources in function argument list because the order of evaluation of a function's parameters is undefined
Use the same form in corresponding calls to new/malloc and delete/free
Do not invoke malloc/realloc for objects having constructors
Avoid hiding the global new
Declare a copy assignment operator for classes with dynamically allocated memory
Declare a copy constructor for classes with dynamically allocated memory
Never return a dereferenced local pointer initialized by new in this function scope
Call delete on pointer members in destructors
Provide error handling for file opening errors right next to the call to fopen
A copy constructor shall copy all data members and bases
Call fclose() on pointer member in destructor if the pointer was used to open a file
An assignment operator shall assign all data bases
Do not pass a pointer that has insufficient storage capacity or that is not suitably aligned for the object being constructed to placement 'new'
Do not allocate more than one resource in a single statement
All classes should contain the assignment operator or appropriate comment
All classes should contain the copy constructor or appropriate comment
Don't memcpy or memcmp non-PODs
Always assign a new value to an expression that points to deallocated memory
Always assign a new value to global or member variable that points to deallocated memory
Always assign a new value to parameter or local variable that points to deallocated memory
Adhere to convention when writing new and delete
Adhere to convention when writing new
If a class defines any overload of operator new, it should provide overloads of all three of plain, in-place, and non-throwing operator new
If a class defines any overload of operator new[], it should provide overloads of all three of plain, in-place, and non-throwing operator new[]
If a class defines any overload of operator delete, it should provide overloads of all three of plain, in-place, and non-throwing operator delete
If a class defines any overload of operator delete[], it should provide overloads of all three of plain, in-place, and non-throwing operator delete[]
Do not allocate memory and expect that someone else will deallocate it later
Do not allocate memory and expect that someone else will deallocate it later
Do not allocate memory and expect that someone else will deallocate it later
Use objects to manage resources
Use objects to manage resources
Store newed objects in smart pointers in standalone statements
Write operator delete if you write operator new
Write operator delete[] if you write operator new[]
Always provide new and delete together
Always provide new[] and delete[] together
Use allocation by declaration rather than by new or malloc
Freed memory shouldn't be accessed under any circumstances
Destructor should not be called manually
Check the return value of new
Never provide brackets ([]) for delete when deallocating non-arrays
Always provide empty brackets ([]) for delete when deallocating arrays
Copy and destroy consistently
A copy assignment operator should be declared when a copy constructor is declared (and vice versa)
Both the copy constructor and copy assignment operator should have the same public/protected/private permission
If you have a non-trivial copy constructor or copy assignment operator, you should also declare a destructor
Both copy constructor and copy assignment operator should be declared for classes with a nontrivial destructor
Do not use sizeof operator on pointer type to specify the size of the memory to be allocated via 'malloc', 'calloc' or 'realloc' function
Do not use calloc, malloc, realloc and free functions
Classes containing at least one non-static member variable should declare the assignment operator or contain appropriate comment
Classes containing at least one non-static member variable should declare the copy constructor or contain appropriate comment
A copy constructor and a copy assignment operator shall be declared for classes that contain pointers to data items or nontrivial destructors
Do not use 'delete' on pointers to a void type
The user defined 'new' operator should throw the 'std::bad_alloc' exception when the allocation fails
Avoid using the default operator 'new' for over-aligned types
An overhead should be used when an array of objects is passed to the placement 'new' allocation function
Copy assignment operators should not have side effects that could affect copying the object
Move assignment operators should not have side effects that could affect moving the object
The result of the memory allocation function should be cast immediately
