category.description: Rule 0110 (Required) The body of an iteration-statement or a selection-statement shall be a compound-statement

rule.header: The statement forming the body of a 'switch', 'while', 'do...while' or 'for' statement shall be a compound statement
'if' and 'else' should be followed by a compound statement

category.description: Rule 0125 (Required) A goto statement shall reference a label declared in the same block or in an enclosing block

rule.header: Any label referenced by a goto statement shall be declared in the same block, or in a block enclosing the goto statement

category.description: Rule 0133 (Required) The only declarations in the global namespace shall be main, namespace declarations and extern "C" declarations

rule.header: The global namespace shall only contain main() and namespace declarations

category.description: Rule 0134 (Required) The identifier main shall not be used for a function other than the global function main

rule.header: The identifier main shall not be used for a function other than the global function main

category.description: Rule 0143 (Required) The address of an object with automatic storage shall not be assigned to an object with a greater lifetime

rule.header: The address of an object with automatic storage shall not be assigned to another object that may persist after the first object has ceased to exist
The lambda that captures local objects by reference should not be assigned to the variable with a greater lifetime

category.description: Rule 0147 (Required) Parameters in an overriding virtual function shall not introduce different default arguments

rule.header: Do not redefine an inherited virtual function with a different default parameter value

category.description: Rule 0148 (Required) The features of "<cstdarg>" shall not be used

rule.header: The identifiers va_list, va_arg, va_start, va_end, va_copy should not be used

category.description: Rule 0150 (Required) A function with non-void return type shall return a value on all paths

rule.header: All exit paths from a function with non-void return type shall have an explicit return statement with an expression

category.description: Rule 0158 (Required) The union keyword shall not be used

rule.header: Unions shall not be used

category.description: Rule 0162 (Required) Named bit-fields with signed integer type shall not have a length of one bit

rule.header: Named bit-fields with signed integer type shall have a length of more than one bit

category.description: Rule 0163 (Required) Classes shall not be derived from virtual bases

rule.header: Classes should not be derived from virtual bases

category.description: Rule 0165 (Required) An accessible base class shall not be both virtual and non-virtual in the same hierarchy

rule.header: A base class shall not be both virtual and non-virtual in the same hierarchy

category.description: Rule 0173 (Required) Conversion operators and constructors that are callable with a single argument shall be explicit

rule.header: Constructors allowing for conversion should be made explicit
User-conversion cast operators should be made explicit

category.description: Rule 0187 (Required) An exception object shall not have pointer type

rule.header: An exception object should not have pointer type

category.description: Rule 0207 (Required) Precautions shall be taken in order to prevent the contents of a header file being included more than once

rule.header: Use multiple include guards

category.description: Rule 0208 (Required) The "'", """ or "\" characters and the "/*" or "//" character sequences shall not occur in a header file name

rule.header: Non-standard characters should not occur in header file names in #include directives

category.description: Rule 0210 (Required) The #include directive shall be followed by either a "<filename>" or ""filename"" sequence

rule.header: The #include directive shall be followed by either a <filename> or "filename" sequence

category.description: Rule 0239 (Required) A comparison of a potentially virtual pointer to member shall only be with "nullptr"

rule.header: A pointer to member virtual function shall only be tested for equality with null-pointer-constant

category.description: Rule 0320 (Required) Octal and hexadecimal escape sequences shall be terminated

rule.header: Octal and hexadecimal escape sequences shall be terminated

category.description: Rule 0324 (Required) A pointer to an incomplete class type shall not be deleted

rule.header: Do not delete objects with incomplete class at the point of deletion

category.description: Rule 0343 (Required) Member function declarations shall use the virtual, override and final specifiers appropriately

rule.header: Each overriding virtual function shall be declared with the override or final specifier
Only one of virtual, override or final should be specified in a member function declaration

category.description: Rule 0370 (Required) A macro parameter used as an operand to the "#" or "##" operators, which is itself subject to further macro replacement, shall only be used as an operand to these operators

rule.header: A macro parameter used as an operand to the # or ## operators, which is itself subject to further macro replacement, shall only be used as an operand to these operators

category.description: Rule 0023 (Advisory) Trigraph-like sequences should not be used

rule.header: Trigraphs shall not be used

category.description: Rule 0039 (Advisory) #include directives should only be preceded by preprocessor directives or comments

rule.header: #include statements in a file should only be preceded by other preprocessor directives or comments

category.description: Rule 0049 (Advisory) When an array with external linkage is declared, its size should be explicitly specified

rule.header: When an array is declared with external linkage, its size shall be stated explicitly or defined implicitly by initialisation

category.description: Rule 0105 (Advisory) The comma operator should not be used

rule.header: The comma operator shall not be used

category.description: Rule 0135 (Advisory) There shall be no unnamed namespaces in header files

rule.header: There shall be no unnamed namespaces in header files

category.description: Rule 0146 (Advisory) A declaration shall not declare more than one variable or member variable

rule.header: Each variable should be declared in a separate declaration statement

category.description: Rule 0159 (Advisory) Bit fields should not be declared

rule.header: Do not declare member variables as bit-fields

category.description: Rule 0212 (Advisory) The "#" and "##" preprocessor operators should not be used

rule.header: The # and ## preprocessor operators should not be used

category.description: Naming Conventions
category.name: NAMING

rule.header: Identifiers for constant and enumerator values shall be lowercase
All "#define" constants shall be in uppercase
In an enumerated list, list members (elements) shall be in uppercase and names or tags for the list shall be in lowercase
Use lowercase for file names
Global prefixes should only be used for global variables
Begin local variable names with a lowercase letters
Begin global variable names with a lowercase letters
Begin member variable names with a lowercase letters
Begin all boolean type variables with 'b'
Begin class, struct, union, enum, and typedef names with an uppercase letter
The names of abstract data types, structures, typedefs, and enumerated types are to begin with an uppercase letter
The name of enumeration type shall begin with an uppercase letter and contain a suffix '_t' at the end
The names of structures shall begin with an uppercase letter and contain a suffix '_t' at the end
Begin constant variables with 'c'
Begin class data member names with 'its'
Begin all double type variable with 'd'
Begin all float type variables with 'f'
Begin all function names with uppercase letter
Begin global variable names with 'the'
Begin all integer type variable with 'i'
Functions that begin with 'is' should return boolean values
Begin all long integer variables with 'li'
Prefix a variable type 'pointer' with a 'p' character
Begin all short integer variables with 'si'
Begin all signed character variables with 'c'
Begin all terminated characters string variables with 'sz'
Begin all unsigned character type variables with 'uc'
Begin all unsigned integer type variables with 'ui'
Use lowercase letters for structure and union member names
Append names of non-scalar typedefs with "_t"
Implementation files in C always have the file name extension ".c"
Do not use typenames that differ only by the use of uppercase and lowercase letters
An include file for a class should have a file name of the form <class name> + extension
Do not use identifiers which begin with one or two underscores (`_' or `__')
Global function names should start with lowercase
Member function names should start with lowercase
Names of parameters in declaration and definition should be identical
Include files in C++ always have the file name extension '.hh'
Implementation files in C++ always have the file name extension ".cc"
Inline definition files always have the file name extension ".icc"
Only the first word of the name of a class, structure, namespace, enumeration, or typedef will begin with an uppercase letter
Header files will always have a file name extension of '.h'
File name extension, if present, should be "*.cpp" or "*.h"
All letters contained in function and variable names will be composed entirely of lowercase letters
Identifiers will not differ by mixture of case, the underscore character, interchange of the similarly looking letters and numbers
The ', ", /* or // characters shall not occur in a header file name
Different identifiers shall be typographically unambiguous
The \ character should not occur in a header file name
User defined suffixes of the user defined literal operators shall start with underscore followed by one or more letters
Universal character names shall be used only inside character or string literals
Header files should have a file extension of: ".h", ".hpp" or ".hxx"
Use visually distinct identifiers

category.description: Hungarian Notation
category.name: HN

rule.header: Hungarian notation for array variables and parameters
Hungarian notation for bool types
Hungarian notation for bool pointer, array, or reference types
Hungarian notation for byte types
Hungarian notation for byte pointer, array, or reference types
Hungarian notation for char types
Hungarian notation for array of char types
Hungarian notation for pointer, array, or reference to array of char types
Hungarian notation for char pointer, array, or reference types
Hungarian notation for char pointer or reference types
Hungarian notation for constant parameters
Hungarian notation for double-precision floating point types
Hungarian notation for double-precision floating point pointer, array, or reference types
Hungarian notation for dword types
Hungarian notation for dword pointer, array, or reference types
Hungarian notation for dynamically allocated array
Hungarian notation for floating point types
Hungarian notation for floating point pointer, array, or reference types
Hungarian notation for class declaration
Hungarian notation for structs declaration
Hungarian notation for ifstream type variables and parameters
Hungarian notation for int types
Hungarian notation for int pointer, array, or reference types
Hungarian notation for istream type parameters and variables
Hungarian notation for long int types
Hungarian notation for long double-precision floating point types
Hungarian notation for long double-precision floating point pointer, array, or reference types
Hungarian notation for long int pointer, array, or reference types
Hungarian notation for member variables
Hungarian notation for int types
Hungarian notation for int pointer, array, or reference types
Hungarian notation for ofstream type parameters and variables
Hungarian notation for ostream type parameters and variables
Hungarian notation for pointer
Hungarian notation for reference parameters
Hungarian notation for short int types
Hungarian notation for short int pointer, array, or reference types
Hungarian notation for static variables
Hungarian notation for string types
Hungarian notation for string pointer, array, or reference types
Hungarian notation for unsigned types
Hungarian notation for void pointer types
Hungarian notation for word types
Hungarian notation for word pointer, array, or reference types
Implementation files in C++ will always have a file name extension of ".cpp"
Identifiers in the same name space with overlapping visibility should be typographically unambiguous
Eliminate unused parameters
Variables will not be introduced until they can be initialized with meaningful values
Declare variables as locally as possible
Prefer canonical form of ++ and --. Prefer calling the prefix forms
Avoid unused private member variables
Prefer "a @= b" than "a = a @ b", where "@" is +, -, *, /, %
Prefer "a @= b" than "a = a @ b", where "@" is &, |, ^, <<, >>
Do not declare variables in "if", "for", "while", and "do while" statement
If a file-level static variable is used/referenced in one function only then include that variable in the function itself
If a file-level static variable is used/referenced in one class only then include that variable in the class itself
Declare member variables in the descending size order
Pass objects by reference instead of by value
Consider overloading to avoid implicit type conversions
Global function containing recursion, loops or virtual function call should not be inlined
Avoid inline constructors and destructors
Member function containing recursion or loops should not be inlined
Consider using op= instead of stand-alone op
Postpone variable definitions as long as possible
Every switch statement shall have at least one non-empty case clause
Useless case statement shall not be permitted
'strlen' function should not be used to check string against NULL/non-NULL
Every defined function with internal linkage shall be used at least once
There shall be no unused parameters (named or unnamed) in non-virtual functions
All non-empty functions with void return type shall have external side effect(s)
Do not assign a variable to itself
Do not use a variable inside its own initializer
Every switch statement shall have at least two switch-clauses
There shall be no unused named parameters in virtual functions
Avoid unused local variables
Avoid unnecessary local variables
Trivial accessor and mutator functions should be inlined
Trivial forwarding functions should be inlined
Only functions with 1 or 2 statements should be considered candidates for inline functions
The number of accessor and mutator functions should be minimized
Redundant explicit cast to the same type is not allowed
Functions with void return type shall not be empty
A function should not contain unused label declarations
There should be no unused parameters in functions
The same code (after preprocessing) in two branches of if-else-if chain
The same code (after preprocessing) in different clauses of switch statement
A file should directly include only the headers that contain declarations and definitions required to compile that file
A project should not contain unused variables with internal linkage
Remove unnecessary '== true'
Consider returning object by reference instead of by value

category.description: OWASP Top 10 Most Critical Web Application Security Risks (2017)
category.name: OWASP2017

category.description: OWASP A10 Insufficient Logging&Monitoring
category.name: A10

rule.header: All exceptions should be rethrown or logged with standard logger

category.description: OWASP A2 Broken Authentication
category.name: A2

rule.header: Do not use weak encryption functions

category.description: OWASP A5 Broken Access Control
category.name: A5

rule.header: Observe correct revocation order while relinquishing privileges
Ensure that privilege relinquishment is successful

category.description: OWASP A6 Security Misconfiguration
category.name: A6

rule.header: Where multiple handlers are provided in a single try-catch statement or function-try-block for a derived class and some or all of its bases, the handlers shall be ordered most-derived to base class
Do not leave 'catch' blocks empty

category.description: OWASP API Security Top 10 (2019)
category.name: OWASP2019

category.description: OWASP API10 Insufficient Logging & Monitoring
category.name: API10

rule.header: All exceptions should be rethrown or logged with standard logger
Do not use 'syslog' function for logging purposes

category.description: OWASP API2 Broken User Authentication
category.name: API2

rule.header: Do not use weak encryption functions

category.description: OWASP API3 Excessive Data Exposure
category.name: API3

rule.header: Do not print potentially sensitive information, resulting from an application error into exception messages
Avoid functions which use time from MFC library
A pointer to a structure should not be passed to a function that can copy data to the user space
Usage of system properties (environment variables) should be restricted

category.description: OWASP API8 Injection
category.name: API8

rule.header: Use care to ensure that LoadLibrary() will load the correct library
Avoid passing dynamically created strings into exec
Avoid passing user input into methods as parameters

category.description: OWASP API7 Security Misconfiguration
category.name: API7

rule.header: Where multiple handlers are provided in a single try-catch statement or function-try-block for a derived class and some or all of its bases, the handlers shall be ordered most-derived to base class
Do not leave 'catch' blocks empty

category.description: OWASP API9 Improper Assets Management
category.name: API9

rule.header: All usage of assembler shall be documented
Use of floating-point arithmetic shall be documented
All uses of the #pragma directive shall be documented and explained
Objects or functions with external linkage shall be declared in a header file
Assert liberally to document internal assumptions and invariants
When using enum, the values of each member should be explicitly declared
Document integer division

category.description: OWASP Top 10 Most Critical Web Application Security Risks (2021)
category.name: OWASP2021

category.description: OWASP A7 Identification and Authentication Failures
category.name: A7

rule.header: Do not use weak encryption functions

category.description: OWASP A8 Software and Data Integrity Failures
category.name: A8

rule.header: Use care to ensure that LoadLibrary() will load the correct library

category.description: OWASP A9 Security Logging and Monitoring Failures
category.name: A9

rule.header: All exceptions should be rethrown or logged with standard logger

category.description: OWASP A1 Broken Access Control
category.name: A1

rule.header: Observe correct revocation order while relinquishing privileges
Ensure that privilege relinquishment is successful

category.description: OWASP A5 Security Misconfiguration
category.name: A5

rule.header: Where multiple handlers are provided in a single try-catch statement or function-try-block for a derived class and some or all of its bases, the handlers shall be ordered most-derived to base class
Do not leave 'catch' blocks empty
Don't use hard coded value of offset in structures
Don't use hex constant '0xffffffff' as an error marker
A pointer to a long should not be casted to an int pointer
Do not cast an int pointer to a long pointer
Algorithms shall not make assumptions concerning the order of allocation of nonstatic data members separated by an access specifier
Assigning result of ints operation to long without casting at least one of the ints is not allowed
Do not assign a long int to an int
Do not pass long casted to an int in function call
Constant assignment to long should not involve int literals
Do not initialize a long int with int literals
Do not assign the value from 32 bit multiplication to long type
The type int shall always be declared as unsigned int or signed int
Avoid conversions from "shorter" type to "longer" type in assignment
Do not cast from "shorter" type to "longer" type
Avoid conversions from a "shorter" type to a "longer" type in function calls
Don't use 'i64' or 'L' suffixes directly
Instead of casting a long type operand of an expression to int cast the result of the expression
Do not declare variables of long type directly
Do not assign a long value to a double
The names of identifiers should not be longer than 64 characters
Avoid implicit conversions to a type of narrower size
Avoid conversions of constant values to a narrower type
A pointer to a structure should not be passed to a function that writes data to a file
Type long double shall not be used
Type wchar_t shall not be used
User-specified C++ external identifiers should differ in the first 64 characters
User-specified C++ internal identifiers should differ from external identifiers in the first 64 characters
User-specified C++ internal identifiers declared in the same scope should differ in the first 64 characters
User-specified C external identifiers should differ in the first 31 characters
User-specified C internal identifiers should differ from external identifiers in the first 31 characters
User-specified C internal identifiers declared in the same scope should differ in the first 31 characters
The names of identifiers should not be longer than 31 characters
The names of macro identifiers should not be longer than 31 characters
Do not throw an exception across execution boundaries
Do not pass a nonstandard-layout type object across execution boundaries
Use capital 'L' instead of lowercase 'l' to indicate long
Use arrays of int types instead of large arrays of longs
Use arrays of int types instead of dynamic allocated large arrays of longs
Don't use large arrays of pointers to bool, char, short, int and float types
Don't use macros in include statement
In a macro function, use parentheses before and after multiplication or division
Do not allow absolute or relative path names in #include statements
The #include directive shall use the <filename.h> notation to include header files
Avoid using macro definitions
The #include pre-processor directive will only be used to include header (*.h) files
The #ifndef pre-processor directive will only be used to prevent multiple inclusions of the same header file
The #endif pre-processor directives will only be used to prevent multiple inclusions of the same header file
The #if pre-processor directive will only be used to prevent multiple inclusions of the same header file
The #ifdef, #else, #elif preprocessor directives should not be used
The #if preprocessor directive should not be used
C++ macros shall only be used for include guards, type qualifiers, or storage class specifiers
Macro should not contain token pasting, variable argument list nor recursive macro calls
All macros must expand into complete syntactic units
Pointer dereference operations may not be hidden in macro definitions
A macro parameter immediately following a # operator shall not immediately be followed by or preceded by a ## operator
The input/output library stdio.h shall not be included
The controlling expression of a #if or #elif preprocessing directive shall evaluate to 0 or 1
Match the filename in a #include directive to the one on the filesystem
#error directive shall not be used
The #pragma directive shall not be used
All macro identifiers in preprocessor directives shall be defined before use, except in #ifdef and #ifndef preprocessor directives and the defined() operator
#undef shall not be used
The #ifndef, #ifdef, #if, #elif, #else, and #endif pre-processor directives shall only be used for conditional file inclusion and include guards
Do not use the 'bool', 'false' or 'true' identifiers in the #undef directive
Don't redefine primitive types
Don't define part of statement
A macro parameter used as an operand to the # or ## operators, which is itself subject to further macro replacement, shall only be used as an operand to these operators
Incorrect 'NULL' definition
Avoid token concatenation that may produce universal character names
Place an opening brace '{' on its own line
Place a closing brace '}' on its own line
Physical lines should be less than eighty characters
The length of a macro should not exceed 10 lines
Only one statement shall be allowed per line
There shall be a single ASCII space character preceding assignment operators
There shall be a single ASCII space character following assignment operators
There shall be a single ASCII space character preceding bitwise operators
There shall be a single ASCII space character following bitwise operators
There shall be a single ASCII space character preceding and following bitwise operator '&'
There shall be a single ASCII space character between a conditional statement keyword and its opening parenthesis
There shall be a maximum of 1 ASCII space character following the opening parenthesis in conditional statements
There shall be a single ASCII space character preceding ternary conditional operator
There shall be a single ASCII space character following ternary conditional operator
There shall be a single ASCII space character preceding and following relational and equality operators
There shall be no white space following '.' or '->' operator
There shall be no white space preceding '.' or '->' operator
There shall be a single ASCII space character following all commas
There shall be a single ASCII space character following all semicolons
There should be no space between a unary operator "!" or "~" and its operand
There should be no space between a increment/decrement operator (++/--) and its operand
There shall be no white spaces between the 'return' statement or the 'sizeof' operator and the following opening parenthesis
There shall be no spaces after the opening '(' and before closing ')' parenthesis that enclose the operand of the 'return' statement or the 'sizeof' operator
The operand of the 'sizeof' operator should be enclosed in parentheses
Parenthesis shall be used with the "return" statement
There shall be a single ASCII space character preceding and following logical operators
Line should be indented by a multiple of four spaces
In a function definition, the return type of the function should be written on a separate line directly above the function name
Multiple variable declarations shall not be allowed on the same line
Place left parenthesis directly after function name
Separate logical tests in conditional expressions
Each variable should be declared in a separate declaration statement
Braces "{}" which enclose a block should be placed in the same column
When declaring functions, the leading parenthesis and the first argument are to be written on the same line as the function name
Sibling statement lines should be indented to the same level
First line in control statement body should be indented more than control statement keyword

When declaring functions with more than 2 parameters, the leading parenthesis and the first argument are to be written on the same line as the function name, each additional argument will be written on a separate line
Braces ("{}") which enclose a block will have nothing else on the line except comments
Braces ("{}") which enclose a block will be placed in the same column
Braces ("{}") which enclose a block will not have an empty line after "{" nor before "}"
There should be no space between a unary operator "&", "*", "+", "-" and its operand
There should be no space between an increment/decrement operator (++/--) and its operand in macro definition
Place CV-qualifiers on the right hand side of the type they apply to
CV-qualifiers shall be placed on the right hand side of the type that is a typedef or a using name
Parameter names in function declarations should not be enclosed in parentheses
Local variable names in variable declarations should not be enclosed in parentheses
The dereference operator '*' and the address-of operator '&' should be directly connected with the type
Sort #include directives in alphabetical order
Tabs that do not use ASCII spaces shall not be used
White spaces after the opening square bracket '[' and before its closing square bracket ']' shall be used in consistent way
There shall be no space between '[' opening square bracket and preceding token
Number of blocks of code in a function
Number of function calls within function
Class inheritance level
Number of data member(s) per class should not exceed 15
Number of methods per class
Number of parameter(s) per method should not exceed 10
Number of private data member(s) per class
Number of private methods per class
Number of protected data member(s) per class
Number of protected methods per class
Number of public data member(s) per class
Number of public methods per class
Avoid functions with more than 5 parameters
Macros should not use more than 5 parameters
Follow the Cyclomatic Complexity limit of 10
The percentage of comment lines versus the total number of module lines should be between 20 and 60
Avoid too long functions (declarations and statements)
Avoid too long functions (blocks)
Avoid functions with over 75 lines of code
Nested block depth should not be higher than 5
Any one function (or method) will contain no more than 200 logical source lines of code (L-SLOCs)
Source lines will be kept to a length of 120 characters or less
Functions with more than 7 parameters will not be used
Follow the Cyclomatic Complexity limit of 20
No function should be longer than 60 lines of code
The assertion density of the code should average to a minimum of two assertions per function
All functions with more than 20 lines should contain at least 2 assertions
A global function should not be called from more than 5 different functions
A function should not call more than 7 different functions
The number of statements within function should be in range 1 - 50
The value of VOCF metric for a function should not be higher than 4
Statements within function should not be nested deeper than 4 levels
The number of blocks of comments before and inside function to the number of statements in function should be > 0.2
Report the value of Halstead's delivered bugs (B) for a function
The number of execution paths in a function should not be higher than 80
Avoid functions with over 50 lines
Avoid switch statements with many cases
Avoid structs, unions, or classes with more than 20 fields
Avoid source files that are longer than 500 lines
Report Cyclomatic Complexity
Report Essential Complexity
Follow the Essential Complexity limit of 4
Follow the Essential Complexity limit of 10
Follow the Essential Complexity limit of 1

category.description: MISRA C 1998
category.name: MISRA

rule.header: Only use characters defined in the ISO C standard
Values of character types shall be restricted to a defined and documented subset of ISO 10646-1
Do not use wide string literals
The basic types of char, int, short, long, float and double should not be used, but specific-length equivalents should be typedef'd
Explicitly declare 'char' type as signed or unsigned
The underlying bit representations of floating point numbers shall not be used
All functions shall be declared before use
Identifiers shall not simultaneously have both internal and external linkage in the same translation unit
External object should not be declared in more than one file
External objects should not be declared in implementation files
The use of a tag shall agree with its declaration
All automatic variables shall have been assigned a value before being used
The right-hand operand of a shift operator shall lie between zero and one less than the width in bits of the underlying type of the left-hand operand
The comma operator shall not be used, except in the control expression of a for loop
Implicit conversions from wider to narrower integral type which may result in a loss of information shall not be used
Avoid mixing arithmetic of different precisions in the same expression
Implicit conversions from integral to floating type which may result in a loss of information shall not be used
Implicit conversions from integral constant to floating type which may result in a loss of information shall not be used
Redundant explicit cast to the same type is not allowed
Do not use the volatile keyword
Assignment statements should not be nested within other assignment statements
Avoid possible integer overflow in expressions in which the result is cast to a wider integer type
Don't cast the dividend of two integers to a floating-point type
Avoid possible integer overflow in expressions in which the result is assigned to a variable of a wider integer type
Avoid unintentionally discarding the remainder of integer division
A null statement shall only occur on a line by itself
Do not use the break statement
Do not use floating point variables as loop counters
Do not use functions with variable numbers of arguments
Functions shall have prototype declarations and the prototype shall be visible at both the function definition and call
Functions shall always have visible prototype at the function call
Provide none or all identifiers for function arguments
Provide expression for return statement of non-void functions
Avoid expressions in return statements of void functions
The #include directive shall be followed by either a <filename> or "filename" sequence
Enclose in parentheses whole definition of a function-like macro
Use only non-ambiguous forms of defined pre-processor operator
Pointer arithmetic should not be used
Do not use non-constant pointers to functions
All the functions pointed to by a single pointer to function shall be identical in the number and type of parameters and the return type
The NULL pointer shall not be dereferenced
The NULL pointer shall not be dereferenced
All members of structure or union should be fully specified
Unions shall not be used to access the sub-parts of larger data structure
All the members of a structure (or class/union) shall be named
Standard library function names shall not be reused
Do not use 'setlocale' function
Do not include <locale.h> header
Objects or functions with external linkage shall be declared in a header file
Provisions should be made for appropriate run-time checking
Provisions should be made for appropriate run-time checking
Use type suffix for numeric constants
Use type suffix for numeric constants
Use type suffix for numeric constants
Use type suffix for numeric constants
Declare objects at function scope
The 'register' storage class specifier shall not be used
Document integer division
Evaluation of constant unsigned integer expressions should not lead to wrap-around
Do not use labels

category.description: Physical File Organization
category.name: PFO

rule.header: Don't define entities with linkage in a header file
Use multiple include guards
An include file should not contain more than one class definition
File with extension '.c' may not include other files with extension '.c'
Never include other files in a file with extension '.icc'
Use multiple include guards with pattern based on the header file name
Use mechanism that prevents multiple inclusion of the file i.e. include guards or "#pragma once" preprocessor directive
"#pragma once" preprocessor directive should not be used in source files
Do not define more than on class in a header file
Every implementation file should declare a local constant string that describes the file

category.description: STL Best Practices
category.name: STL

rule.header: To make copying efficient, correct, and immune to the slicing problem create containers of pointers instead of containers of objects
Call empty instead of checking size() against zero
Avoid using iterative calls to insert in an explicit loop
Almost all uses of copy where the destination range is specified using an insert iterator should be replaced with calls to range member functions
Instead of anonymous istream_iterator objects use istream_iterator names when used as function parameters
When using containers of newed pointers, remember to delete the pointers before the container is destroyed
Never create containers of auto_ptrs
Avoid using remove algorithm with list and standard associative containers
Prefer vector and string to dynamically allocated arrays
Use reserve to avoid unnecessary reallocations
Each vector and string should be checked if it is not empty before it is passed to C function
Avoid using vector<bool>
Specify comparison types for associative containers of pointers
For associative containers never use comparison function returning true for equal values
For associative containers never use comparison function returning true for equal values
Prefer iterator to const iterator, reverse_iterator, and const_reverse_iterator
Use distance and advance to convert a container's const_iterators to iterators
Make sure destination ranges are big enough
Follow remove-like algorithms by erase to remove elements from a container
Avoid using remove and similar algorithms (i.e., remove_if and unique) on containers of dynamically allocated pointers
Proper implementation of copy_if should not be based on returning the remove_copy_if with a not1 in front of the predicate
If accumulate() is used on a container of floating point values, use floating point value as initial one
Design functor classes for pass-by-value
Make predicates const pure functions
Each functor class should has only one operator() function, and it's parameter and return types should be passed to unary_function or binary_function
You must employ ptr_fun, mem_fun, or mem_fun_ref whenever you pass a function to an STL component
Make sure less<T> means operator<
Prefer algorithm calls to hand-written loops
Prefer member functions to algorithms with the same names
Do not rely on the conversion of count()'s nonzero values to true and zero to false
Do not use an iterator range that isn't really a range
C-style arrays shall not be used
Use != instead of < to compare iterators
Use traits classes in conjunction with overloading
When calling swap, employ a using declaration for std::swap, then call swap without namespace qualification
Do not declare the non-member to be an overloading of std::swap
Member version of swap should never throw exceptions
Consider using vector<char> instead of string
It is necessary to be careful when using reverse_iterator's base iterator for erasure purposes
Consider istreambuf_iterators for character-by-character input
If you pass a sorted range to an algorithm that also takes a comparison function, be sure that the comparison function you pass behaves the same as the one you used to sort the range
Instead of trying to write the container-independent code use class encapsulation
Factor parameter-independent code out of templates
Define non-member functions inside templates when type conversions are desired
Do not overload functions within a template class
In template global functions use 'typename' to identify nested dependent type names
In template classes use 'typename' to identify nested dependent type names
Don't change default arguments of virtual functions in template classes
A copy constructor shall be declared when there is a template constructor with a single parameter that is a generic parameter
The viable function set for a function call should either contain no function specializations, or only contain function specializations
Overloaded function templates shall not be explicitly specialized
All partial and explicit specializations for a template shall be declared in the same file as the declaration of their primary template
A copy assignment operator shall be declared when there is a template assignment operator with a parameter that is a generic parameter
In a class template with a dependent base, any name that may be found in that dependent base shall be referred to using a qualified-id or this->
Do not declare non-member generic functions in associated namespaces
The function shall resolve to a function declared previously in the translation unit
Declare 'extern' an explicitly instantiated template
Template specialization shall be declared in the same file as the primary template or a user-defined type, for which the specialization is declared
Use a trailing return type syntax if the return type is preceded by the 'typename' keyword
A non-member generic operator shall only be declared in a namespace that does not contain class (struct) type, enum type or union type declarations
